description:
I was heading to a barbecue and a friend and I decided to bring some meat. We stopped by Cheung Hing on Saturday, October 13th around 3:15pm. There was a line, but altogether, it took less then 30 mins to order and get our food.

01. Roast Duck ($18.95 ea) x2
02. Roast Pork ($9.95 lb) x2
03. B.B.Q. Pork ($8.35 lb) x2

I love siu yuk (roast duck) and they do it right here. The meat was juicy with a nice chew. And that skin. So deliciously crispy. The siu aap (duck) was tasty. The meat fatty and tender. I'm not a huge cha siu (barbecue pork) person as I find it a little too sweet for my tastes, but everyone seemed to enjoy this.

Solid spot for roasted meats. I know they have kui fei gai / chicken which I adore. Gotta try that next time.

Note: CASH ONLY.
author: Elena N.

description:
So here's the deal...

1. There's a line out the door, almost all the time, for good reason
2. You're better off ordering to-go than trying to dine-in (there's like 4 tables)
3. It definitely helps if you go with someone who speaks Chinese, but you'll still be fine if you don't (pointing helps)
4. Cash only (and bring just more than you think you'll need, your eyes will betray your stomach!)

The roasted meats here are some of the best in the city. You can't go wrong with either the roast duck or BBQ pork (assuming they haven't run out of either....).  

I will say I've gotten some less-than-friendly looks coming here, but only from other customers and never the staff. So as long as you're ok with some open gawking, you'll be grand.
author: Claire S.

description:
Really good Chinese bbq.  The roast duck was so succulent and the bbq pork was sweet and salty.  The only downside was that they ran out of roast pork, which is my favorite.  They are also cash only so make sure you come prepared.  

My wife isn't into Cantonese style cuisine so she ordered the Mongolian Beef which was nice and flavorful.  I really enjoyed their hot and sour soup but it needed more spice as the sour flavors dominated.  I do like that they have a lot of meat in the soup.  

I wish there was something like this in the East Bay but I will definitely come back if I'm ever in the area.
author: Jason L.

description:
Their Roast Duck is amongst the best, if not the best like many have said. The BBQ Pork and Roast Pork are better than average as well. The Soy Sauce Chicken is average. Prices are competitive and good value when it's so good! As an example, you can get half a Roast Duck and a pound of BBQ Pork for around $18.

Located in the Outer Sunset and cash-only but locals will make the trek. Parking is plentiful most of the time, but be wary around lunch and dinnertime - especially the holidays (great spot to grab items before any party or event).

Before eating in you should consider how small the place is, tables/chairs are cramped, and constant foot traffic/noise. Strictly a to-go spot as a result.
author: Peter L.

description:
Basically it's a Chinese takeout deli. You can smell the roasted duck the minute you step out of your car. That's what everybody is here for! Thank goodness I only ordered half a roast duck. It was a ton of duck!

The pieces with lots of meat are super fatty, while the pieces with mostly bone have super crisp skin.  I always go for the latter, personally. I only got through about four pieces before I was completely spent. Looks like I'll have leftovers!

The duck was pretty tasty, but not so much better than the duck at my local 99 Ranch that I would drive up here just for the duck. 

There were 5-6 people ahead of me in line at 5pm on a Tuesday. The line moves quite quickly!
author: Julia C.

description: One of my favorite places to come to for Chinese BBQ meat plates! Love the BBQ Pork Over Rice (#99). It comes with some side veggies as well! Super affordable for SF at $8.95 a plate. Most of the locals get get take-out so there's never really a wait for a table; even though it's super Asian the employees speak English.
author: Alice C.

description: I love siuk york!! This is a fast eating place for lunch. Just sit there, order, eat and leave in total room me 15 minutes. I always walk here and have lunch when alone and don't know what to eat for this would be a good choice
author: Patricia L.

description: Good place for BBQ Chinese food. It gets busy around the evening time. Highly recommended if you're trying to get several last minute items for dinner.
author: Jimmy T.

description:
Was debating between a bbq plate but went with one of my favorite dishes:
Prawns with scrambled eggs chow fun
Delicious with that "seasoned" wok flavor. The dish was of a generous portion with a good amount of shrimp. 

There's only about 4 tables here with the majority of their orders takeout. The roasted duck was a popular item as they kept bringing more out. During the lunch peak, the line was out the door for their precooked food and bbq pork, duck, and roast pork. 

Located directly across from Safeway with plenty of metered street parking in front.
author: Tim Y.

description:
My favorite place for roast pork and roast duck!! SO YUMMY! 

FYI, place accepts cash only!
author: Bonnie T.

description:
BEST. ROAST. DUCK. EVER.

That's really all I need to say for this 5 star roast duck because it's that amazing. If you are looking for great roast duck, this is the place! What makes their roast duck so distinct in flavor, is their sauce! Ask for extra sauce on the side, sprinkle on your rice, and take a spoonful of rice with the duck and boom. Heaven. So much flavor in one bite, plus the duck is so tender and soaked with flavor. The way they marinate their duck is some kind of sorcery, it's just so delicious.
Another dish that is yummy is their green beans. It is a bit on the oily side, but it's so delicious to have a veggie dish on the side to balance the meal (even though duck itself will suffice :D)
I have been eating their roast duck since I was a kid, and my parents drive all the way from the Easy Bay to SF for this duck. It's amazing and please go try it. You won't be disappointed. Ultimate favorite. :)
author: Jenny L.

description:
Ok wait. 

So much meats. Allll the proteins. So many things I love to eat, perfectly executed, well-priced.

BBQ Pork: sticky, charred ends that taste like meat candy and soft tender center pieces. I almost forgot I don't like to eat pork when I was eating this.

Roast Pork: tender meat, crunchy skin. Sadly this was missing a lot of crunchy skin parts with the meaty pieces so yeah. 

Princess Chicken with ginger. Steamed chicken perfection. 

Soy Sauce Chicken: savory deliciousness

Peking duck: yum! Wish it came with buns, hoisin, and green onions! 

Yang Chow Fried Rice: "everything" in it fried rice perfection 

The line is long but it moves quickly. If you love Chinese deli's - this is a good one. 

Ah - most important part? You can ask for LIVE CHICKENS like I did and taste how delicious a live bird is. Fresh is best! 

I called my order in a few days in advance to ensure the duck and live chickens were made just for me. You can do that too - phone your large order in ahead of time. 

Back on track - the price? So much food for $130. 

Bring cash. It's cash only (good for them - avoiding those pesky merchant terminal fees) 

It's perfect except one thing. MSG. 

I can't wait to visit again! My family and colleagues loved it!
author: Jennifer C P.

description:
Cheung Hing is your one stop shop for when you're craving some Chinese bbq meat. Don't be intimidated by the line out the door since it's a small primarily takeout place and they're pretty efficient so the line moves rather quick. I actually prefer the long lines because the meat is not left sitting for too long since they're always cooking up the next batch of bbq meat. 

Be prepared to order or you'll be holding up the line. I usually get the roast duck ($11/half or $18/whole) and bbq pork ($8.25/lb). There's also roast pork, chicken (five spice, soy sauce, free range, soy sauce), cuttle fish, pork ear/tongue/stomach, chicken feet, as well as cooked dishes. Both the roast duck and bbq pork were really good. Apart from the good seasoning/flavors, the duck isn't too fatty and the bbq pork isn't too lean. I usually frequent Ming Kee on Ocean Avenue because it's closer but actually prefer Cheung Hing.

There's only a few tables which is fine since most people do takeout. Cash only.
author: Ruby C.

description:
The roast duck and food portion lived up to the hype! My roast duck and chicken combo along with string beans were delicious.  By the time I got there, there was no more BBQ pork. So go there early! 

My only complaint is that the floor was a bit slippery, so hope they can attend to that since I saw many elderly who dine in. 

I would come back again - earlier next time for my BBQ pork.
author: J. Y.

description:
CASH ONLY Thank you yelpers for pointing me in this direction.  This place reminds me of a couple of the better spots in Oakland's Chinatown. 

I simply went with a little bit of the BBQ Pork and BBQ Duck over rice.  They throw in some cabbage and just the meat, rice, cabbage go very well with one another to create a great taste that I had not had for awhile. 

Service is friendly and as others have noted the line moves relatively fast. 

Good value as well especially by SF standards since the hearty combo  above ran me $10 and some change.
author: Rod M.

description:
There's a reason why there's always a line queued up here. Their meats are top notched and very flavorful.

Roast Duck - must try.. one of the few places where the skin is crispy (but not potato chip crunchy) and the meat is flavorful and tender. (make sure you tell them you don't want plum sauce... else they may include it and charge you an extra $0.50)

BBQ Pork - must try..

BBQ Spare Ribs - try.

Their hot plates - must try: stuffed tofu, salt and pepper chicken wings. Pretty much everything but skip the vegetables. 

If you plan to eat here, go for their rice plates or porridge only. Skip the noodles and skip the wonton/dumplings. This place is known for their BBQ stuff. 

Bring cash and if not you'll need to go a few doors down to the ATM
author: Eric T.

description:
The best roast duck you can get in San Francisco. And that's a BIG statement. This place constantly has a line out the door for their duck and bbq meats. You know a place is good when a bunch of elderly Chinese people are willing to stand in line for 20 mins for some food! There isn't a lot of seating, and the place is small, but that's okay. Most people order their food a la carte and to go!

The duck meat is the perfect ratio of fat and meat, is juicy, and flavorful. Best eaten when hot, my mom always gets a whole duck and we have an amazing dish for the next few meals. I also want to take one with me whenever I head back to San Diego for college. This is something you can't find anywhere else!

Another notable dish is the bbq pork. When it's fresh, the pork is so tender and flavorful. Pair it with some cabbage and rice and you have an amazing meal. YUMMERS!

If you are ever in the area, you CANNOT miss out on trying the duck from Cheung Hing.
author: Golden H.

description:
That was some damn good roast duck. I'm always torn between roast duck and crispy pork, but I'm glad I got my duck on rice platter the other day! I usually never finish a full serving, but I cleaned my plate (except for all the rice)! The duck had a nice thin layer of fat, the meat was moist, and the generous side of cabbage was deliciously meaty as well. 

The line was consistently out the door on a Friday at lunchtime. I can see why most people get takeout or party trays, parking here can get quite expensive at 25 cents for only 6 minutes! Next time I've got a craving for some Chinese BBQ, this is definitely my go-to spot in SF.
author: Christine L.

description:
I have been coming to this place since I was in grade school! It's crazy to see how much they have improved over the years. 

It's my go to restaurant for some Chinese BBQ essentials-- especially when I want to throw a party! The prices are fair and the food here is absolutely delicious.

I 100% stand by other reviewer's thoughts their roast duck being so delicious. I would even dare to say it's the tastiest outside Asia. I would recommend ordering a whole roast duck to share or a roast duck over rice and steamed cabbage meal for one. It's so tender and flavorful! It's really a party in your mouth. When I was little, my parents would buy me a roast duck over rice from here to eat while they worked nearby. I really do regard this restaurant and their roast duck as my comfort food. Everyone I have shared the roast duck with, loved it as well! It's not a surprise that their line is out the door every time I come into town to visit now.

I also love their fried pork belly and char siu pork. My family and friends will send me here to buy these to bring home (and I live 2 hours away)! 

CASH ONLY!

They speak both Cantonese and Mandarin... and a little English too! Don't be afraid to try it!
author: Laurie H.

description:
This place is super delicious! I've been meaning to try this place for a while and my friends and I decided to come. It is a bit crowded and there aren't that many tables, as well as a giant line getting the BBQ items to-go, but we still managed to find a spot quickly and efficiently.

I had the 2 item bbq plate, and I chose the roast pork and the duck. For the roast pork, you have the choice of getting it with belly meat or lean meat, and I chose the belly meat, which made it taste amazing, but it was very rich and felt quite guilty. It was crispy on the outside and tender and juicy on the inside though which was amazing.

The duck was excellently flavored as well. It is a bit on the fattier side in parts, but it was still delicious and the duck had a rich and amazing flavor, while still being crisp enough on the outside. Not as amazing as the ducks you get in Beijing, but I guess this is a solid Cantonese style duck.

You can also request plum sauce on the side if you want something to dip the duck in. Overall it's a super delicious place, and at ~$10 a plate is a steal for being in San Francisco.
author: Tyler T.

description: Good food, but the owner's got very arrogant attitude!!!!! Very snotty about tips. A very bad experience dining here
author: Teng I.

description:
You rock Cantonese people. Ma people!

It's normal to pass by Cheung Hing and seeing a long line outside. Luckily this is just the to-go line where everyone orders the delicious roasted duck, roasted pork or other meat.

We ate here on a Sunday so the tables were all free and we didn't want to wait.

Like every Asian place, the service is super fast. The food was great. I'm a vegetarian so I don't know about the meat. But the whole duck my friends ordered was amazingly crispy according to them.
author: Tim C.

description: Duck, duck and duck! the seasoning is what made it stand out. skin is crispy and meat is tender
author: Souris L.

description: Best roast duck and soy sauce chicken ever. So fresh and the flavor is just different from every where else. BBQ pork and roast pork also delicious. There's always a line but they move fast. Some customers buy multiple boxes. Be sure to bring cash as credit is not accepted. I've eaten here and the food is pretty good but you come for the barbecue. There are two types of chicken. One is more expensive but the chicken has more meat.
author: Nancy P.

description:
Came here for the roast duck, spicy eggplant, and pig feet.

Note: came here at 6:50 and ordered the second to last duck.

This duck, wow. Can't talk enough about it. It's got that sort of crispy skin like Peking duck, but the layer right underneath the skin is so fatty. Every bite is flavorful. Never did I need any sauce or anything.

The eggplant. Eh, they put a lot of starch in to make it thick, and the texture of the eggplant was good. Flavor was similar to that of hot and sour soup. Would pass on this.

Pig feet, also flavored that of sweet and sour. The texture was good and it was sticky. Would also pass on this.

Just come here for the duck, that itself will make this a 5 star experience.
author: Victor D.

description:
Just returned from a day trip on the SF Peninsula, where I experienced one of the worst Asian meals ever.  Service was distant and uninvolved at best, but the food was even worse.

Barbecue Pork:  small, bone-ridden chunks that were under-cooked and under-seasoned.  A Chinese restaurant that does not understand how to deal with pork ??

Leaf Cabbage:  No flavor whatsoever.  Had to salt and pepper to even stomach the serving.

Sticky Rice:  Acceptable, but nothing noteworthy.

Duck:  My wife liked the duck, but little else.  

What a disappointing experience....  Why would Peninsula Asian customers find this place acceptable at all?
author: Ron C.

description:
Stopped here on a Friday evening as there are so many positive reviews for this place. They sadly didn't have any bbq or roasted duck/pork when we came in. I think that's what they're best known for. 

So we ordered the shrimp wonton soup and the tomato beef with crispy noodles. Both were pretty delicious. If you're not a fan of sweet food though, I don't recommend the tomato beef. Very sweet overall. Two dishes were plenty enough for two (perhaps too much!). Check was under $20. 

In terms of atmosphere, it's your typical hole in the wall Chinese deli. It was kind of cold inside and the interior is worn. So don't come here if you're looking for somewhere super fancy. 

I'll have to update this review if I ever get to try the items that they're best known for. Otherwise, good place for cheap Chinese food.
author: Julie L.

description:
I remember when this place first opened sum 30 years ago.  It's actually better now.  Perhaps it's the cutting block where anything that gets chopped on it, it soaks "damn good" flavors. 

Real talk...get there early because it does get very busy as it should.  Know what you want to order.  If you dont, get out of line and look thru the front window like a noob, everyone starts a noob it's okay.  It's cash only so no line foul by saying, sorry I didnt know.  If you can get out of there without getting yelled at, you're ahead of the game.

Roast pork is amazing.  So tender with a slightly salty/savory brine flavor that will make you shake your head in disbelief.  Then...then...you bite into the crispy skin.  Holy shiz...makes you want to slap something or someone because it's so damn good!  Then you use the ever so cheap plastic fork they give you to scoop as much rice as possible and you chuck it in your mouth, times 2, don't forget a bite of cabbage then chew.  Close your eyes and taste the sauce they've rendered from meat...then you say, this is so "damn good.". 

Best roast pork ever!
author: Dan S.

description:
Delicious. Their ducks are definitely bigger and contains slight more fat then other restaurants I've tasted. 

We had roasted duck porridge (it's just duck on porridge, but Cantonese is also good at making good and fine porridge, it was very tasty! The juice and oil of the duck mixed into the bowl... yum), and 3 mix rice (duck, script skin BBQ pork, and duck liver) this was delicious too! 

The rice was well cooked and the meat were put on top, so the juice will go into the rice! Also this dish will have a little bit of veggie to go with. 

I wish I could have taken one whole duck togo. It was that good!
author: Sarah N.

description: While I am not a fan of roast duck (or duck in general) my husband says it's the best roast duck he's had in the Bay Area/SF. I myself am a big fan of the regular food menu. Having only gone twice, I've only tried a few things - the BBQ Pork fried rice is yummy and the Won Ton Soup (that my kid ordered) had a delicious clean broth. The won ton itself was simple, a decent big bite and juicy. I would definitely order that again as a noodle dish or try a BBQ Pork noodle bowl. They do a good job of catering to American-Chinese dishes (Beef with American Broccoli, etc) and the prices are really decent for the portion size you get. Will definitely be coming back here again and adding it to the takeout food rotation.
author: Maria G.

description:
Bad. They don't accept a cards, cash only pay.
Bad. They don't accept a cards, cash only pay.
author: Arkadiy V.

description:
My review can only be for the cha siu (BBQ Roast Pork), currently sold for $7.80/lb. This is the only thing that I have purchased and will continuously go out of my way to come here to purchase. It's totally worth it! Eventually, I'm sure I will try the other offerings, but this place literally has the best cha siu I have had since coming to SF. It's tender, a little fatty, not dry at all and extremely flavorful. There are only two other places that I will repeatedly travel out of my way to get cha siu from and they're both in NY (Queens and BK!). 

I highly recommend this spot - there is usually always a line outside to purchase their food - they have roast duck, chicken, siew pork etc. all the offerings of your typical chinese establishment. There is little seating available - do not expect anything fancy but do expect to get a good bang for your buck! I'm telling you that cha siu is delicious. so. worth. it.
author: Deanna S.

description:
Many reviews against the butcher is accurate.  This particular individual has a stinky attitude and from time to time makes customers feel like begging for their food.  If you ask for one pound of roast pork, good luck.  I guarantee you will get a pond and half and of course, the extra half pound is NOT free.  Also if you want just half of a duck, too bad, you have to buy a whole duck because... because he wants you to.  

This stinky attitude sadly has been shared throughout the restaurant and obviously does not correspond to the  basic business principle which should be customers first.  For this reason I'd givethis restaurant two star.  Without the attitude it is a 5-star restaurant.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Hole in the wall but the bbq pork and ribs are some of the best in sf.  Roast duck is good also 
Always a line and cash only.  They also have very good rice vermicelli and noodles , I always buy them for the family.  Typically Chinese joint, employees a bit gruff and you kinda of worry about the cleanliness of the place but haven't been sick yet from their food from all these years
author: KW L.

description: So freakin' full of fatty and meaty deliciousness- the steamed, yet delicate cabbage and rice holds all the wonderful flavors together. I had the duck liver, roast pork, and roast duck over rice and steamed cabbage. Best time to go is in the morning on a weekday where the line is at a minimum
author: Anna D.

description:
The best Chinese BBQ in SF, arguably over any Chinatown spot. It's a hole in a wall with a steady line out but moves quickly so you should be in and out in 10 minutes. The roast pig and roast pork are my favorite and my dad favors the roast duck. Cash only but there's a BofA next door and a Safeway if you're strapped for cash (buy Hawaiian king rolls + $20 cash back and that's dinner, baby!). 

Knocking off a star for a few small things ... 

1) They sell out of the popular items so be sure to have a second favorite order of meat. Next one out won't be for another hour and there's no way to time what's gonna run out. 80% of the time you're fine but beware. 

2) It's a bit grimy but the place has been here for decades. For the record, I've never been sick from the food but the frequent low health ratings do raise an eyebrow.

3) Language barrier = inaccurate orders. Most of the time I'm good but every now and then I accidentally over order. You order 1/2 pound but they hear 1.5 pounds or half a duck and they start cutting up a whole one before it's too late. A good problem but hurts the wallet ... so have some hungry friends to share it with.

Gripes aside, I've been going here since 2010 and will be eating here until my last days in SF.
author: Tee T.

description:
The meats you get at the counter are good, especially the BBQ pork.

We ordered noodle soup off the menu, probably our mistake. The soups were really salty, and mediocre. 

Come here for the takeout, don't stay for anything else
author: Mimi T.

description:
Cheung Hing's high ratings were what drew me to this restaurant after browsing through Yelp for places to eat. They have a banner that proudly proclaims them to be one of the top 100 best Chinese restaurants in the US. But apparently this sign was from before 2014, so I don't know how legit it is now that it's 2017. A ton of people walking in and out despite the cramped tables and not so clean interior. We decided to give it a try since we were already there. 

Once we were seated, we were informed that the roasted duck - sold out. BBQ pork - sold out. Pretty much everything we wanted was sold out. We were tempted to walk out of the restaurant, but the waitress convinced us to try some other dishes and so we reluctantly stayed. 

Roasted pork: I love a good roasted pork, especially when the skin is crispy and the meat is tender and not too salty. Unfortunately the skin of the pork was chewy and soggy, while the meat was a bit too salty. Not a big fan of their roasted pork that night. 

Chicken: Not too bad. The skin and the meat was tender and tasty. This was probably the best dish of the night from the restaurant. 

Veggies: Ordered a plate of vegetables. Quality was pretty good and the vegetables were definitely fresh, although way overpriced for what you can buy and cook yourself. 

They actually have more locations in SF that looked much cleaner and more modernized, so I definitely should have consulted Yelp a bit more before stopping here. Floor was a health hazard - super wet and very easy to slip. Service was not the best; probably typical service you might expect to get from these local Chinese restaurants. 

tl;dr - Eh, below average Chinese restaurant. Maybe if we got the BBQ pork, roasted duck, or soy sauce chicken, I might have thought otherwise. I'll give this place another try only to try the roasted pork or duck.
author: Tiffany C.

description: The bbq pork and the crispy skin pig are delicious.....there's always a line out front and you'll see why once you try the bbq!!
author: Al T.

description: This is my spot for bbq meat when I'm in the area.  Order up a half pound cha siu, half pound siu yook and it's a wrap.  The lines can get long sometimes and if you're going near closing your meat of choice might be missing, but it's a no frills place to order some food or if you really want, to sit down and eat.  If you're worried about the health score, just don't come here then, but I think they're always harsher on Chinese places about that most likely from people complaining. (The same people that complain about service at a Chinese restaurant).  I've been here enough times that I should have been sick but haven't ever gotten sick so I'll keep coming
author: Alexander C.

description: Great place and great prices. Their BBQ pork and pork ribs are def a must try. Their noodles and rice is also good. Hard to find these places in the city but they are out there and def worth going
author: Ivan C.

description: This place is amazing, don't verve off their specialities . Duck &BBQ Pork are the true winners. I also give the Hot/Sour soup high marks with a lot of taste and substance. Wait in line , drive or whatever to eat here.
author: j. g.

description:
This place has really good bbq pork! The meat was flavorful and not dry. Had the right amount of sweet and sticky-ness! 
I also ordered roasted duck and roasted pork. The roasted duck was good. It wasn't overly salty taste and the meat had a lot of juice to it. The skin had a little crunch to it..which was amazing. The roasted pork was ok, imo. The skin was crispy and everything but the meat was a bit dry. Maybe because there wasn't much fat in the meat.
We went there during lunch and dinner hour on different days and there was a line out the door but it moves pretty fast. 
It's a small place with a few tables but it can get crowded so I suggest getting your food to go.
author: Jenny M.

description:
BE CAREFUL!!!! Greasy and Dirty Environment. 

They do not welcome new customers because you suppose to know how to order before coming here. 

Salty Chinese food and the worst service!!
author: Irene F.

description:
I wasn't surprised when I saw their poor hygiene score by the food department when attempting to write this review.
This is the lowest of rating I've given a restaurant. I usually try not to give negative feedbacks on eatery for one time visit if the food is mediocre.
This restaurant indeed serves a good tasty roast duck. That's a 4 stars on that dish. However, my recent dining experience there with my family was horrific! The entire wait staff was so rude. 
We ordered some roast duck, veggies and 3 bowls of wonton noodles. When the food came, only one bowl of noodles arrived. We told them what was ordered and instead of apologizing, the waitress was arguing we had ordered one! 
It took extremely long for the 2 other bowls to arrive. When we reminded them we are still waiting for our food, the waitress shouted back "have to cook"! Then she turned to the other 2 waitresses and made some unkind remarks in Cantonese. They didn't know or couldn't care less we understood Cantonese. My sister couldn't resist answering them back and they actually came to the table to argue back! OMG! OMG!!
When the noodles finally arrived, we didn't dare to eat for fear there might be "additional" ingredients in the noodles. 
We weren't expecting fine dining service at this place. All they need to do is said the orders is perhaps mixed up and the food will be out shortly. Don't need all the dramas...
Not going back even if the roast duck is free!
author: Melissa T.

description:
Best roast duck!!! I feel like unless you are Chinese or speak Chinese, you won't really understand or enjoy this place. I know the place looks dirty and the service is poor but most OG Chinese places are like this. It's very homey and nostalgic for me. 

This is where my grandma used to take me. And many others come here from word of mouth or through family.
author: Becca W.

description:
I heard this was one of the best Chinese BBQ places in the city, but I'd have to say meh, I've had better. 

I tried their roast duck here twice. While the flavor is good, I didn't think it was as moist as some of the other roast ducks I've had. Actually I have to say it was a little too salty for me. I've had it over rice and in noodle soup, and both times they gave me very fatty pieces with barely any meat.
author: Jen P.

description: Awesome stop for dry fried chicken and roast pork on the way home ... be careful for timing on arrival as it gets super crowded before early dinner. Only five tables for "dine in" so take out your best bet.
author: Casey A.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon and the line was pretty short.  We ordered a full duck to go and boy is it as good as the ratings and reviews show.  Will definitely come back!
author: Siv L.

description:
This place is by far the cheapest and the best Chinese restaurant that I have tried. There's usually a line out the door, and the inside is quite small so I always call ahead and get take out. I think they are known for their roast duck, but because I'm not a huge fan of duck, I always order the beef chow fun dry and it's delicious. BF usually orders roast duck, beef chow fun with eggs. 

I'm honestly not a huge fan of Chinese food as it could get too greasy for me, but if I'm ever craving Chinese food on a rare occasion, I always find myself ordering from here. Super cheap and huge portions. Can't beat that!
author: Elaine C.

description: I hate lines. But this Chinese BBQ is worth the wait. It's busiest before dinner time. If you don't like to wait, then pass the line and order something from the buffet. They've got it all, including braised pork belly.
author: William B.

description: Five stars for the food one star for customer service. Last Sunday was my first time there, the tall Asian lady who takes orders was very rude and unprofessional. She was trying to rush me while I was asking questions about different dishes they offered. She kept helping other customers while I was trying to order then she got frustrated when I asked a question about one of the dishes. I will be back for the roasted duck, hopefully with a better experience.
author: J P.

description:
I can see why this place always has a line, even at 3 pm on a weekday. Their Chinese BBQ is delicious!

Stopped by with my +1 who was raving about CH's roast duck. We chose to dine in and each ordered the two BBQ item over rice plate, with roast duck and roast pork as our BBQ options. When the plates came out, I was pleasantly surprised by the generous portions--several slices of each BBQ item over A LOT of rice, and cabbage on the side. Both of the meats were very flavorful, not too salty, had crispy skins (YUMMM), and juicy tender meat. I ate so much and still had enough for a second meal! Each plate was $10, so very worth it :)

I'll definitely be back here whenever I'm in the area again.
author: Leanne C.

description:
I had to go to Safeway across the street from Cheung Hing and was craving BBQ after shopping. So, I dropped my groceries and walked on over.

The first thing you notice when you upon this place is the poultry hanging in the window. The roast duck and chicken looks phenomenal. This is definitely an eye catcher to those passing by on the street or sidewalk. I saw ribs as well and knew I had to get something from here. 

Once inside I noticed that the seating was very LIMITED. Actually, there are signs posted to just take a seat at a table if you want to dine in. Also, the seats are reserved for those that want to dine in as well. The signs come off as a bit aggressive which was a somewhat of a turn off. When you walked in you see the menu to your right on the wall. I thought initially that they only offered to poultry by the pound but I did see a menu at the end of the counter. Fortunately, I knew I wanted BBQ ribs and that was my aim in coming here. After placing my order I was considering buying more food but that seemed to be a bit much for just me, I like to eat but this would've been excessive.

When I finally placed my order the butcher began to chop up the BBQ ribs. He was rather aggressive and excited while he was chopping. I don't know if that is how most butchers are but he was really into it. The cost for the pound came out to $8.70 total. All things considered that was a bargain in my opinion.

While I placed my order the female cashier and someone in the back were yelling back and forth to each other. It was a bit odd and confusing. I could tell by her face that it was not something good. Because I could not understand what was being said I just waiting to get my food rung up. But, when I finally got ready to pay she seemed upset and frustrated. I just got some bad vibes from here. Not very welcoming or inviting. Oh, I forgot to mention that out of the maybe 5 or 6 tables here there was only one table that was occupied and that was by the staff who happened to be taking a break. My guess is that eating here is not the best option.

After paying for my food I grabbed a menu and headed out. 

When I finally got home I had a chance to review the menu. There are some really good options for food here but I am not sure that I would want to come back to such a unstable environment. I would like to try the running chicken with rice but we'll have to see.

As far as my food goes, it was OK. Good sweet ribs that I mixed with some steamed rice. I did feel that the ribs were cut into pieces way too small but the flavor was still good. I was able to save some for tomorrow because the pound was actually more than what I needed. Good ribs and a good meal. 

If the workers here could get along and customer service improved I could see this place getting a lot of good reviews. 

I am satisfied with what I ordered but I hope that next time I come here things have improved for the better. 

#bbqribsIgotdibs
author: Robert F.

description: I've always stop by here when I'm the area. The bbq meats is sooo good. The roast pork is crispy and perfectly cooked and juicy inside, must have if you like pork! The roast duck has a unique flavor and just perfect with the white rice. No soy sauce needed! Inside is small and a hot mess but you can order rice dishes and noodles to accompany your bbq. Hey also have the pre-made food you can order at the front. If you're not buying bbq you can skip the line and walk in to sit down and eat and order takeout. Much faster then waiting in the long lines.
author: Lana N.

description:
TLDR - Delicious Chinese roast meat!!

My parents and I happened to be driving by one weekend afternoon and the massive line out the door intrigued us enough to stop and check this spot out. Normally I'm deterred by long lines for things like brunch, but we figured it must be good if so many people were lined up for Chinese takeout.

The wait was maybe 20 minutes, which wasn't too bad but definitely more than we usually wait at Ranch 99 for roast duck. IT'S WORTH IT. You can also order food to eat in the place, but I think most people just order things to-go.

We got a few things to-go, which immediately filled our car with delicious smells:

* ROAST DUCK
Delicious flavor!! And super tender, moist and juicy. A little fattier and greasier than duck my family usually gets, but soo good.

* BBQ PORK / CHAR SIU
I love BBQ pork so I was expecting to like this regardless, but their BBQ pork really impressed me. Nicely cooked (only some parts were a little dry) and packed much more flavor than BBQ pork I usually have.

* ROAST PORK
I found the pork belly to be just okay - a little dry and bland - but my parents really enjoyed it and loved the crispy skin.
author: Jessie L.

description:
When I crave Chinese BBQ, I come here. 

This place is by far the best BBQ place I've been to in sf. And it's pretty darn cheap too. Cash only, but there's an ATM at the Safeway across the street. 

Order the crispy fatty pork, it's delicious. It's something I crave often after I ordered this the first time. Juicy cuts of pork with delicious crispy skin on top. Perfectly cooked, it's never dry. 

The duck is delicious too. Succulent with a crispy fatty skin. 

It's entree dishes are pretty good too. I like that this place has dishes that remind me of things my parents make. Their fish and bitter melon stir fry is comfort to me. Simple, light and healthy.

It's definitely one of my favorite places in sf. Worth the wait in its long line.
author: Michelle C.

description: I was just in there for a quick deli-type takeaway as is described in all of the google reviews and was told I had to special order stuff off the menu, which was totally fine. What wasn't ok was being harassed by someone affiliated with the restaurant, while they all watched and talked about me in another language. Really strange. Definitely didn't say or do anything to warrant the incident. Was just passing through, but won't come here again or recommend to the locals I know.
author: Erica C.

description: When you order BBQ rice plates to go make sure you look at the worker that is chopping up your meat. I ordered BBQ pork and roast duck rice plate to go without paying attention to the preparation. When I got home my rice plate was all bones and fat. I wonder where all the meat went?. I know duck don't have much meat but seriously there was only one piece of meat and the rest was bones, fat and skin. And they gave me very little pork. There food is good but need to request what you want and pay close attention on the person that's chopping your food.
author: Tina K.

description: Likely the best bbq pork in the bay area
author: Ingrid R.

description:
If you're coming here, it better be for their BBQ. Never even had dishes from their regular menu before. I've been living in SF for almost my entire life and from childhood my parents would bring Cheung Hing bbq home for dinner, and now as an adult I'm a patron myself.

Best items are their duck, bbq pork, and siu yuk. Order by the pound, or duck by whole or half. Their duck is soo good, as long as you appreciate a fattier duck. I love duck fat, so the more the better! Don't come here if you're on a low fat diet or can't handle a bit of gristle and bones to go with your meat.
author: Melody S.

description:
++ The BBQ Pork. Great flavor, great consistency, great taste. Currently the golden standard I compare all other BBQ pork I encounter with. I always ask for pieces that are fatter- because I like flavor.
+ The roast duck. Classic taste. 

= Soy sauce chicken. Good flavor (not outstanding), good consistency (not too dry), good consistency (slightly too salty).
= Roast pork. Great flavor, good consistency, too salty for my taste.
= They tend to cut on the heavy side- You ask for 0.5 lbs, they try to sell 0.7lb.
= Decent price for all of their selections. 
= They will sell out of certain meats near the end of the day.

- Not good for sit-down eating. 

Bottom line:
If my friends ask for the best BBQ pork place, I point them here. I wouldn't suggest them to get anything other than meat here. There are better places in SF for everything else.
author: Arthur S.

description: A bit overrated now. The BBQ pork on my rice plate came out cold when i got in my car and alot of places have them hot or at least microwaved beforehand. Having the pork hot makes sure the juices from the pork drips onto the rice, but my pork was cold. Also, they charge you for ginger sause which other restaurants give out for free!
author: Jerry M.

description: Sometimes the line is so long but well worth the wait. I love the roast duck and roast crispy pork that stays deliciously moist.  It's interesting to watch the folks in line watching the the guy doing the chopping :-) Great food for the right price.
author: Bombo V.

description: The meat is so good. Service is not too bad either. Unlike what others have said, I would say the service is better than your average Chinese place mainly because they'll communicate and respond to you and have a reasonable understanding of English. Other than that, yes the place is crowded cause it's fantastically delicious.
author: David C.

description: Been going here for years just for the bbq to go. The char siu and siew yook and roast duck are probably the best in the city. There usually is a line here and service can be hit or miss.
author: Dan C.

description: Ignore the health rating. This place, oh man, full duck + pork ribs + tofu was simply amazing. If you want to eat duck with your family without paying restaurant duck prices, come here.
author: Sean H.

description:
My peoples know how to proudly display animal brutality in all it's delicious glory. Burnt animal bodies on hooks - could be a scene out of Hostel. Veggie heads run away before the Butcher comes for you next!

That roast or bbq pork. $8 per pound. Make sure you come by when it's fresh! You can ask for a leaner or fattier cut.

It's better than the various Sam Woos and knock offs scattered about LA & OC. Too bad I don't live in this neighborhood anymore. Wow they'll even sell a whole roast pig for your home party!
author: Jeff H.

description: The best cha siu I ever have in SF area! Their other BBQ products like roast duck also great. Since this tiny restaurant is always crowded with so many people lines up outside waiting to be seated, I always go for take out, half cha siu and half duck, make my own rice and veggie at home and enjoy tender & juicy BBQ bought from them:D
author: Bella L.

description:
2.5 stars.  Tried this place bc many people told me they have the BEST roasted duck (something I rarely buy).  Since I was visiting a friend, I dropped by to pick up a whole duck for our lunch.  BTW, buying a whole duck is cheaper than 2 halves.  There were only 3 people in the queue because I was there during a week day afternoon.

TIP:  Cash only

2 word review:  Too salty!  

Enough said.
author: Kim S.

description:
Found long black hair inside roast duck
Another fusion confusion
Where is Gordon Ramsey!!!!
author: Chef C.

description:
Their BBQ is excellent! The line is long during rush hours. If you go during off hours (3pm) it's empty and it's fast service. 
Their other meals like porridge and any non-BBQ meals aren't good so I don't recommend those. Stick with their BBQ meals. 
Don't expect courteous service here. It's the typical rude Chinese service.
author: Melissa C.

description: I called to explain my order of "roast duck wonton" seems to lacking on the "duck" part. They said if I'm not happy I can bring it back for exchange. Upon arrival they threw out the part and say here's the meat what seems to be your problem. And spoke LOUDLY THATS HOW THE ORDER ARE. I always order from them and needless to say this will be my last time and I'm more motivated than ever to stay on my diet. Where is the negative one star???
author: Mzc C.

description:
Pretty standard... Nothing too special. Yes, if you're not Chinese or Canto, the deli meats hanging in the window might be super impressive. But if you're Chinese or Canto, this is basic haha

After running around for the day, came here with the boyfriend because we were both craving duck. The line was out of the door (small store space anyway) and we just got behind everyone. Little did we know, the line is only for to-go orders. If you want to stay and eat (5 or 6 tables of four), just head straight in and grab a seat. We ordered:

roast duck with rice ($7.25 on menu) - peking duck!
roast pork with rice ($7.25 on menu) - pork belly
BBQ pork with rice ($7.25 on menu) - chasu

I would say that the meats are on the saltier side. And the menu prices weren't actually what we were charged. We got charged $8.45 for each dish but it wasn't a huge deal so we didn't fight it... Definitely will though next time. I would estimate maybe a little less than half a pound for each meat dish. If you're starving like we were, just order 3 dishes and you don't have to finish all the rice. But since the meat oils saturate the rice on the bottom, the rice becomes SUPER delicious. Pretty standard compared to a lot of deli places in other Chinatowns like Flushing and Boston.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
At 4:00 PM, I was overtaken by a sudden desire for Chinese roast pork. I thought of the crispy skin. The soft fat. The tender meat. I quickly took to Yelp to locate my closest access to pork heaven.

Sadly, it would appear you cannot find roast pork in the Lower Haight. As I continued my search, I discovered a magical place that had earned the widespread Yelp consensus that it was, in fact, the best Chinese BBQ spot in San Francisco.

And that's why I spent an hour on the MUNI today getting to and from Cheung Hing. 

Was it delicious? Hell yeah. As soon as I got out of the store, I walked to my MUNI stop and made use of my free 7 minutes to start wolfing down my generous portion of rice, BBQ pork, roast pork, and not-so-generous portion of veggie (I have no problem with this, but I probably should).

Did I get some judgmental glances? Eh. Yes.

Do I care? No.

New plan is to spend warm weekends indulging in Cheung Hing takeout at Ocean Beach. Yum.
author: Kelly R.

description: To all the customers who buy BBQ FOOD from this place CHEUNG HING(祥興), please check all your BBQ FOOD especially the roast duck. I just bought a whole roast duck from this place CHEUNG HING(祥興) at sunset 2339 NORIEGA STREET SF, CA 94122. I asked them to cut the whole roast duck in half and put them in two separate containers. They cheated me by replacing half of my whole fresh roast duck with half of an OLD roast duck. So I ended up with  a half new and half old roast duck. I asked them to split into two containers for me and got charge an extra $.50 just to split whole roast duck into two container. Charging me extra is ok. But it's another thing to cheat me by giving me half of their old roast duck. I didn't expect this is the way how CHEUNG HING(祥興) DO BUSINESS-- cheating their customers who buy  BBQ FOOD there.
author: Sue C.

description: Good char sui rice box that you can take to-go. Too much rice. They should include some veggies instead for a healthy meal.  They charge $1 extra if you want fried rice instead of white rice.  The meat was juicy and delicious. Under $10 for the rice box. I felt like I was mostly paying for the meat since rice is cheap.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Honestly, if the servers weren't so rude, this place would've gotten 5 stars.  My mom used to get the singapore fried noodles here for me once a week when I was younger and lived further away and it was delicious.  Now, I live 5 blocks away and haven't been here since then.  

I was home alone and didn't feel like cooking so I decided to come back here and try the scrambled eggs with beef over ho fun.  I regretted that decision forever.  I am now addicted to it and will forego interacting with the rude servers at the front to get this delicious container of food.  I like to add chili oil because I love spicy food, but I will be coming back multiple times for that dish.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
This place is one of my favorite hole-in-the-wall joints in San Francisco for good Chinese food. No frills and every dish is less than $10. The other day was my first time dining in this setting and it was perfect for catching up with some friends over comfort food. At first it seemed like people only do take-out here, but as time passed all the tables eventually got filled!

My mom always comes here for their roast duck and bbq pork. When I dined in last, I tried their wonton noodle soup with roast duck, and my other two friends got their rice noodle dish with egg gravy & beef and roast duck over rice. Everything is family style portions with the exception of the noodle soups (I usually don't share my noodle soup since it can get messy, but for all means go for it!). The duck here is AMAZING. It's so tender and juicy and perfect!! They tend to run out of it towards the end of the day, so get it while you can!

They offer other Chinese food dishes like fried rice, tofu, soy sauce chicken, fried noodles, all by the lb at a reasonable price! I'm definitely coming back when I'm craving a Chinese food fix.
author: Kathleen S.

description: This is simply for the jook aka congee I got couple of weeks ago when I was sick. I called in to have a duck jook to go as I was feeling super sick and thought it would make a good breakfast/lunch for work. Their jook was super watered down like it was more soup than the somewhat thick porridge texture. Unfortunately this watered down congee didn't satisfy my sick needs.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
Duck, duck, goose? At Cheung Hing, DUCK DUCK DUCK!

Probably among the most cost-effective duck, because you are neither forced to get an entire Peking duck nor restricted to fine-dining-portions of fancy duck confit. The duck rice plate at Cheung Hing is perfect in terms of taste, portion, and price to satisfy duck cravings. The place is very hole-in-the-wall, almost like street food, but to be optimistic I guess that gives a more authentic feel. Since it's gained some popularity, it's perhaps not as cheap as truely unknown hole-in-the-walls, but everything is still very reasonably priced.

When in doubt, I suggest not straying too far from the famous duck. We tried some other items and though not bad, in my opinion I've had better BBQ pork and chicken at fast food in HK:
- Chicken: It was authentic yellow-feathered chicken (yeah that's a direct translation so it sounds funny), but it was extremely scrawny 
- BBQ pork: Always a safe choice, and the server was kind enough to ask us whether we had a preference for the lean or fatty cuts. Maybe the more popular fatty option would have been better, because we got the lean one which turned out very dry and had a funny texture.
- Roast pork: Pretty good! This one is lean-option-safe and the crispy skin is magically delish, though I would have preferred more actual pork than skin.

All the rice plates come with a side of cabbage so you don't feel as guilty eating so much meat and white rice. I'm not a huge rice fan, but I must admit, the rice soaked up with the fat and flavors of the roast meat is the next best thing to the duck here P:
author: Edna C.

description:
BFF and I went here for dinner. Yelp reviews made it sound good. BFF said she always saw lines out the front. Ok - seemed like a good sign 
Most of the customers were there for takeout. We sat at one of the 4-5 tables and immediately were served water and tea. Hot tea in a plastic water glass ....???.  We chose 3 dishes from the slightly sticky plastic menus and the food was served fairly quickly. Sesame chicken - yuck - dried out breaded chunks of mystery meat. BBQ dried rice - ok. Fish with greens - good! Would have liked to had more fish in the dish though. The wait staff were nice about refilling our water glasses too (that will always earn points with me) 
My recommendation is get the food to go. Otherwise it's pretty noisy at the tables - which might be fine if you are there to catch a quick lunch, but not conducive to conversation.
Regardless the staff get high marks
And it wasn't till the next day I saw the poor health inspection report notice...oh well
author: Amy M.

description:
The line is for the take out roast duck.  
The honey sauce is extra.
Cash only transaction.
author: Drew B.

description: This is a great restaurant that doesn't really get the credit it deserves. The health rating is low, and that's really unfortunate, but the food is great, and the price extremely reasonable. For meat eaters, I would recommend the Whole Roast Duck, or Barbecue pork. For Vegetarians, I would recommend any of their tofu dishes. They're all great! For seafood eaters, their cuttlefish is delicious. For good value, buy the seafood or meat by whole, and not over rice. Overall, this place is good for anyone wanting to enjoy great Chinese barbecue and traditional dishes.
author: Justin C.

description:
We have all heard the story of The Ugly Duckling. It's a story of a young ugly duckling who was constantly bullied by her friends because of her appearance. But as we know, the duckling eventually blossomed into a beautiful Swan, admired and revered by all.

But you never heard the epilogue.

With beauty, fame, and power by her side, the Swan vengefully sought for all the ducks who had bullied her. Swan roasted each duck until their skin were crisp to the touch, and then she would send them off into a place known as Cheung Hing. To this day, it is said that one could walk by Noriega and 30th and still smell the roasted skin of the duck bullies....

As a Yelper investigator, I had to check out the legendary Cheung Hing myself. True to the tales, the aroma of roasted duck found me almost a block away. Mesmerized, I followed my nose all the way inside Cheung Hing. 

As I was ordering my plate of Roast Duck Over Rice, I saw Natalie Portman sitting with a plate of her own on the side table. I am a big Star Wars fan, so I was very excited to see Padme in the actual flesh. I handed the cashier my $7.50 and immediately sat across from Padme at the greasy table. 

"Wow Padme, it's so great to finally meet you! You know, Anakin actually turned out okay in the end, and Luke and Leia are doing great. Hey what are you doing here anyway?"

"The same reason why you are here." She pointed to her plate of Roast Duck Over Rice.

In my rush to meet Padme, I had forgotten to admire the beauty of my plate. The glaze of the crispy skin reflected the bright lights of Cheung Hing. The oils and fat, full of flavor, were leaking from the duck and into the crevices between each grain of soft and fluffy rice. It looked spectacular, and smelled even better. 

It must have tasted even better than that because Padme was attacking her plate with ferocity. She licked the juice off her fingers after sinking her teeth into the tender meats from the duck leg. The duck was delicious, yes. But it was still very uncharacteristic of her to savagely devour the duck in that violent manner. 

"Hey Padme, maybe you should slow down. I know it's delicious and all, but you're still a Hollywood actress and there are paparazzi everywhere."

With half of her face still buried in the plate, her eyes rose to stare into my own. Her eyes were beginning to turn red, and her pupils dilated into utter blackness.

"You keep calling me Padme..." she hissed.

"I...I'm sorry, would...would you prefer Qu-Queen Amidala?"

"Can't you see...?"

She stood. Black feathers sprouted from her sides. She fluttered her arms fluidly and cocked her head. Her black pupils fixed onto me without expression.

"I am the Black Swan."
author: Ringo M.

description: I ordered whole baby pig at this store $218 for my son birthday but see what I got . I said no cut but they cut it and they said have to eat right after get home if don't eat 2 hours the meat will turn dry and black . They offer pay me back $20 dollars after I was complain. It's hurt
author: Mai L.

description:
YOU MUST CHECK THIS SPOT OUT. I am not exaggerating at all. Their food here is the best Chinese food I have ever had in my life. I have lived in SF around the Richmond District and Sunset neighborhoods all my life and this place exceeds any of the Chinese restaurants I've been too. Even San Tung! I mean this is a hole in the wall type of place, but their food is delicious. My friends parents introduced this spot to me after buying us take out from here. And I knew I had to come here for myself. 

I usually order the roasted pork or duck over rice. My mouth is watering just thinking about the food. You gotta try the food here!
author: Dara S.

description: The line out the door explains it all. The duck and roast pork are juicy while the skin is crispy. The cuttlefish is crunchy and so flavorful. There is a good selection of other dishes as well including eggplant, fried tofu stuffed with beef, Mochi, and sticky rice.
author: C C.

description:
I tried several visits to order different items, giving a fair review. Even sat down with family, had a dinner menu of fried rice, tomato beef chow mein, & a tofu dish. Sorry it was just okay- great for single men/women for quick bite. I've taken out roast duck, roast pork, soy sauce chicken & pigs feet. One common denominator - fat & grease on every item. Crispy pork skin & everything very tasty, but I couldn't justify/handle the fat. Maybe twice a year to satisfy my craving for Chinese BBQ & roasted take-outs. Positive - all servers very accommodating, nice, & will speak English.

Had to change review from 3 stars to 1 star. See my image posted today on the Chinese jhoan (Chinese tamale), mainly fat no meat charged $2.85, again fatty & greasy. Had enough of same theme.
author: Yvonne M.

description: This place is overrated. The BBQ pork was very dry and over cook, duck and cold chicken was good. The food was average nothing special.
author: Kay D.

description: Duck is excellent. It is a small hole in the wall with mostly take out. Cash only and has a line most of the time
author: Mason L.

description:
The line here is as famous as the food itself. During peak hours, there's always a line of hungry Chinese people going out the door, but it tends to move at a decent pace. People inside are all yelling out their orders, and the butchers somehow collect everything and channel it into boxes full of roasted goodies. For how disorganized it is, there's some sort of chaotic efficiency. Just know what you want before you reach the counter, and don't be shy. It also helps to speak loud Cantonese. However, all of this is pretty easily avoidable if you pick up food during off peak hours.

As for the food, you can't go wrong with their venerated roast duck. Rich, savory, fatty, juicy, it hits all the right notes. The spices and seasonings they use give it a really bold flavor. The skin could be crispier, but it's still really good. The leftover salty and fatty juices can be used like bacon grease. It makes anything taste great. On rice, noodles, bread, eggs, vegetables, or other meat, it's all good. Lips feeling chapped? Lather them in delicious leftover duck fat. Ming Kee is also one of our favorite places for take out roast duck, but it's been a little inconsistent since they moved back to Ocean.

I also like the Cha Siu (BBQ Pork) here. It's tender, juicy, and sweet. In addition to the glimmering sweet glaze, the burnt edges also add a lot of flavor and texture. Ordering half lean half fat doesn't seem to change the composition of the pieces much, but it's all still tasty.
author: Nei N.

description: Thee to to spot in SF for bbq'd Chinese meats. Id vouch and say it's the best in the bay area
author: Mista N.

description:
It was 5pm and there was a line out the door for the meat per lb. That's really more like 10 people in front of me, but that's 80% chinese speakers. If majority of the patrons are natives waiting in the windy cold weather with their kids yelling for them in the car, it should be legit right?
After the slightly confusing order (quarter of a pound of bbq pork pls...no not half a pound...less than half, yeah sure that's fine), I took one step to the left to speak with a lady who took my order for hot foods. Got half an order of steamed tofu, fried tofu in some pork sauce (sorry I'm not chinese, I just saw and pointed), and sticky fried rice with Chinese sausage (according to a helpful lady trying to fix my puzzled face).
The total was $19.50. They charged for a plastic bag, hot sauce packets, and to go boxes. But there was enough for 2.5 meals. 
I took everything to go as the place was crowded and that just seemed like the right thing to do. 
The food was ok. The steamed tofu had some kind of mixed meat overpowered by chives with a sauce that looked liked watered down soy sauce. The fried tofu was pretty good and it had pieces of pork in it so I didn't feel completely like a vegetarian. The pork was soggy, but added flavor to the dish. Sticky rice was really good, not too salty and had a good chewy texture. Finally the reason for the line - bbq pork. It was...ok. I had it, I can cross it off my list, I can move on. If you closed your eyes and couldn't smell, you can definitely taste that it was pork. It was chewy, a bit tender, not too salty, and the outside bbq sauce was what made it good. I wish it had more of the glaze. 
I don't think I'd go back on line, but if I was craving chinese and no one was there I'd give it another go.
author: Jenny P.

description: We came here at 2pm on a Saturday and it was pretty easy to get a seat for 3. The food also arrived quite fast. The famed roasted duck here is 5 stars and a must-order. Very flavourful skin, tender meat and not overly fatty. Soy sauce chicken noodles was ok. I knocked off a star as the sweet/sour pork legs dish was only fatty skin and thick bone without any meat. It had looked like tender soy sauce pork legs but turned out too cloyingly sweet and tough. Seems like a lot of people order for take-out. I will be back for the roast duck alone.
author: Lindt C.

description:
Ok, DON'T come here when the bald headed chef if working. (Other guy is great) but when you let other people cut in line and take their order, it's BS. On top of that he tries to short me on my order. I've come here multiple times to know what a full order of roast pork consist of. I made sure the girl who cut me line won't be doing that again. Two stars cause the food is good regardless of their crappy service today.

Update: yeah, my stance hasn't changed. Stay away when bald headed chef is working. He'll try and give you left over scrap pieces on your order.
author: Brian L.

description:
People know what's up! The Peking duck is incredible. I ordered the half of one to go, and then waited for noodles, clams, green beans. Everything was delicious! Incredible well spiced. The service was refreshingly fast, and spoke English. I feel great 2 hours after eating! 

Going to always get take out here and looking forward to learning what's good on the menu.

In the name of five spice, I pray! Amen.
author: Priya S.

description:
My brother raved about this place for months and finally dragged us all out there this weekend to try it out. This place encapsulates everything you would imagine when talking about a hole in the wall chinese meat shop. It's dirty, loud, greasy and the (great) smell permeates the air both inside and outside.

We ordered a number of items but the ones that stood out were the roast duck, the roast pork and the char siu riblets. Each and every one of these items were pretty close to the best I've ever had. And that is saying something considering the great chinese meat shops we have in my home town of Honolulu. Perfectly salty, fatty and moist the meat is accompanied by the most flavorful and crispy skin. 

Unfortunately the char siu itself is not the best there is but hey, you can't have everything in one shop right? 

Overall, for some chinese meats, this place is simply "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Giving 2 stars because the food is not horrible but the service is. Staff is so rude! And the place is somewhat unsanitary!
author: Vinnesa G.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here after school after searching on yelp. We came here around 730pm and there was a lot of parking space. So we are able to find a parking spot right in front of the store. 
When we got into the restaurant, the place was pretty small. There was only maybe 5-6 table max. This place is mostly for ordering to go. Since we got here late, there was a table for us to sit down. 

We ordered egg gravy beef over rice and beef chow fun. The wait for the food  didn't take long and the food was hot and steamy. Both of our food was delicious. We had tried these dishes at many other restaurants and this one tasted the best. 

My boyfriend and I will definitely come back and try their hot deli. We most likely not going to dine in but will surely buy food from here to go! 

Ps.  We also tried their mochi but it did not taste as good as we thought. Next time, we will just stick to the hot deli and their asian dishes.
author: Noel K.

description: I can see this easily becoming my favorite Chinese roast meats place in SF. Their portions run large. Their staff seem happy at work. Their food is tasty without that weird after-taste that some of the other Chinese take-out places around there have.
author: Yad L.

description:
We are so glad that daughter introduced us to this place; before our two recent visits to see grandma, we stopped for some take outs, grandma was happier with the food then anything I spent hours to make. 

Yes, there is always a line, the place is small, not the cleanest, no ambiance what so ever and they handle your orders like an assembly line. If you can see beyond that, the food is fresh, tasty and very reasonably priced.

We've tried so far the roast chicken, bbq pork, roast pork, soy chicken (need to try roast duck next) from the bbq counter; and sticky rice, stuffed tofu, vinegar pig feet from the steam table. The roast pork was the clear winner, all the other bbq items were good as well. I like the fact that they have the options of free range chicken and regular chicken because our 92 year old grandma can't handle the tougher meat of the 'yellow feather chicken'. 

We'll be back.
author: Julie W.

description:
This is my go to take out Chinese joint. My kids love beef with scrambled eggs over rice and they make it just right here. They don't skimp on the beef and do not over season the dish. The beef chow fun container is always filled to the top and not overly greasy.

There's always a line for their BBQ items (their BBQ is awarding winning) but if you order off the menu walk pass the line and get someone's attention. If you order over the phone (which I did) they make the food extremely fast! I ordered three items and it only took 10 mins. The BBQ is good but I only eat that occasionally. Roast duck here is also good but way to fatty for my taste.

3 dishes = $22.50
author: Liz N.

description:
The best roast duck in the bar area bar none!  I've been to their other locations but they're simply not as good or flavorful as this location.  The duck meat and skin is so juicy and flavorful that it gives you good memories instantly!  The cabbage that comes with it is also good and I normally tend to not eat too many vegetables...The rice could be a bit much but ask for extra duck sauce to make it less dry and have more flavor!

Parking could vary depending on how lucky you get a space on Noriega st.  It's quite busy around this section since there's many Chinese shops and restaurants, and Safeway around there too.  The line can get out the door so it's best to be patient, they get to you eventually as they're fast at taking care of people in line.  It's small inside the restaurant so it's usually best to take it to go.
author: Eric T.

description: TERRIBLE! Got the roast pork and roast chicken over rice. They gave me all end pieces of the roasted pork, no crispy skin, just scraps I wouldn't even feed to my dog. Watch what they put in your box if you order a rice plate or any of the BBQ items, they will try to cheat you!
author: Fantastique J.

description:
Gotta hand it to them...The Chinese are an interesting bunch. 

The first thing I notice when I walk in is a cook swiftly hacking a duck's head off and another preparing bean sprouts in the corner. Ah, familiarity. 

The order-to-go line is pretty long and full of patient aZn parents who probably don't want to cook after a long day at work. This is a strong indicator that this place MUST be good if the aZn parents are willing to feed it to their offspring.

The rest of us Americanized Asians awkwardly sit at the table trying to eat and converse while the kitchen staff is screaming Cantonese words to one another, but it is all part of the experience, folks. 

This is a very authentic Chinese restaurant. This ain't no Panda Express bullshit restaurant. This is the real deal. 

Things you should try: 
duck of course -- people have raved about it 
old ass egg in rice porridge 
Beef with bean sprouts my fav 

I understand that Chinese people don't care about ambiance or environment. They care about quality of food and practicality. However, I docked off one star because of the cleanliness. 

Nevertheless, it is a great place to try if you are looking for something new to eat!!
author: Emily F.

description:
Roast duck & rice MMMMMM.

Recently decided to come with my sister after years of not having it and best. decision. ever.

It's a very small place inside, people usually do take out but we were too hungry to wait so we just sat down! They probably fit about 10-15 people in there (very cramped), but the duck is worth it. 

The plate comes with a side of cabbage and it is perfect. if you're ever craving some peking duck - come here!

Beware: the line gets super long during rush hours so come when they first open to avoid!
author: Carrie L.

description: Wow! 4 stars based on 484 reviews! Well deserved for previous crew. Current regime? I'd be skeptical. On Tuesday, I ordered a whole roast duck, an order of more than 1.5 lbs BBQ pork and two dishes to go or "take away." At home, I found one and a half duck heads, and a less than normal number of pieces of duck breasts and thighs. It is a good thing that I always request the 2 duck drumsticks to remain whole. However, I believe that I'm financing the establishment to keep their dine-in customers happy. If they have a profit sharing plan, I'd be the first in line.
author: Alan W.

description:
I had this place booked marked and finally came. 

The roast duck and roast pork are definitely a hit here! Skin is nice and crispy and flavorful. The long line in front proves how good the food is here. Big portions good food for a cheap price!

This place is known for take out, but if you want to avoid the line sit in and order. The waitresses are quick and nice. 

I'll be back here again!
author: J B.

description: This place is cheating.  I order two lbs of roasted pork.   When I got home the pork  is all bone and no skin.   It is not the piece I picked.    WTF.
author: Ed Y.

description:
I recall coming here when I lived in the Sunset, and everytime I walk or drive by, I can smell the tempting aroma of their BBQ pork & roast duck. There was always a line out the door during meal times. Since the place is tiny, having a line form wasn't hard to achieve. It only takes 3 or 4 customers to look busy.

So on my trip back to SF for business, I am again staying in the Sunset. Trying to capture some memories, I dropped by Cheng Hing to grab a quick bite. Inside, there's a counter with pre-cooked dishes, from diced chicken with peppers, to fish, fried tofu...etc. Hanging by the window in true Cantonese fashion are whole golden, glistening roasted ducks and slabe of BBQ pork. There are also a few tables for customers who don't mind eating next to a line of shouting customers ordering take-out. 

As I recalled (and read on Yelp) they are known for their duck, and I had to have it again. I also chose a 2nd item, fish filet in black bean sauce over rice. I was never a fan of Cantonese BBQ pork (char siu) so I passed as much as they tried to convince me how good it is. 

The two items rest on a pile of rice with a few pieces of cabbage, which I suspect was to fill the box and make it appear fuller than it really is. The fish in b.b. sauce was decent. It's salty, tender (as fish should be) but lacked anything exciting. It's a "filler" The duck pieces were extremely fatty. I'd say 50% of the pieces they threw into the box was not edible, unless you actually enjoy chunks of oily, fatty, greasy duck lard covered by an equally fatty skin. The pieces that actually had meat was good, but the flavor was often covered by the taste of grease. 

After eating half of the order, I began to feel.... not right. That was my cue to stop. Perhaps it was the heavy amount of grease that stealthily leaked into the rice but I felt weighed down and had an urge to drink hot tea to rinse out the grease from my intestines. 

Thinking back, the duck I ordered years ago were much leaner and didn't make me feel sick in my stomach (sorry belly, I'll make it up to you with some 'good' food) Now that I relived my memories, I no longer want to go back. 

For 2 items and a plastic bag (I assume they charged me for the bag, since they spilled sauce on the box and I really didn't want duck grease on my leather seats) it was $8.60. Hardly a bargain, and definitely not worth the price. I now have the urge to detox. 

As for the people lining up, perhaps the Cantonese elders have grown immune to this level of cardiac causing oil. Not me. I can find many other tastier ways to clog my arteries.
author: James L.

description:
Food was brought out cold & was very average. I got the duck (very oily), banana leaf wrapped rice (cold & inedible), and rice porridge (the only warm thing that was brought to us). 
It could have been an off day because it was near closing time, but I will never be eating here again.
The plus side was that it was cheap & fast. Cash only
author: Ian O.

description:
For friendliness and customer service a four star would be more appropriate.

That being said, the two stars is because we ordered chicken Chow mein and honey walnut prawns and while it was served within 5-10 minutes, after a few bites it became evident that the chicken was RAW! Just cooked enough to look cooked but it was so pink that it looked like we had just bought chicken to take home and make ourselves. 

We were so shocked that we hadn't even thought to take a picture and just immediately alerted the staff and they quickly took actions and replaced the plate with beef chow instead. Unfortunately, the beef was so chewy we couldn't even finish all the pieces. 

While we aren't picky in our food, we do value fully cooked meat and proper food health codes. 

I don't think it helped that the employees were really concerned with cleaning than anything else. 

So 2 stars for lack of food health standards being met, 4 stars for friendliness and quickness.
author: Auxiliadora T.

description:
Okay, as everyone saying this is mostly take out place. But I needed a lunch atm, and I usually would look for 4.5 or 5 stars in the area, but there were nothing above 4.
This was one of these 4 star places.

I hesitated a bit, but decided it maybe not that bad.

I ordered curry chicken on rice.
Well, I did not finish my plate.  
Everything was good, except chicken.
There were sinew's and fat served in plate. To me it's not acceptable, but I can see how this place could be good for someone who likes fat and sinew's, because, well if you like THAT in your food, then you would like this place.
author: Artem M.

description:
I strongly believe there should be a lot of hidden gems Chinese restaurants in SF besides the Chinatown area. So did a lil bit research on Yelp, and found Cheung Hing - did not disappoint me a single bit.

It's a tiny restaurant barely fits 5 tables. It's not the cleanest place to dine in to be honest, and the staff were speaking quite loud. But the food I got, whoa, was extremely authentic.

I ordered a roasted pork + roasted duck rice plate:

-) Roasted Duck: A. They didn't give me the sour plum sauce which I was gonna ask for one, but decided to give it a try first. Yup, I don't need it - the sauce that they used was locked not only between the skin and the meat but inside the meat as well. It smelled good and was very tasty.

-) Roasted Pork: A-. I have never liked roasted pork to begin with so I'm probably a bit biased, but unlike a lot of roasted pork I tried which was dry and hard, they've got soft and a bit moist texture! The fat portion didn't feel like fat but just soft meat. I changed my perception about roasted pork after this experience.

-) Vegetable: A-. Yes the vege deserves a separate paragraph to be talked about. I guess they stir fried it with garlic pretty well that it provided sort of a balance to the two roasted meat I was eating, a good supplement for my taste bud.

-) Rice: B+. Not the best rice I've eaten but they put quite a lot of sauce on it that enriched my whole eating experience.

Price was $9.20 after tax. This place is actually even better than a lot of roasted meat restaurants I tried in Asia. I really want to try other dishes Cheung Hing has got but I live far away, I bet next time I will come back and still get the same dish again - it's so memorable!
author: Simon C.

description: Buyer beware  - visited this BBQ pork, roast duck place because of good reviews on Yelp.  Bought a  roast duck.  The guy cut up the duck with his back facing me.  When arrived home, my daughter opened the box and said, "how come these are all pieces of bones, you have been cheated".  We immediately checked it out - other than two lower leg parts,  the rest of the legs, thighs and breast parts are all missing - replaced pretty much by all bony pieces. Very different from what we usually have. We also bought BBQ pork,  roast pig and duck etc. costing closed to $60.  I am sure the guy realized we were out of towners .
