He dare not cheat on the locals.  This place has a few tables lined up against the wall for eat-in customers.  Go figure !!! Will certainly not go back to this dishonest merchant!!!
author: Raymond Y.

description: LOVE this place! The chinese bbq is amazing and the other items you can order are just as good. I first learned of this place in Millbrae...my only gripe about this location is that it's cash only - Millbrae accepts cards for purchases (I think) over $20..this is just part of city living. Whenever I have cash I am happy to come here - I just unfortunately rarely have cash on me!
author: Joanna L.

description: I bought BBQ pork with rice and it was ok. It was cold and not that great. Service was horrible!! It took about 15 mins just to get the bill and after we paid already, the lady chased after us saying that we needed to pay them a "service fee" after the total amount. Came here for the high reviews and left disappointed. I will not return.
author: Jay T.

description:
Cheung Hing : the place well known for their roast ducks, roast pork  and savory BBQ pork.  Well folks, those deliciously delightful dishes are all but a faded memory.   I believe C/H is under new ownership and staff other than the fatty who chops up the stuff at the front.   I hope the previous owner's got paid for the amount of goodwill that business location.  The Pa pah duck they sold us today will be the last duck or anything else my family and I will ever savor from this establishment.   For $18 bucks, we got Pa pah duck fat.  Too bad for the Cheung Hing name.  

Do not recommend this business and most definitely we will not return.
author: K H.

description: The Duck and Mongolian beef or chicken is THE BEST! Depending on what time you go be prepared for a line. It's because it's that good! Cash only too. My boyfriend and I have been going for soooo many years and never have been disappointed!
author: Monica L.

description: Great great Chinese barbecue. Very traditional cooked. If you want to try the REAL cantonese food, not the awful american chinese things, this is definitely the right place! By the way, the ducks there are with perfect proportion of meat, fat, and skin, if you only like the meat and feel bad about eating fat and skin, try some pork or chicken, and please please keep away from ducks and leave them to others! Because their ducks always sold out sooo soon!
author: Jady X.

description: Came here on a Saturday afternoon at 4 and there was a line out the door for takeout. I had the duck and it was great. I also got some BBQ pork which was a little on the sweet side for me.
author: Jack Y.

description:
Let's call this simply a review of food. Because ITS SO GOOD! My boyfriend and I picked up 1/2 a duck, 1/2 lb BBQ Pork, 1/2 lb roasted pork, and a large container of  green beans. Green beans were super tasty! Beware, there's some meat in it if you think its vegetarian friendly. The BBQ PORk was by far my favorite. 2nd green beans, 3rd the duck, and 4th would be the roasted pork. large portions are more worth it than the smaller ones in terms of cost so, just have some leftovers. :) CASH ONLY 

BBQ pork so tasty. I'm eating it over and over again in my head xD you can eat in if you so choose to. They have about 4-6 tables. It's more of a to go place than a sit down as the occupancy is very limited. You will see all the lovely roasted and BBQ meat through the window. There are some other options available like pigs feet, salted fish, chicken, etc. Go and enjoy. It's some legit Asian food :)
author: Michelle Y.

description:
If you don't speak Chinese, you will probably get smaller portions for take-out. For $15, I got 10 very small chicken wings and half a box of green beans. 
Food is good but lines are not.
author: Kay L.

description: Poor service and unwilling to make substitutions even if you are willing to pay extra. Food came out cold and dirty, not worth eating your money.
author: Kurt S.

description: Came from Los Angeles, and this is the best bbq shop i have ever eat, the wonton soup so fresh, fried rice is so yummy
author: Tom D.

description: I love this place since I was a kid their barbecue pork, roast pork& duck are all on point. Best Asian BBQ hands down. Five star for the food I would give three stars to the staff because they're pretty friendly and nice considering standing there for our is cutting up people's meat. I would give zero star for the decor and the cleanliness of the place that is why I always get it to go and never eat in side if my life depended on it. I know we're considering if the place is dirty the kitchen must be dirty. But their barbecue is just off the chain.
author: Michele T.

description: There a reason why this place has a line outside in the middle of the day.  I ordered the duck and pork. I loved the duck. The pork was a little to sweet for my taste. Personal preference.
author: Jack Y.

description: I came here on a weekend with some friends after visiting the San Francisco Botanical Garden for dinner, and it was quite tasty. The line for take-out was out the door upon our arrival! There are only four tables inside, and at the time we arrived, none were taken. I ordered a BBQ pork with flat rice noodles and I asked for lean meat; it was quite tasty. I think the BBQ pork itself could have had more flavor, but I think the sauce they poured onto it all went into the soup which was flavorful that way. Yum! My friends ordered roast duck and BBQ pork, and they enjoyed their meals as well. I think for BBQ meats, this place is quite cheap. I love Cantonese food!
author: Andrea W.

description:
The food here is good but this one skinny lady (around 30-40 yrs old) is really rude! She will give customers attitude for small things like changing an item on the order a minute after. Her face always looks bitter and she just wants customers to get their food and gtfo. That's why I always get food to go and not eat there. I would avoid talking to her. She is those typical cranky Asian servers that hates on customers. 

Good thing the store still has a young girl there that knows English and is very nice and polite. If all their staffs are sourpuss like that lady, even if they have good food, people will hesitate to go back since there are couple other Chinese bbq places that are also good.
author: Momo C.

description:
Oh man this place is legit. It's $7.50 a lb for BBQ pork, roast pork, and under $20 for a duck. 

So of course get a couple lbs each with some nou mi fan and go home and chow down. 

I sat there and started with the juicy, roasted chunks of pork and that beautiful crackling while Netflixing my evening away, and before I knew it found that I was just picking out the crackling and eating delicious, delicious pig skin. Not wanting to use up all the good stuff, I moved on to the BBQ pork and roast duck before being struck by my own brilliance. 

Which happens often. 

I took that heavenly roasted duck juice, slightly sweet and fatty and savory, and poured it all over the chunks of roasted pork. I don't remember much of what happened next. But after all was said and done and chopsticks strewn about...I remember defiantly thinking that this meal should end with ice cream.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Take-out restaurant,  and BBQ is featured. 
Don't dine in,  and don't order other non-BBQ dishes
author: Bessie Y.

description:
This place always has a line outside, 24/7.

Need I explain more?

The roast duck is really, really juicy. And by really juicy, I mean crazy juicy.

Folks. You know the drill. The place is for takeout! Would not recommend sitting in. But damn, is the takeout awesome. One of the best  (if not the best) places for BBQ meat in SF
author: Henry L.

description: Really good, cheap chinese bbq! The soy sauce chicken is good and the bbq pork is ever better. Plenty of street parking, right across from safeway. Its cash only! If you forget there is a Wells Fargo a block down and there is an atm at the safeway across.
author: Larissa L.

description:
Pro tip: this place is cash only. 


I just came in for some vegetable chow mien. Never been here before. The girl that greeted me and took my order was friendly and the portion they gave me was big. The only thing I didn't like (besides having to go to the Bank of America next door for cash and pay a $3 ATM fee) was that they charged me more than the menu online said. By I guess $7.85 isn't all that bad for dinner. I'd eat here again.
author: Nick M.

description:
Authentic HK-style restaurant with efficient service and friendly staffs. I'm from Brunei and has consumed tons of good Asian quality roasted duck, roasted char siew in Asia and I can honestly say this is one of the best I've tried. The food is of top quality tenderness and its crispy duck skin just topped it off. Overall extremely satisfied with this restaurant. 

Our order ($46):
Roasted duck with rice
Roasted chicken and char siew with rice
Long bean
Eggplant
Wa tan ho
Wan tan meen
author: Vun Hui H.

description: I swear they put crack in their roasted pork or char siu cause you can't just have a small amount. I go out of my way from the east bay just to get it and although there's always a line out the door, it's well worth the wait.
author: Brian R.

description:
There is a constant line out the door for this place.  They have a very efficient ordering process, so even if you're in line out the door, past the storefront, it should only take you 10 minutes to get to the front of the line.

Get the roast duck. That's what everyone is in line for!
author: Jaching H.

description:
The roasted duck here is so good! I normally get the roasted duck wonton soup and every time I leave satisfied. I think they make / cook the wonton fresh because every time I order it they tell me it'll take an extra 10 mins or so. 

The line you see going out the door is usually for takeout. You can go inside and usually get seated instantly, though, there aren't that many seats inside. They give the complimentary hot tea when you sit there. 

Overall, this is a great roasted duck Chinese shop ran by a super friendly family (well, they seem like a family).
author: Paul U.

description:
Everything so good! My family and I have been coming here for many years and are never disappointed with the meats. From bbq pork to roast duck, everything tasted great. 
The only thing about this place is that if you decide to dine in. Things may be and feel a little dirty.

Overall will definitely recommend!
author: Arda S.

description:
FINALLY tried Cheung Hing last month, after having it fester in my bookmarks for years! While the three of us considered getting some side (non-meat) dishes, well, it seemed silly, so we just went with entree sizes of their:

* Soy Sauce Chicken - Good flavor and tenderness overall, but came in on the dry side (as most white meat does).

* BBQ Pork - I was expecting to like this a lot more than I actually did, but it didn't taste like the chashu that I'm used to getting at dim sum, or in pastries. A bit less sweet, and a bit more medicinal. Probably would not get this the next time around.

* Roast Duck - Definitely the star of the three, with great flavor, and deliciously wonderful duck skin.

While there were some misses, the roast duck alone is worth coming back for, especially at these prices!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Seating is pretty limited, but most people seem to show up to get orders to go. Show up after 7pm and you should have missed the bulk of the dinner rush, leaving you with a small selection of accessible tables. If you come during the rush, well, good luck.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description: Came with high expectation but was disappointed. While their BBQ pork was good, their roast pork skin was crunchy but the pork itself was bland & disappointing. The roast duck looked really good but tastewise was meh & way too oily. I had better & more fragrant roast duck elsewhere. Their congee/porridge was also bland, but texture & consistency was good. Why 3 star? The lady was friendly & service was fast.
author: Angela L.

description: Had a craving for roast duck and decided to order ahead of time to beat the line. Requested them to have the duck to be cut. Upon getting home notice that the choice pieces (breast) where missing and all that was in the box where the scraps. So learn my lesson to order the duck in person and watch the carver place all the pieces in the box.
author: Phillip F.

description: Hooooo boy mama AINT MAD at these boys. I like to pick up the $16.95 juicy af whole roast duck on the way to a friend's house to nibble on with some Hennessy. That's how you win someone over. It's a lil sweet and a lil five-spicey and a whole lotta gooey fat so if you're fat-phobic, then don't be. After all the meat is eaten, I'll keep the fatty globs for cooking - throw some in the pan, let the fat render, scoop out the rest, then cook your eggs, kale, potatoes, whatever. VERY YUM. The staff speak English. & watch out for meat juice splattering in your face when they chop it up.
author: Lovebird ..

description: Today went to Cheung Hing order Togo beef chow fun around 2pm because I was so hungry. But Very disappointed, i open the box I can smell the NOT fresh meat weird smell from the beef. ...  when I bit on it it taste nasty, gross. And the chow fun don't look good too..so I throw the order away after two bit. JUNK! How can give this out to customer? Sigh
author: M Y.

description:
As a sunset native, I need to always return to my roots. My family frequents here since they've been opened. Hole in the wall.

Just a heads up, if you get squeamish, don't go inside. It's pretty unappealing but they really do have the best bbq meats! Get the bbq pork or roast duck! You can order by quarter pound, half pound, whole pound. They speak mandarin/cantonese, very limited english.

Prices are fare:) HINT: when ordering the meats, ask for a side of sauce/drippings! It's pretty much the au jus. If you order rice plates, they drizzle it on the rice with a side of steamed veggies. I prefer an extra side of the drippings to dip on the side. 

Again, don't say I did not warn you about going inside. It's definitely not the cleanest.. but its the most comforting and delicious chinese meats you will find in the city. There is always a line but trust me, it moves quick. There are sides/rice dishes as well. You can order take out or dine in. 

Cash only.
author: Wendy X.

description:
First thing to note is that the prices listed on yelp are totally off. Everything was listed around $5 but when I went to pick it up it was $7 per item. Also, on the yelp menu they advertised a roast duck entree, a half and a whole duck. They only sell half and whole, so I didn't get it. 

We got sesame chicken, chicken chow mein, and hot and sour soup. The chow mein was pretty good, had large chunks of chicken, but would have liked to see more sprouts and other veggies. The sesame chicken was not how I'm used to, it did not have a sause on it. It was still pretty good though. I did not like the hot and sour soup; it was too thick and the flavor was strange. 

Overall its not a bad place, much better than some of the other places nearby.
author: Cooper M.

description: Usually cha siu in the states is lean and nothing compared to HK but Cheung Hing had some good fatty pieces this time.  Even the chicken breast was juicy.  Best experience so far at Cheung Hing.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Arrived around 11 AM so there were no crowds yet.

Soy Sauce Chicken: Was cold and I always eat meat hot or at least warm.  The taste was of chicken and did not have any distinctive Chinese restaurant taste to it. Could have bought a similar chicken across the street at Safeway and it would have been warm.

Roast Pork Over Rice: Yes there was a generous amount of roast pork and the size of the dish or order was large. The roast port was about three times saltier than it should have been and the skin had been cooked too long and was kind of tough. Was not happy with this order.

Won Ton Noodle Soup: Won tons were all right but the soup was too watery. Quite bland and not special at all. 

Steak Fried Rice (to go): Took home some steak fried rice. It was all right, no problems with that.

We were given one napkin each for our meal Good thing I had other napkins with me. 

Had a glass of water with my meal. It was room temperature as they did not have any ice.

Bathroom seemed to be clean enough.

Prices were reasonable.

With so many good Chinese restaurants in town, will not have a desire to return to this one.
author: Steven G.

description: Great food, roasted duck was just perfect and now is my favorite. The place to dine is not very good, it is better to take away. Cheap and good food.
author: Alli N.

description: I'm not sure why i never thought about writing a review about this place. Maybe because i feel it should be known fact that this is one of the best places to grab Chinese BBQ.   I've been coming here since i was a kid and there is always a line.  However, if you want to order the rice or noodle dishes to go you can cut the line and go straight to the front to place your order.   I love their duck and bbq pork here.  It's always so tender and juicy.  For the togo orders I always get the Singapore noodles, mince beef over rice and their egg over chicken noodles (ho fun).  You can also call in advance to place your order, but if you want their bbq items, be ready to wait at least 15 to 20 mins in line.  However during chinese new year the line wraps around the corner. Good luck!
author: Belinda C.

description:
Are you looking for some of the tastiest Chinese barbecue meats in San Francisco? This place is a pretty good choice. 

Cheung Hing is the Cantonese Chinese pronunciation of 祥興. I have no idea what it really means, but 祥 itself supposedly means "auspicious" or "lucky" and 興 itself supposedly means "prosper", "rise", or "become popular". Well, I was lucky enough to get some of the best Chinese barbecue in San Francisco and this place looks really popular. 

This is probably one of my relatives' favorite place for Chinese barbecue in San Francisco. I stood in a somewhat long queue with my relatives, and the queue consisted of mostly elderly Chinese people that spoke either Cantonese Chinese or Toisan Chinese (台山話). When you see a queue of elderly Chinese people, it's possibly a good sign that the Chinese barbecue is really good. The wait was not bad, probably less than 20 minutes. 

We got more than 2 lbs. (more than a kilogram) of 燒肉 (siu youk, crispy roasted pork) and 燒鴨 (siu ngaap, roasted duck). These refer to the Roasted Pork (#3 on the sign, 脆皮燒肉, Cheui Pei Siu Youk) and the Roasted Duck (#1 on the sign, 明爐火鴨, Ming Lou Fo Ngaap). We then went out, got some toothpicks and began to snack on them while watching the San Francisco sunset nearby. 

The crispy roasted pork was excellent. The crispiness had a really good crunch, and the pork had the right amount of tenderness. However, the roasted duck was even better. It was so freshly cooked, very juicy, very tender, and every piece was very meaty. The taste was almost heavenly after each bite. It was definitely one of the best Chinese roasted ducks I have eaten. 

If I had some freshly cooked white rice and some freshly cooked and somewhat seasoned vegetables with either the duck or pork, I think I would have the most ideal Chinese dinner or lunch. The prices are pretty good and almost cheap. It costs $6.75 for a pound of 燒肉, and it's enough to feed 4 people. As for the duck, it's about $8.75 for half a duck, but $14.95 for the whole duck. If you could only get one item off the menu, I recommend you get the roast duck or a dish that contains a generous portion of roast duck. 

Overall, if you do not mind the gritty setting and you are looking for some of the best Chinese barbecue meats in San Francisco, this place is a pretty good choice. I thought I had some of the best roast duck not only in San Francisco, but possibly in the USA.  I can't believe I am giving a somewhat gritty place in San Francisco a really high rating, but I thought I had the best Chinese barbecue style pork and duck in years.
author: Ambrose C.

description:
Duck...duck...goose? Okay, so they don't have goose, just a lot of duck and barbequed meats.

Why the five stars? For the duck alone. Crispy, crunchy exterior, and juicy interior.

Sure the tables are small and greasy. Sure the lines are long.

But this is one of the BEST places for duck, which is one of my TOP 20 favorite foods in the world.

Why are people complaining about seeing fat under the skin of the duck? It's duck, it has fat. It's not peking duck, where they scrap the fat off for you and give you a bun, some chives, and hoisin sauce. C'mon people, get a clue.

Duck, by it's very nature is fatty. I mean, if you're looking for a lean cuisine or something under 200 calories, you wouldn't be eating duck right?

Just a thought.
author: Jack R.

description:
Can you say Roast Duck. Seriously I swear every time Im hear someone is ordering that but it is good. My favs here are the soy sauce chicken (when they have it) and the fried rice. The food here is definitely good and tasty. If you like duck this is the place. There are other similar places in the district but this one is the best for duck.

The place is small but the lines can be long out the door.
Only downside is the long wait and the ladies can kinda be too pushy.
author: T C.

description:
This location always has a line out the door...why? Their meat options are pretty tasty...especially the roasted pork, peking duck, and BBQ pork. Be sure you specify how fatty or how lean you like your meat though. The best thing about this location though is that they realize there is a dinner rush and will continue to bring out fresh options well into 7pm!

Tip: Get your aggressive Asian side out though cause there's a fair amount of pushing, screaming, and general disorder.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I was lucky enough to find this place when my little brother moved to SF for school. When we dropped him off at his new place, we saw this place driving by and it said something like Top 100 Chinese Restaurants in the U.S.  That really caught my eye because I was like REALLY?? I have got to try this place! 

They do stand up to that! It is the BEST Chinese BBQ place I have been to in my life so far! It's a small little restaurant with maybe 4 tables but usually everyone just orders togo here. All the times I have been here, we have been lucky and missed the rush. I have heard that the line for this place can get really long!

Location: outside the main city in the Sunset District. South of the Golden Gate Park.
CASH ONLY
Parking - a bit of a pain because it's street parking - but deal with it, it's worth it.
Side Notes: fast service, clean tables and everything is at a decent price.

Food:
SUPER fresh roast pig and duck. Both came out looked and tasted heavenly! 

A two item combo on rice is about $8 and they give you lots of meat, barely any bones. Butcher knows how to cut his meat!! Thumbs up!

Here are a few items I have ordered from there:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cheung-hing-san-francisco?select=3mkW1XmbOQODMhBwzqjI8g#3mkW1XmbOQODMhBwzqjI8g
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cheung-hing-san-francisco?select=5Ge83a1x71uo8QIth0NUDg#5Ge83a1x71uo8QIth0NUDg

This dish is actually Scrambled Eggs with Beef. My husband LOVES this dish and we was on cloud 9 when eating this. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cheung-hing-san-francisco?select=mjiNop0ToWc2nWm4Vh5kuQ#mjiNop0ToWc2nWm4Vh5kuQ

Honestly, there's nothing in OC that matches to this place. Its a bittersweet relationship... I always have to stop by this place when I am in SF. 

They even have trophies on the wall!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cheung-hing-san-francisco?select=v-b42kV8Ocu9IBYkGTP5ug#v-b42kV8Ocu9IBYkGTP5ug
author: Thuy L.

description:
THE BEST CHA SIU (BBQ pork). 

Long lines sometimes, but hey, totally worth it!! I came here twice this week and drove over 45 minutes to eat their BBQ pork plate and even bought half a pound to bring it home. Their BBQ pork is cooked perfectly, and its not hard or not burnt on the outside. It's red, but not an artificial red like some other Chinese meat places.  I wouldn't usually choose to sit inside because it's not the nicest place to eat, but it's okay. I usually get their BBQ pork to go, and I get it "half fatty and half lean", however you say it in Chinese. makes it a lot less tough and it tastes really good!

Definitely coming back here again next week and buying a pound of that bbq pork!
author: Carmen C.

description:
Chinese style roast Pig and Duck.

Cheap and a sh*t ton of food.

You walk and and you can feel the authenticity of this shop as you stand in line and watch them chopping up a seemingly endless supply of roast duck and pork.

it is quite greasy, but so so so so worth it.  

One of those places where if you can't decide what to get, just get it all.  'Murrriica!!!


Tip: Get it to go, there isn't much space to eat there.
author: Steven F.

description:
Tip #1: If you're only ordering a menu item or rice plate, you don't have to wait in the long (meat) line, go inside and stand in line in front of the food counter.

Tip #2: If you're ordering meat and menu item, still stand in the long meat line. 

Tip #3: CASH ONLY and bring your own plastic bag. 

The bbq pork was pretty good! Most folks I saw were ordering the roasted and BBQ pork, so I followed and ordered the pork. I would go back again if I happen to be in the area and was hungry, but a special trip isn't warranted IMO.
author: Erin C.

description: 1 of 3 of the best places to get char  sui in the bayarea and forgot where the other 2 are but all one is ran by the father, one by the son , and one by the son in law lol
author: Karl L.

description:
My mom used to take me here as a kid after my orthodontist appointments down the street.  In hindsight, it was probably a bad idea since it wasn't great for the braces, but I do remember it being delicious.  There's always a line out the door which has got to mean that this place does something right.  That something, is their duck.

Well, of course I had to have their duck, and I doubled down with some roast pork over rice.  We also ordered the beef stew over chow fun as well.  The duck is delectable, and the skin is perfectly crisp without too much fat.  The pork was the same way and was a bargain for $6.50.  The chow fun was piping hot and paired well with the beef and veggies, and a great deal for about $6.

Their most popular dishes are their roasted meats and that's what you should come for.  Service was good, but if you don't speak Cantonese it can be pretty tough to communicate.  I would consider take-out next time to enjoy the dishes at home, but this place is a winner for sure.

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 6/10
author: Joe M.

description:
The Good, the Bad and the Ugly:

GOOD: The food was excellent, especially the bbq pork and eggplant with garlic.

BAD: The place could use a good cleaning, and some sort of system for those waiting. It's a little haphazard and is every woman for herself in nature.

UGLY: Placing the order on the phone was an exercise in frustration. The woman who answered the phone alternated between yelling to someone in Chinese and loudly asking me what I wanted. She could not hear me for the all the noise in the background, and all the secondary conversations she was holding, so I ended up literally yelling at the top of my lungs. I haven't yelled that loudly since I was married. I had to yell every dish name three or four times, and then yell the quantity I wanted another three or four times. I was ordering for a large group, so it was an extended yell fest. I was left with dizziness, a pounding pulse, and a vein in the middle of my forehead that I never knew existed.

But the food was good, and I'll go back for that bbq pork. I guess we all have our price.
author: Mary C.

description: Accidental find. Holy #&@%! We will definitely be back every chance we get. Roast duck and Char Siu were smoking!
author: B B.

description: This place is freaking amazing. I came here to order a few pounds of BBQ pork and roasted pig for dinner at a friend's house. They chop it up for you and make it easy to take home. Next time I come here, I will cook rice and have a feast at home. You can also order food at Cheung Hing and eat it there... the tables are small and it's claustrophobic with a long line of other people ordering their meat. Good for a few people but not a group. At any rate, the BBQ pork is a little too salty for my tastes, and they can run out of a certain part of the roasted pig if you get there too late in the day. I WILL BE BACK.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
The best roasted duck in the City! Period. 
This place is so popular, that usually you see people standing in line outside this tiny place. 
They do have several tables inside for those who want to grab a bite. 
They sell several side dishes (rice, noodles, veggies), but I don't like it much & prefer to stick with roasted duck, pig or soy chicken to go.
author: Ellie J.

description:
Don't come here for the ambiance, service, or cleanliness. Don't dine in.

Arrive early (before 7pm or else things run out), order quickly, and take it home.

On most days, you will find arguably the best roast pork, BBQ pork, and BBQ duck in the Sunset. Their fried tofu and roast pork tofu are also 100% scrumptious. When the weather cools down, they will bring out a killer dish: Mei Cai Kou Rou, or Pork Belly with Mustard Greens. If you aren't afraid of fat, this place is pure comfort.
author: Warren L.

description:
I know this place is tasty, but their taste is at the cost of mass amount of sodium and MSG.  I literally get high off the MSG here.  

The reason I don't come here anymore is their rodent problem.  It got shut down twice that I know of.  SF health department rarely shuts you down unless you're in serious violation.  Just too risky for me.  Be careful, and keep an eye on their health score if you wish to buy your meat here.
author: Jason L.

description: Cash only. We dined here and it was pretty dirty. I got the BBQ Pork Thick Noodle soup (Cha Siu Ho Fun) and it was good but lacked a little flavor. I guess you get what you paid for. It's relatively cheap and there are a lot of people getting take out. Their roast duck is pretty good though!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Oily floor, be careful not to slip and fall. Small place, the duck is mediocre, very fatty skin and yet tasty. Roast pork is ok and bbq pork is heavyweight loaded on Wine flavoring. Did not get a hit on MSG.
I probably will not go back. Locals can keep it! It has a line waiting though....tasteless and desperate people?
author: Bob W.

description:
Winner winner roast pork & roast duck dinner!  Okay, we actually got lunch to go here...but you know what I mean!  I've had Cheung Hing in Millbrae's roast pork many years ago with my then bf & from what I can remember that one can't compare to this one.

We wanted a light late lunch so we got a 1/2 lb of the roast pork & a 1/4 lb of the roast duck.  The pork was so good with it's delish crispy skin, oh Chinese roast pork I love you more than Lechon...but maybe it's because I'm Cantonese!  The roast duck was so juicy too. Probably one of best Chinese roast ducks I've had in awhile.  Even bf who doesn't care for duck admitted it was good.  We had rice at home so we just got it a la carte and it was under $8.  My dad always tells me how much he pays for cha siu, whole chickens, & roast ducks at Marina Market...if only there were a Cheung Hing in San Mateo!  

Next time we'll get more meat for sure for a yummy carnivorous dinner!  As others have mentioned too...get it to go because this place is teeny tiny!
author: Cat C.

description: Good Chinese bbq items & additional take out foods. I call ahead for the roast duck noodles & it is ready 5 mins later. There's always a line for take out. I have never experienced any 'yelling' other yelpers are talking about. The woman who helped me today was super nice & the food was tasty.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Super small and super cramped but we still managed to pack 9 people down at the table in he back. 
Considering how busy the take out line was for the whole time we were there the service was good. 
The must eats are the pork and the duck.  
Definitely better for take out then sit down but he food is on point either way.
author: Blake R.

description: I didn't order BBQ where people seem to come here for, but ordered porridge and chow mein. Both are a bit too bland for my Japanese standard. But Overall, I like them both.
author: Mike M.

description:
Ahh, this place has been around since we moved into this neighborhood 20+ years ago. It's been featured on many food and travel shows as well and the reasons are simple. It's not insanely overpriced yet they probably carry the best Roast duck or bbq pork you'll ever try outside of Asia. 

Since it's so close to home, I'll order it when I'm feeling fancy. The prices here have increased quite a bit since then but it's extremely tasty. The sauce they give you for the roast duck is to die for! It really does taste best served over rice, but again, what doesn't?

If you ever visit San Francisco, be sure to put this restaurant on your list of "must check out" places. There's usually metered parking right in front or free residential street parking during non peak hours.
author: Ced C.

description:
I don't think the BBQ was thaaat good.

I was craving BBQ and we decided to come here bc my bf said when he thinks of good BBQ...he thinks of this place. Decorations were...well, what do you expect from these typical Chinese places. Which I'm not saying it's bad, because I love Chinese restaurants. Even if the place wasn't nice but the food is still good? I will definitely come back.

We sat down and one of the ladies promptly gave us hot tea...we had to grab the menu ourselves which I didn't really mind.

I got the BBQ pork and soy sauce chicken. Now...I LOVE LOVE LOVE BBQ pork. Biggest fan of BBQ pork right here. Whenever my family went out to eat, they ALWAYS asked me "so, what do you want? BBQ pork again?" So I would say I know what GOOD BBQ pork tastes like. But, this wasn't that good. Definitely other places that are a lot better. The soy sauce chicken, on the other hand, was pretty damn tasty. A lot of meat. Yummm. Not that much sauce on the chicken itself...more on the rice haha. Some veggies on the side and a good amount of rice. The portion of our rice dishes was perfect. 

Funny story: There is always people lining up for this place (it was 4pm and it wasn't never empty...). Well, this one guy skipped all of them and ordered his food. The other see lais (lol if you're chinese you know who I'm talking about! hahaa) were GLARING at him. Hilarious.

Scary story: There was a little girl with her mom and she kept on singing but it was creepy...like those little kids in scary movies. lol. Please learn some Disney songs :/

I think I would come back again. Although the BBQ pork wasn't the most amazing, I think I want to try their other foods. A-OK for me!
author: Cathy C.

description:
My nose knows no fool.  

Cheung Hing is no fool when it comes to food.  

I pass by this restaurant everyday and I know you can't see it but my nose cracks a huge smile when it nehales all the wonderful flavors of the pork and duck.  

Order one or both items, steam some rice, and eat. Shh.  Don't talk, jsut eat.
author: Linda N.

description:
Two words: DUCK SAUCE.

Duck sauce, oh duck sauce,
How can you be so good?
You're such a danger to my health
But I always find myself in your neighborhood.

Duck sauce, oh duck sauce,
Your salty fatty goodness in me,
I pour you on everything,
On ramen, on veggies, on everything I see!

Duck sauce, oh duck sauce,
I must quit you,
For I am addicted,
But cannot find anything else to order on the menu!

This place is your typical Chinese butchery with duck, BBQ pork, roasted pork, soy sauce chicken, the whole works. People typically grab their food to-go. It doesn't matter what I'm ordering, I HAVE to get the duck sauce. Duh. Oh don't forget to order veggies if you're eating in, that way it kind of balances out the fatty intake of duck. I always get "gai lan," aka chinese broccoli. Their soy sauce chicken is pretty good too. Very tender and cooked to perfection. Then pour duck sauce all over it.
author: Arleen F.

description:
My family has always been loyal customers to this restaurant, and I can't say the food doesn't taste amazing. But just a couple days ago, after ordering the duck here, I had symptoms of nausea and vomiting for two days and so did my mom. My dad has a stronger immune system, so it took a while for his symptoms to show up, but as of now he is currently in the hospital due to the same symptoms and high fever. They are running tests to see what type of infection he has - hopefully it is nothing serious.

Not trying to rag on this restaurant, since I'm positive this does not happen everyday. This has not happened before when ordering from here, but just warning people out there that EVERYONE should be careful of where they order their food from. A lot of restaurants are very dirty and you never know what type of bacteria (e.coli, etc) may be lurking around in your food. 

I only posted this review because I noticed a couple other reviews down below VERY RECENTLY about the shut down and negative health inspection for this restaurant indicating its dirty conditions. 

Just please be aware of the restaurants you order from. Hopefully the conditions will get better because we love this place and I know a lot of people do too.
author: Cindy S.

description: Best Peking duck in the entire Bay Area!  This place gets crowded quick so go early!!
author: R B.

description:
Having heard of the amazing Roast Duck, I was about to get that but switched to Peking duck on seeing the menu.

Oh my, what a bad choice! The Peking Duck was ice-cold. It had all the flavours that makes a roasted duck tasty but alas I find no redemption in an ice cold dish such as this. The server kindly took it back to reheat but it was luke warm at best.

The chicken fried rice, thankfully, was simple but pretty tasty. I had a slice of the BBQ pork but I am not a porker so I have no opinion on it really.

The price was amazing though - $21 for fried rice + bbq pork + a whole Peking duck !!!

I will definitely go back as I need to try the famous roast duck and hopefully it would be hot and soul-satisfying.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

On my second visit, I decided not to stray from the roasted duck -- I had a rice place with it and came with a side of steamed cabbage; it was quite good and fortunately the duck wasn't ice-cold this time around.

Allergen warning: The wonton soup had shrimps so if anyone in your party is allergic to shellfish, like my friend is, then you'd want to be mindful of that. There was no mention of it and it was a good thing I took the first bite or he wouldn't have known about it.

I tried a piece of the sweet & sour pork and it was sub-par.

The bang-for-the-buck is pretty impressive if you stick to the duck. The rest are "meh" so far.
author: Umesh T.

description:
Basically your familiar SF Chinese cuisine, almost near sticky tables, tea in plastic cups, and quality good food.  The waitress can speak English and wants to feed you everything.  Seen all types of people here, so no need to feel intimidated.

Ordered: 
Tofu w/ fish (good, silky tofu!)
3 meat Fried Noodles (sam si jin mein; bomb)
Flat noodles w/ egg/shrimp gravy (wat dahn ha yun chow fun)

Have family who are regular customers here for their xa xiu, roast duck, and roast pork.  You can see why!

P.S. They also have trophies for top 100 Chinese Restaurants.  Check it out.  It's on the back wall.
author: Janet T.

description:
No need to repeat that the place is not the cleanest place in the world, but come on, it's a chinese duck and pork place! Line was not too long on a weekday around lunch. Communication is not bad as the guy cutting up the meat speaks some English. The only slightly tricky part is that the line that goes out the door is for the cut meat (pork, duck, etc) and apparently you can skip that line if you are getting a plate with rice. Not sure about that, so don't hold me liable!

Now, on to the food. I ate some of the pork on the way home and it was really tasty! I'd say as good as I'd had at other places. The duck is still in a holding pattern as I didn't eat it yet, but it looked awesome as he was cutting it up.

Overall a good experience and good pork. I'm assuming the duck is going to be up there too!
author: Marc K.

description: Food is ok. If the place closes, I wouldn't miss it because there's only one word to describe their service: RUDE!
author: Jane A.

description:
LARGE Orders BEWARE - NIGHTMARE & INCOMPETENCE AHEAD.  Cheung Hing has been a staple on Noriega throughout my childhood in the Richmond/Sunset until I made that leap down to Los Angeles for college then work.  The quality of food is better than say a Panda Express and prior to this last time, I've only been a standard wait-in-line/place an order customer.  It is a no-frills, quick eat place.  I understand that there may be new management.
 
I experienced my first (and last) catering ordering here as I returned to SF for my nephew's birthday.   I'd advise that you DO NOT CATER from here if you want your simple but large catered orders to be 1) prepared on the correct date, 2) ready at the time stated on your invoice, and/or 3) handled with any modicum of service.   
 
A large order was placed for over $400 with a cash deposit.  According to the employee, Jessica, my college educated Vietnamese sister-in-law who does not speak one ounce of Cantonese, but speaks perfect English called and had the date changed from the party date to the day before and the time was changed to 10:30 pm (yes pm) (I have a picture of the handwritten changes to the invoice).  The party was at a fixed venue reserved 2 months in advance and no the restaurant does not open past 9 pm.  After some basic reasoning, Jessica later acknowledged that either she or the employee misunderstood my sister-in-law and incorrectly changed the date and the time.  That mistake was obvious.  
 
This mistake by the restaurant led to some unnecessary chaos the day before the party as the restaurant thought it was supposed to prepare the order the day before.  Allegedly that was fixed.  However, we receive a call at 10:30 am the day of the party informing us that the food was ready (the food was supposed to be ready at 12:30 pm). Yes, this really happened even after confirming the correct date and time the day before when dealing with the prior fiasco.    I also suspect that this may have been a deliberate "misunderstanding" so the food would be ready pre-lunch rush, rather than the agreed upon time stated on the invoice. We scramble to get there early at 11:30 am and NO ONE helps to take the remainder of our balance (cash of course) or to give us our massive $400 order.  After some time, Jessica helps and yes some of the food, including the fried chicken is already COLD since they cooked it early at the incorrect time.    We wait for them to re-fry the chicken and load the car with the re-fried chicken and other trays of somewhat warm food.  Total time in since entering the restaurant to pick up our allegedly ready order - approximately 40 minutes (and one double parking ticket).   We ask to speak to the manager to discuss the various problems with our order- and the MANAGER REFUSED to COME OUT TO SPEAK TO US.  
 
It is unbelievable to experience such dismissive customer service (or lack thereof), particularly with respect to an order as large as ours. 
 
I grew up in the Richmond/Sunset area and I am very familiar with the way Cantonese establishments are run.  I did not expect Michelin star service, but I did expect bare bones-pride in your work and accountability for mistakes, particularly when a large order exceeding $400 is so blatantly and incompetently mismanaged.  
 
 
Also, I could do without the middle aged female worker at the take out counter who would not stop making snide comments in Cantonese as we futility waited to speak to the manager shouting things to Jessica such as "there is no one to blame for the error" and "we can't do anything for them" (yep, I understand Cantonese), As I told her, she didn't even know the half of the problems and yes there is a party at fault (several times over), the restaurant.  We took pictures of our copy of the original invoice and the restaurant's copy that was subsequently changed by hand with the incorrect date and time for any interested parties.
author: Julie W.

description:
Cheung Hing is the sole Asian deli I know of where you don't have to rely on a whole lotta luck to come at the perfect time of day to score the tres delicieux ribs part of the beast. No, these aren't mutant pigs genetically modified to grow extra ribs. Instead, they roast extra slabs of ribs separately (I think this is a new thing, or maybe it's not that new and I always thought I was my own lucky charm). I'll have to "experiment" a bit more (i.e. buy more often) before I can draw any conclusions about whether there's a notable difference between ribs roasted along with vs. apart from the whole body. Either way, I'm willing to shell up the extra buck per pound for guaranteed tender tastiness. And no matter what part you get, the skin is always perfectly crisp. 

Their roasted duck, on the other hand, is pretty standard. I like to get my ducks extra dry since they tend to be less fatty and slightly more flavorful, though I could hardly tell the difference last time I got an extra dry one from CH.

Cash only... The Wells Fargo next door has saved me a number of times!
author: Pauline D.

description: Mother always comes here to get duck, barbecue pork, roast pork, cuttlefish, and more. The prices are good.
author: Denise C.

description: Surprisingly tasty dishes. Definitely a notch up from the typical Chinese bbq place with bbq meats hanging in the window. Ate in, since we're not from the neighborhood, and was a bit uncomfortable since it's a small place with a constant line for takeout and people waiting for pickup.
author: Anthony B.

description: This place is better than the average for the roast duck and not the best.  I had roast duck and roast pork ribs combo plate and I'm grateful they were good portion.
author: Patricia C.

description:
My first review as Yelp Elite :). 

Cheung Hing gives me fond memories growing up. I used to eat here a lot with my family, especially when they were too busy to cook and just wanted something inexpensive and fast to eat. I absolutely LOVE their porridge here and I always get it. My favorite porridge is the seafood one. I love everything about it. They also make really good chow fun. What they are known for though are their roast duck and pork. Omg just thinking about it is making me drool... Definitely will ask my parents to eat here with me the next time I'm back in the city. 

Yes this place can be crowded and is outdated but as long as the food is good, thats all that matters right? Sometimes the best places are the hole in the wall establishments. None of that pretentious stuff! 

There is only street parking which can be tough to find but doable. They also do to go if you don't want to wait to be seated. Have some porridge for me the next time you are here.
author: Tommy L.

description:
This is the best place ( many places sell duck but this is the only place for those who love really duck) to get roast duck in SF. less fat and more meat on duck and seasoned perfectly. 
They also served cooked hot food to go. Always looks hot and tasty. Selection vary from days to day.
The line outside the door is long but moves quickly as most chinese getting food for dinner. Mostly Chinese in line....so you know it is pretty good. 
Sit down for lunch is good too. Wontons very good and other dishes off menu
author: Charles W.

description:
Cheap price. 
Duck done right. 
Years of business. 
Fast and traditional experience.
author: Robert T.

description:
A no frills, no bullshit Chinese spot to get your roast duck and BBQ pork. You know its legit when you have to order by the full pound and the guy across the counter speaks zero english.

The best roast duck i've had in SF! Definitely try it.
author: Andy J.

description:
Their roast ducks are artery-clogging good.  Seriously, a day later, I can still feel my heart pumping extra hard!

For appetizer, we ordered fried squid/calamari - it was SO GOOD.  While the batter was crispy, the squid inside was juicy and tender, with the perfect amount of salt and pepper covering each chunk.  These were not small chunks either; they were pieces from the body of the squid, so you won't be eating that dry, shriveled up tentacles!

I ordered roast duck over noodle soup.  The noodles they use are those yellow ones that have a bouncier texture... I wasn't expecting that, but it was decent.  What was amazing was the roast duck covering my noodles!  They were fatty, I could see my reflection from the grease on top of that crispy skin, and the layer of fat hidden underneath the crisp literally melted in my mouth!  The meat was really good as well - it was soft and didn't require a lot of chewing.  I love dark meat. 

Normally, I would expect roast ducks from places like this to be very salty, but it wasn't the case here.  The shop retains the juiciness & sweetness of the duck meat and did not over-season - always a plus!

I don't care what people say about MSG and how it makes you bald.  I was happy sitting next to two gigantic roast pigs (no, I wasn't talking about my friends), slurping my MSG-filled noodle soup!
author: Peggy S.

description:
My little template for ratings...
1 star: Terrible service and/or Terrible food, will never come back.
2 star: Some critical mistake with food or service, might have a small chance of trying it again.
3 star: Average; decent filler option on a day I can't think of anything else.
4 star: At least one really good dish that I would come back for. Consistently good.
5 star: TOP NOTCH, will be craving everyday.  Multiple great dishes or one AMAZING dish. Impeccable service and value.
***************************************************************************************
O...M...G...

If I'm in SF, I have to go here.  A small, mostly take-out joint with various Chinese hot deli items.

The Roast Duck over rice is AMAZING. It's served over rice with a side of cabbage, and each part of it is delicious and fits hand-in-glove.  The duck fat/jus is absorbed by the rice and I honestly could shovel it into my mouth all.day.long.

Got a side of Gai Lan (chinese broccoli) as a side, which had an appetizing vibrant green-ness to it.  It was perfectly cooked, not a hint of bitterness!

A go-to place for sure.  Just keep those health standards up please!
author: Sas N.

description: Cheung Hing has been voted as one of the top Chinese restaurants in the United States..! I go there for their Chinese Barbque Pork (Char Siu) and their roast duck (I get half-a-duck) but have eaten at a table once because all of the seats are almost always occupied (they are very generous with their portions). The quality of their food is really top-notch, but unfortunately the young women who work behind the counter definitely have an attitude and are very unpleasant. I wold have liked to give them a 5-star rating, but those women spoiled it. The chefs who chop up and carve the meats and poultry interact well with the customers,  and seem to appreciate their patronage. I have been their customer for at least 20 years.
author: George B.

description: We love this hole in the wall!! We always always get char siu & roast pork. Today I actually ate in and the service was great! We ordered the house special fried & Chinese broccoli with garlic sauce in addition to our regular meat orders. There is usually a line. PLEASE BRING CASH!
author: Bel W.

description:
Always a long line waiting in front of this place across from a Safeway around lunch and dinner time.  The windows showing the roast duck, chicken, pork hanging and the kitchen staff busy chopping up takeout orders (a unique Cantonese restaurant scene), and they also have some tables and chair for eat-in but the majority of the business are takeouts.  Every time I am craving for some greasy roast duck, cha-siu (roast pork), crispy siu york (roast pig or bbq pig with skin attached) or deep fried tofu, I come here.  They also have a variety of cheap Cantonese comfort foods that can be ordered by weight.  This place reminds me of back home in Hong Kong and things are pretty authentic.  Gosh, my mouth is watering while writing this review.

Due to the volume of business they do, many dishes and takeout orders are really fresh as the cooks are churning out trays and trays of them.  They also cater with large trays of yummy foods, like chicken wings, chow mein and fried rice.

Cash only!
author: Frank C.

description:
Probably the best Cantonese take-out restaurant in the Bay for cheap and tasty grub. Just look at the juicy, plump ducks hanging in the window if you're not convinced.

I always get the duck over rice, with a side of boiled cabbage to cut the grease.

Cheung Hing could be cleaner, obviously, but whatcha gonna do.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Their rodent problem is still exist here.
But that is a part of Chinese restaurant. I am well aware of the problem.
So, I don't judge any Chinese restaurant because by seeing a rat run around, a roach dropped from wall, and a few flies flying around. As far as I'm aware, no one has complained yet.
Be aware, Under new management.
The guy that cut the chicken up just doesn't understand what the customer service should be like in US. He does chop the chicken's head off like a SOB!
When i call the place back up, the person that answer tries not to understand english or difficult to communicate.  come on.  without customer service or messed up customer service like this will not work either.  
Train your workers properly to serve the public and do not try to disavow knowledge of it.
Also ... sometimes you maybe run into a situation like this,
"go home, excited about the duck, open the box only to find a duck head and bill, pieces of neck, and a bunch of skin and bones....wtf.....? "
people had the same problem before and suspect that they keep those pieces for their rice plates that they sell. 
Those dirty crooked thieves!
The duck is mediocre, very fatty skin and yet tasty. Roast pork is ok and bbq pork is heavyweight loaded on Wine flavoring. Did not get a hit on MSG.
I probably will not go back. Locals can keep it! It has a line waiting though....tasteless and desperate people for nothing.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I normally only rate a restaurant based on the food alone,  but since they fucked up my order I will base this on service also.

So I walked in expecting to order my food and go because it's your basic Chinese togo place. Didn't expect any sort of awesome service except to take my order,  pay,  and go; Cuz you know,  it's a Chinese togo place. 

Anyways,  I ordered some bbq pork, and an order of fried chicken wings. The worker says that it will take 15-20 minutes for the chicken wings.  I asked her to go ahead put in the order, and repeated to her exactly what I wanted in Chinese just so there was no miscommunication. I let her know that I wanted to go across the street to Safeway to buy something and just have the order ready. She said okay.

I came back in 15 minutes and she sees me and says,  "hey we didn't cook the wings yet,  but here is your bbq pork, you want something else instead of the wings?" Right before that I saw a guy walking out with an order of chicken wings, so I was like "wait a minute,  wtf you mean you didn't cook the wings? I waited for almost 20 minutes! If I wanted something else I would have ordered it 20 minutes ago."

I wanted to asked how long will it take to cook more wings... but I walked out, never to return. 

I was most upset about being lied to... they should have just said they gave away my order by mistake,  and that they will make more right away... but no, she starts helping another customer, and ignores me, because she realized I knew she was lying.
author: Mike W.

description:
This little hole-in-the-wall is such a gem. I came here on a Saturday afternoon at 2pm, and found the place enjoying a steady stream of customers, most of whom were elderly Chinese people living around the area.

That's when you know the meat is good, when old Chinese people are lining up for it because 1. it must be authentic as fuck and 2. Chinese people waiting in line?

The portions are huge, so don't try to order two rice plates (roast pork and roast chicken) and half a roast duck. You'll stump over in meat sweats and wish you had never set eyes on this place.

The duck is roasted so that the skin is nice and crispy while the meat is still incredibly juicy and tender. I personally would have asked for leaner portions, because the regular ones came with pieces that were entirely skin and fat (which some people love). The drippings go great with a side of rice, it's packed full of umami and fat that just rolls great off the tongue.

The roast pork was tender as well. The 5-spices chicken was dry and quite flavor-less. The skin wasn't roasted to crisp either.
author: Chia L.

description:
Cheung Hing isn't a really big place, but it sure does serve a quality product.  I would highly recommend the BBQ pork and the roast pork.  The BBQ pork is moist and very flavorful.  The roast pork had very crispy skin and the meat was soft.  Can't really describe it in much more detail- just go and try it!

I've also had the porridge, which was fine; but I'd stick with the roast meats.  I'll be sure to try the roast duck next time!

Notes:
-Metered parking directly in front, or free street parking around the corner.
author: Samantha L.

description: This place has the most incredible roast pork I've ever had. It's the Franklin's of Chinese roast pork. I don't know how they keep their meat so juicy.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Do you know they are ranked as 1 of the top 100 Chinese restos in the US? That said, go here for the roast/ BBQ meats!

Not a lot to say about the ambiance but this is the #1 place to go for Roast Pork! Their roast pork has crispy skin and moist & flavorful meat!
author: Gordon O.

description: Unbeatable value!  Great tasting roast duck, bbq pork, and traditional Cantonese BBQ house  style dishes.  Be sure to request the au ju when you get the roast duck.  The flavors are incredible; you can taste the maltose, honey, red vinegar, five spice, and ginger.  The ducks were all incredibly succulent and fat.  This place is pretty dirty, and is a hole in the wall, but the service is friendly and they know they don't have to keep it too clean because the food will rock your socks off.
author: David C.

description:
This review is only for the roast duck won-ton soup. 

Everytime I go to Cheung Hing I get the roast duck won-ton soup and a diet coke. It is one of my favorite restaurants in SF based on the strength of that dish alone. 

This place is legit judging by the huge lines that form for takeout. Maybe someday I'll get around to trying something else...
author: Alex W.

description:
I got the bbq pork, and even though it was one of the better ones in the city, the real gem here appears to be the roast duck that is filled with broth. Upon ordering, the butcher chops off the head and juice just pours out. I've been on the lookout, and so far no other place in the US rivals this spot. If you know of one, please let me know.
Wear only what you won't be upset about if some grease gets spilled on it.
author: Brian J.

description:
I've stopped by here for takeout food items only, sampling the chicken, roast pork, BBQ pork, duck, whole roast pig and many of their deli items.  I find the meat to be fairly lean, not overly fatty or greasy.  I've also ordered noodle and rice dishes off the menu that are cooked to order.  Their fried chicken wings are outrageously good, especially when they come right out of the fryer.  Lines can get pretty long so I try to stop by during down times or call ahead with my order.  Party trays are fairly popular.

I've never eaten in but would have no problem doing so if the opportunity presented itself.  The seating area is small and spare, but you're there for the food, not the ambiance.  I've always found the service to be friendly and like that you can see your deli meats being prepared/packaged in front of you.

A great option for solid Chinese food when you feel like eating it at home.

I like this location so much better than the Clement St. store, as they are way more honest and parking is easier.
author: Melissa L.

description: Chinese BBQ!, Try them all, they are all delicious! if you don't want to wait in line, you can pay a little extra by dining in. don't be shy to ask for a better cut of the meat. check out the window and lock down on a specific of meat before you order (unless some one else in front of you had the same taste as you). the Cha Siu and Roast Pork are simply amazing here. much better than their other locations.
author: Raymond L.

description: Probably the best Cantonese-style bbq pork dish I have had in SF so far..very little fat and beautifully roasted, a generous portion, and  inexpensive as well. It's a bit remote from downtown SF not far from Ocean Beach, but if you like pork, duck, and cuttlefish hanging in the window - you will definitely like this place.
author: Robert B.

description:
This has always been the go-to place for me when i'm too lazy to cook dinner.  They get busy during lunch and dinner hours and the line gets kind of long. Well, not too long. it never took more than 10 mins to get what i wanted. 
I recommend the BBQ pork & roast duck especially. String beans are good too! That's all you need to be happy :) you won't regret it!!
author: Anh T.

description: I spent a month traveling through China last fall and as soon as I stepped out of the car on Noriega, I was magically transported to the back alleyways of Shanghai after 11pm. This is a traditional hole-in-the-wall Chinese joint with BBQ'd ducks hanging in the front window and a buffet counter from which the workers serve up take-out. There are a few funky orange plastic tables to sit at and the service was super friendly. We ordered the Mongolian Beef (excellent flavor, not very much beef though), the delicate greens in garlic (bok choi soaked in yummy garlic sauce), and the BBQ'd pork (large portion of sliced pork). Everything was cooked perfectly, even the tea was delicious. I totally recommend this place!
author: Jacquelynne O.

description: This place has the most authentic traditional Chinese food that I have tried. I'm a huge fan of Chinese barbeque pork, so I ordered that as well as some wings and honey walnut shrimp. I absolutely loved the Chinese barbeque shrimp. It was cooked well and just the right amount of salty and sweet. The wings were the best out of everything we ordered. They had this unique fried texture, and it was so crispy and hot. The walnut shrimp was a little bit too much mayo for me, but I loved how they had so much walnuts with the shrimp. The food was about a five star, but I have to give this place a four just because I thought that the place could use some cleaning up and sanitation. Other than that, I would definitely eat here again.
author: Julie Y.

description:
Cheung Hing is the best Chinese BBQ takeout joint that I've tried in the city. I first wandered here while going grocery shopping at the Safeway across the street - it is impossible not to notice the line of people going out the door. They have the standard Chinese BBQ fare, like crispy roast pork, char siu pork, roast duck, soy sauce chicken etc. All the meats here are fantastic, and if you order the meat, you get to enjoy the sight of a large Chinese man wielding a cleaver and slicing through connective tissue. Though the BBQ joints on Irving are a bit more convenient to get to, Cheung Hing is my first choice when picking up takeout. Plus the parking here seems to be less of an issue than on Irving.

The reason that I cannot give Cheung Hing five stars is that the dine-in experience is pretty mediocre. The menu is devoid of appetizers, the service is inattentive, the hot sauce is incredibly salty, and the tables are of questionable cleanliness. So if you come here, come for the takeout.
author: Sidney L.

description:
OMG!! This is the best char siew ever!! They also have tasty duck and roasted pork. If you come during lunch hours there is usually a long line out if the door. This place is great for take out, although there are 4-5 tables to sit at it is a small place. We usually order:
- char siew
- roast pork
- string beans
- white rice
author: Belia P.

description: I come here ALL THE TIME for the BBQ pork! Love love love. All the people working are so kind and pretty funny. I also like trying some items they have for rice plates like green beans, tofu, and pork belly. This is a regular spot for me.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Ummm..I hadn't been here for a couple of years but we happened to be in the neighborhood and starving but I probably will not be back and if so, I will be way more careful.

You know, its weird being treated like a tourist in a city I've spent most of my life in..first off..and you would think they have enough business not to act shady but here goes.

The place is very very noisy, small and packed. So my plan was to get some of the deli counter items, which are plentiful, and take it over to the park or maybe even home.

Case 1: the fried rice incident. there's a huge vat of fried rice right behind the counter. Well wait..

Case 1: the screaming. When a person is quietly pointing to items she is interested in purchasing, the woman behind the counter repeats the request, only screaming at the top of her lungs in Chinese. 

I don't really see the point of this as no one is farther than 36 inches away, and its very distracting.

Then, with a huge vat of fried rice clearly visible, she hands me a menu and says "what kind". Uhh..how about that kind? Points.

Still screaming, she vanishes in a vortex of noise and goes to the kitchen to place a menu order for the rice. Uhhh...No.

I ask for some fresh vegetables. She sort of carelessly tosses an almost empty vat of old cabbage in my general direction. Nope

My  gf, who is right on her game, cleverly orders string beans from the menu. This is the last we hear of it for awhile.

Feeling that we have, under the most incredible duress, managed to order rice and a vegetable, and buoyed by a foolish self confidence,  we move on to the meat. Now, this is where their money grabbing techniques really shine.

In most chinese delis, they understand that 2 people are probably not ordering for a family of six or eight. Here, that is the assumption. So, when I ask the butcher for a half duck, a "little bit" of roast pork and a "small order" of spare ribs, this is what he gives me, and I swear to God, I thought I was watching him prepare someone else's order.

He gives me a 2 meat combination rice plate consisting of 1/4 duck and a little roast pork on a huge bed of rice, with a couple of tablespoons of the used cabbage. I'm thinking, gee, glad I am not THAT sucker.

Then he cuts a half pound of said meats. Each. Now, all of this is happening with a busload of people who just got in line, with a steady volume of unrelenting screaming. I seriously want to get out of there.

Finally our order is packed. We're 2 people in a chinese deli, how much could it cost?

Forty seven dollars. Yup. $47.00

At this point I'm thinking whatever, I need to get out of here. We'll have leftovers, lots of them.

We get to the car and take the food out of the bags, and that's when I see that we have the rice plate, pounds upon pounds of meat, and no string beans.

To their credit, they took back the rice plate and lo and behold, there was our order of string beans. When everything was changed out, we still had way more food than we wanted and spent way more money than we planned to.

So, how was the food, Sharon?

The fried rice tasted like ass, I kid you not. Worst. Ever.

The duck, their claim to fame, was actually quite good.

Everything was so over salted that  9 hours, an ice cream sundae and several bottles of water later my mouth is still burning. Is salted food supposed to make your throat and tongue hurt?

And I have a fridge full of this over salted meat that I will probably save a bit of to throw into a soup or a pot of greens, and the rest will probably be tossed.

This, from someone who can make a $20 order from Tsing Tao last for 3 meals and a snack. Who always asks for low salt.

I'm actually quite irritated that I find the meat inedible, it was a huge waste of money. Whatever I paid for the rice, it was too much.

If you are courting high blood pressure and a stroke, this would be the place to buy food. I promise, there is no way you can be prepared for the screaming, the crowd and the whirlwind of over cutting by the butcher. 

No way I am ever going back there.
author: Sharon J.

description:
A Few Things About Cheung Hing.

1. The roast duck is astonishingly tasty. If you get one thing, get this.
2. The porridge is damn good.* Work up to the pork organs though.
3. The chow fun, the BBQ pork and the fried rice were solid.
4. The sesame chicken was too sweet for me, but others loved it.
5. The food is absurdly cheap. 15 people can FEAST for $75.
6. Almost every dish is like $6, so actually, go nuts and order those pork organs if you really want them.

My only real quibble with them is the title of the Noodles And Fun section of the menu. Because obviously, noodles ARE fun.
__________

*Don't take my word for it, take my mom's. She likes porridge more than you.
author: Peter D.

description: I usually love the dishes here, but the other day I ordered a roasted duck to-go and the duck was full of fat :( That disappointed me a bit. It costs $16 for an entire duck, which is better than ordering half. I like the stuffed tofu they have and the soy sauce chicken as well. The roasted pork is always super crispy, which is probably my favorite here. I haven't been here in awhile since I don't live nearby anymore, but when I do, it's for the roasted duck or pork!
author: Amanda C.

description: I came here at the recommendation of my friend who grew up in SF and is in San Diego now. This place has the best roast duck I have ever had. It is very flavorful and orasted correctly and the meat was just good. As far as the barbecue pork, it was more chewy and I didn't care for it as much. The roast pork was really good too. I go the three barbecue combination over rice. This place is fairly tiny so the actual restaurant portion is literally 3 or 4 tables and that is it. It can get crowded if busy. For a Chinese barbecue place, it is infinitely better than anything San Diego has and reminded me of how much I miss good Chinese food. It is one of those comfort food type places.
author: Jonathan E.

description: This was good food and seemed to be a local spot.  I would go there if you like bbq pork/duck.  That seems to be their specialty.  I had the Black bean fish which was good but I wasn't going to go here just to get it.  Prices were certainly reasonable.  Menu looked big but everyone was getting the bbq pork.
author: David G.

description: Prices increased tremendously in the past year. Less meat in dishes. Food is decent but not the best. They should be better about their sanitation habits. They use the same pair of gloves to pack your food, take your money and clean the counters.... makes no sense to me. It's not very clean in general and I'm surprised it doesn't have a food safety warning sign. You can tell all they care about is money, trying to be polite and nice is basically a waste of time. They mostly just yell in Cantonese at you if you don't know what you want. Won't give discount if you order a lot of party trays. Not on time with making all the food when requested in advance. Not very friendly and that's something that I come to experience at restaurants I don't want to get attitude when spending money at a place and get bad customer serviceS
author: Vicky C.

description:
I got the BBQ Pork and the Roast Duck lunch special, which came out to $8.50. The special came with a side of steamed cabbage and rice. The cabbage was overcooked and began to make the rice mushy. The Roast Duck was too fatty, with barely any meat on the bones. The BBQ Pork was done well, but I wouldn't order it with the special - order it separately. The website is not for this location, it's for the South San Francisco location, so be wary when you place your order.

Might come back if I'm craving BBQ Pork again, but it did not satisfy my duck craving. For the price, I wouldn't order this special again.
author: David H.

description: Aside from having the best Chinese BBQ, they also have great rice plates. Most people takeout, but we sit down even though it is very cramped. We always order the BBQ duck liver in addition to our rice plates. My family has been coming here since I was 4 years old and I hope they will always be here to make the best roast duck, roast pork, and cha siu.
author: Nicholas T.

description: I think ownership has changed....I've noticed in the past six months that the ducks are leaner (hardly any meat) and the people running the front are ruder than ever.  I'm all about roast duck, but I'm willing to pay more for roast duck at Noriega Seafood where there is actually meat on the bones.
author: lucy w.

description: food is always the best but the service is always unfriendly, the waitress is extremely rude and that's why this place always get 3 stars......she needs to understand that service is just as important as the food......other than that I always come back for the BBQ and Roast duck
author: Johnny H.

description: The duck was pretty good. The won ton soup was just alright. Would go back just for the duck.
author: B L.

description:
It's roast duck and BBQ pork is the best that I ever had in the silicon valley. 
My son can finish half of the roast duck anytime. 
The BBQ pork is not that fatty but roast duck can be fatty since those ducks are from America not from Asian :) 
well, like all tasty food, most of them are not good for LDL measurement. 

The other must try item is their sticky rice (luo mai Kai in Cantonese ) 

This place us truly a hole in the wall with shitty restroom BUT their food is too good to resist.  I would recommend to-go instead of eat-in
author: Johnson C.

description:
We've been coming here to pick up lunches and dinners often for as long as I could remember like over 20 year.  Once in awhile they would disappoint. They disappointed us big time the week of thanksgiving. The roast pork was dry and salty, the beef chow fun was soggy and tasteless and the salt and pepper fish was oily and portions were small. I guess they could blame it on high demand. The line was out the door and you could tell they barely kept up with phone orders and cashiering. But as a long time faithful customer that is a poor excuse. 

I am thinking twice about going back now.
author: Rose O.

description:
By now you should already know two things about Cheung Hing on Noriega Street based on the majority of the Yelp reviews:

1. The roast duck is awesome and quite possibly the best in San Francisco.
2. The lines are crazy long and if you want your duck you're going to have to wait for it.

So our family has had their roast ducks and their Chinese BBQ on many occasions, but at least once a year we depend on Cheung Hing to cook up party trays of some of their other foods in helping our extended family celebrate my dad's birthday.  My dad is the typical home body.  He doesn't like eating inside a restaurant, and he finds it a lot more comfortable to gather up friends and family and have a feast at his house.  Over the years our gathering has taken on a sort of pot luck style with mostly everyone bringing a favorite dish to share, but we always order extra food from Cheung Hing just in case.  Besides, good food to take home after the party is a big bonus since my dad hates leftovers.

Among the four dishes we ordered this year and based by the popularity vote from the guests were:

Beef Chow Fun with Bok Choy (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sAh7HSFXR9qnuH3kT3koeQ?select=2TCjsiYasxiW6nKc8VDcLA) - This has been the favorite every year because both kids and adults like fun (flat rice noodles).  The fun and the bok choy were very good.  I was the last of the nearly 20 guests to fill my plate, and most of the beef was already scooped up.  The bok choy was cooked up just soft enough to bite into cleanly.  It must've been good because the little kids all wanted seconds.

Braised Tofu with Mushrooms & Carrots (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sAh7HSFXR9qnuH3kT3koeQ?select=182sHWyFewOWVabJrSv7qA) - I love tofu, and this was my favorite.  The silky, soft melt-in-your-mouth tofu squares were lightly fried and the light brown gravy that it was served in was gentlely seasoned.  The mushrooms and carrots were mostly gone, although my sister and my niece each managed to find a hidden mushroom submerged in the gravy.  I just loved the tofu and that's the dish I went to for my seconds.

Green Beans with Chicken Sauteed in Garlic (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sAh7HSFXR9qnuH3kT3koeQ?select=9XG79mYN_F3MM4F2b5jNeg) - There was lots of minced garlic and crunchy green beans and just a bit of soft white onion.  I noticed the kids didn't really get into this dish, but the adults loved it.  Lots of boneless chicken pieces although I found a little corn starch residue on a couple of my chicken pieces.  I loved the minced garlic and the beans.

Chicken and Pork Chow Mein (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sAh7HSFXR9qnuH3kT3koeQ?select=MYcCO-_n5vpetRFHp7-F4Q) - This has usually been a favorite, but this year the noodles seemed a bit more starchy than normal.  Most of the noodles were clumped together, but they gave us lots of shredded chicken and pork and very little bean sprouts, onion and green onion.  The kids didn't really go for this which told us something was not right about it.  It tasted fine; I just wish the noodles weren't all clumpy.

Definitely expect a crowd when you go and be patient because there's good food waiting at the front of the line.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Mouse scurried across the floor!!!!!!!!! June 2015.

I used to come here all the time in the 1990's. Hands-down tastiest Cantonese roast duck in the Sunset. But I won't be going back after the mouse incident. Even tasty roast duck is not worth it.
author: I Like T.

description:
GET THE ROAST PORK. 

Best roast pork in the city. Dat crispy skin on top of a nice ratio of fat and meat. So moist. So good.

Not sure about the duck, it was just alright. But this is now my go-to place for the pork. Don't expect decor or service with a smile or clean facilities. 

Damn that pork is goood.
author: C. Z.

description: Stopped in on a Friday night 30 minutes before closing with a few friends. Definitely a tasty greasy spoon Chinese restaurant.
