We ordered roast duck wonton soup, sauteed beef with scrambled egg and chicken with string beans. I enjoyed everything. Service and interior is definitely no frills, but I appreciated how they accommodated my request to make the roast duck wonton soup with noodles because I accidentally thought they came with them. An added touch of entertainment was that they mopped the floor around us while we ate dinner because they were trying to close. In other circumstances I might be extremely annoyed, but it was all in line with my expectations and added to the "authenticity" of my experience. haha.
author: Alice H.

description: Under new management that does not know how to plan/time the food.  Previous owners always had food coming out at just the right time.  This is for both BBQ stuff and precooked.  I've been standing here for 15 minutes and the trays are all empty with no signs of anything coming out soon.  Sad it has gone downhill.
author: n y.

description:
If you want clogged arteries, a heart attack, heartburn, to become obese or all of the above, then this is the place for you. 

The roast duck is the most salty fatty mcfatty fat duck I've ever eaten. Imagine a duck with no meat, but bones and fat. Can someone say high blood pressure?

I tried the sticky rice wrapped in the lotus leaf and I have to say... it was not so good. It was dry (probably from sitting there all day), and just.. gross. I don't know what they put in it, but I guess I can't expect too much since I went 5 minutes before closing time to pick up the fattiest meal ever. 

If you like fatty meat, then I highly recommend this place! It will give you the biggest food coma and leave you thirsty for days. Be sure to have some water nearby unless if you want to pass out of thirst, haha
author: Caroline L.

description:
I'm Chinese and I've been coming here since the 80's!!

I've had many Chinese roast ducks in my life and trust me when I tell you this is the BEST!!  Their duck is so flavorful!!  No one else comes close in flavor as Cheung Hing.  My dad told me that's because it's Macau style. 

INSIDER TIP: 
If you're not going to eat the duck right away, don't let them pour the duck au jus on the cut meat.  Ask for the au jus on the side.  By the way, it's the au jus that makes it taste so good NOT the plum sauce, so don't let them skip you out of the au jus!!

Be careful they'll charge you extra for the au jus.  I don't know why, because it was already in the duck before it's cut so why do I have to pay extra, right?! 

I remember when the duck price was only $8 and they NEVER charged you extra for the au jus, but now it's $15 and they charge you extra for au jus.  Really?!!!  You'd think they'll just give you the au jus instead of charging you extra for it.  You know they're just going to throw that away at the end of the day.

I forgot to mention their BBQ pork is one of the BEST I've ever had as well.  I just love their duck so much I have to buy one every time I'm in SF.
author: G Y.

description: Hands down, the best roast duck. And also amazing BBQ and crispy pork. Great rice dishes
author: Peter K.

description: I was excited to try food from reputed Cheung Hing. Regretfully, i was underwhelmed. The 5 spice chicken, noodles, beef, tofu dishes were all middle of the road and nothing stood out. There were a lot of leftovers which is a sign.
author: Sunil R.

description: If you're craving chinese food to go, this is the place. Everything I had was really tasty and had me wanting more. If you decide to grab food from here, expect a large food coma. I recommend getting the tomato beef chow mein and chicken wings. If you're not the meat type, then get the string beans. Now if you would excuse me... I have a fridge full of yummy leftovers that I have to tend to.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Really delicious duck. Quick tip: order the entire duck; otherwise they'll give you the half of the duck that's super fatty (think...60% fat, 20% skin, 10% bone, and 10% meat). Char siu also very good.

Great prices for everything. Spared my friends the shame from my gluttony by not ordering more. Will order some organ meat next time.
author: Dianna D.

description:
WHAT. I do believe the great woman from 1350 B.C., Nefertiti, once said, "If you can build three great pyramids, you can surely open a storefront of whole ducks, hogs & slabs of ribs taller than teenagers." Math need not apply. You may see 30th & Noriega as the great hinterlands of San Francisco. OK. We who live a dozen blocks away see it as a neighborhood Chinese BBQ staple. The key point in your deliberation to trek West is that Cheung Hing demands you go in a group to go whole hog or the equivalent in beef or bird. 

While waiting for Friday night, 8pm take out, I witnessed a table of two receive their dinner within 5 minutes, which included a whole duck. While I waited for duck fried rice, two pounds of chicken wings & duck noodles, offered with smiles were tuna in oyster sauce and the duck fat duck fried rice. Cash only while the man to your right chops birds and ribs. What's my favorite thing about this place? The ratio of square feet of meat to square feet of other real estate is about 3:5, which translates into: for the faint of heart of meat, please come here & we'll convince you that your meat sweats, your new meat sweater & scarf you will adore.

Note: I have no idea what Nefertiti has to do with this or anything else.
author: Jon A.

description:
This place literally gets all three stars for having East Coast style duck sauce.  
  
Go ahead - search Yelp (or any other search engine) and try to find another Chinese Food place in the Bay area that has it.  
 
You will not...because I did. Was not happy.  
 
That being said?  This place is fairly horrifying.  I over-ordered so I could try a buch of stuff, and the only things that were good were the veggie fried rice, and the chicken wings.  (and of course the duck sauce).  
  
Inside?  Yikes.  Bathroom?  What room?  What What?  
 
Quick note for those going to other Chinese places and searching for duck sauce.  it is sometimes called "Golden Plum Sauce"
author: Adam P.

description:
disclaimer:  I am aware this place is famous and popular for their Chinese BBQ food to go  (particularly duck) and my family have purchased from them several times before.  This review is based on my latest and perhaps only dine-in experience

This store is the perfect example that once a store has become popular and famous, they can basically do anything and the people would still continue to line up.  My wife and I were craving for some roasted ducks, so we decided to dine in and ordered wonton soup and roasted duck.  the waitress told us that it's going to be a FIFTEEN minutes wait.  Then she explained that they only do their wontons in batches, I guess to save their time and pots, but whatever, we ordered beef brisket and BBQ pork noodles instead..  

It was a long wait for a simple basic order (the line is long, but that's only for the outside to go food... but whatever).  I noticed another dine-in customer is complaining, and the waitress was saying something like they'll only do something if there are two or more orders, and the customer finally said "fine I'll have two orders", and then the waitress said, "but we can't we do it now because we are too busy"... the customer was like forget it.

finally, our orders have come.  I was thinking since it was a long wait and such a famous place, and cost $7.50 each, the quality has to be good.  Well, the duck is good, but both of the noodles tasted like crap. there's not much difference between the broth and the tea.  the pieces of beef briskets are WHITE and some are even COLD as if they just chopped some right from their freezer and dumped in the soup and served to us immediately.  the waitress did give us some "roast duck sauce" to dip the beef briskets in... BBQ pork is Ooookay, but we only got the skinny dry parts, I guess these are the unwanted parts they throw in noodle soup as they wanna save the juicy crispy parts for to go orders.   Anyway, I've had MUCH better  noodles for cheaper (even ABC, or the other Chinese BBQ place two blocks down the road with no customers) at cheaper price... heck, I could have made better noodle soup myself and faster.

safe to say, we would not consider dining in ever again, to go only...  and even then, it's getting more tempting to just go to the other place and skip the line.  the duck there isn't that bad either.
author: gswfan ..

description:
Ever since I can remember, my family has always relied on Cheung Hing for roast duck, roast pork, and BBQ pork. It is hands down the best Chinese roast meat-y goodness I've had the fortune to consume. I am also a die-hard fan of their plum sauce as it goes very well with the roast duck.

The line is usually long, especially during Lunar New Year or other Chinese festivities so plan accordingly.

My family would normally buy the meat as take-out and enjoy it in the comforts of our home. I dined in tonight with my boyfriend but even though we were seated comfortably (we went in half an hour before closing), the greasiness of EVERYTHING was off-putting for my beloved germaphobe. 

Consequently, I knocked a star down for the cramped, limited seating and layers of grease that prove witness to the long-standing business. If you must dine in, try to go during slow hours. The service is more attentive (the waitress addressed my boyfriend as "pretty boy" when offering to refill his tea :P) and you might be able to haggle.

Oh, as with most Chinese places, "SOLLIE, CASH ONLY!"
author: Evonne M.

description:
Yes, this is THE place to get your roast duck.  It is that good...in fact, it's the best roast duck I have ever had, EVER!  Moist, juicy, perfectly flavored and seasoned delicious duck.  If I could replace all other poultry dishes in my life with the roast duck from Cheung Hing, I would.  

There is a Cheung Hing in Millbrae, where I live but I'd much rather make the drive into Noriega for the duck here.  For some reason, the duck in Millbrae doesn't compare to Noriega.  There's a reason why there is always a line. 

I'm not going to lie, my arteries definitely feel like they are slowly clogging up from the duck here but it's okay...I think i'm going to duck heaven.
author: Amy L.

description:
Delicious Delicious Delicious!!!!  The food here is really good and they are great if you need to cater food. We were throwing a party and needed something good, quick and most importantly affordable.   We ordered:

green beans with bbq pork
eggplant
tofu with veggies
beef chow fun
salt and pepper chicken wings

Everyone was impressed by how good the food was and asked us where we went to for catering. Cheung Hing makes it so easy. They have catering menus and list the prices for small and large pans.  We had about 15 people and still had leftovers with the small pans.  Small pans run from $20 to $25 dollars depending on the order.  The lady we placed the order with was really nice. The roast duck hanging by the window looked REALLY GOOD. I wanted to order that too but didnt want to die of a heart attack on this trip home.
author: Janet E.

description:
Mmmmmm roast duck over a bed of cabbage and rice with yummy duck drippings! 

It's been a while since I've ordered this dish because I've been disappointed so many times at various restaurants around the bay area.

My partner in crime swore that its the best place in town so I decided to give it a try.  Right when I stepped out of the car I could smell the spices :) so that was definitely a good sign.

We were greeted, seated, and served hot water within five minutes.  It's a very casual place and everything looked really good.  

We ordered:

Roast duck entree- juicy roast duck over cabbage and rice that was covered with duck drippings.  I am not a big rice fan, but I devoured that plate!  Every morsel of that duck was exloding with flavor and you can't leave rice there if its covered with awesome goodness!

Bbq'd pork entree-sweet & savory bbq'd pork over rice and cabbage.  I would have eaten that plate too, but I was too occupied with my own dish :) .  I did try two pieces and was sold on the sifu's skills.  I will definitely be back!
author: Michelle S.

description:
I've been here several times and I really want to try everything they make, but can't get past the char siu pork and roast duck...it's the best in the Sunset.

The service can be hit or miss...but with Cantonese BBQ this good...who cares...
author: Zoran L.

description:
I think these mofos have finally $queezed the last of my hard earned dollars through my cornholio.

From now on, I will do my best to support the underdogs of Cantonese roasties where I can, like this joint that while looks a bit more run down, is still friendly and delivers the goods, should I be in the area

http://www.yelp.com/biz/happy-bakery-and-deli-san-francisco-2

As much as I like the convenience of having Cheung Hing be on the one stop Noriega block shop, and possibly be the best on the block for that stuff, I think I'm done with them for a long long time.

The butcher dude and the middle aged woman behind the counter aren't exactly Mr and Mrs Miscellaneous and eager to please. I mean a smile once in a while to a customer, and even a "thank you" won't kill ya, right? Are we doing you a favor by walking through the door, or are you doing us a favor, mmm?

Perhaps it was my innocent inquiry (in hopes of change) whether credit cards were accepted....but

- quality of roasties based on the last two visits were very average. 

-asked for "half lean half fat" in Canto for BBQ pork...yes sometimes I like it unhealthy like that, and I still got a pretty meaty fatless cut. Yet they make up for it by jacking up the sodium levels. They probably used very  little molasses and a buttload of salt. If I wanted salty dryer cured meat, I'll eat some Boccalone cured goodness instead, thank you very much.

-got half a soy sauce chicken. They gave me a big one, which ended up almost being the size of a turkey. Never seen such a big ass chicken in my life, unless them birds have been getting their regular doses of growth or anabolic hormones.....Either that or I got the Canto deli version of a buff meathead guy at the gym dressed up as Lady Gaga. On top of that, the mofo butcher included its entire liver that was as big as my fist, which added to the weight (and co$t). Seriously, do I look like some anemic dude that needs extra vitamin A, estrogen, and iron? Bloody hell.

Get your roasties somewhere else if you can avoid it.
author: Ken K.

description:
The perfect hole-in-the-wall, cash only, no nonsense, chinese place. The people who work here are friendly and sweet. Ok get to the point.

HANDS DOWN THE BEST ROAST DUCK EVER!

Half a duck for $7??? I'm there. Thank you for being amazing.
author: Brinda J.

description:
This is the best place in SF to get roast duck and roast pork. Other places can't compare!  Their BBQ pork and free range chicken is good too.  Even their other locations can't compare! 

I love ordering their combo rice plates because the sauce and "grease" from the duck or pork soaks into the rice which makes it so yummy!   Other items here that's pretty good is the chicken porridge, fried chicken wings, and tomato beef chow fun. 

TIP: If you order the BBQ rice plates, you can skip the lines and go straight to the counter to order.  Then at that point if you want to order other items, you can squeeze in that order :)
author: Cathy M.

description: Best cheap Chinese food that tastes yummy.  Best roast duck with crispy skin and not salty.  The roast pork has crispy skin and tasty.  And there is always a line for the to go orders for the Chinese bbq.  Highly recommended!
author: May Y.

description:
Great duck - juicy and flavorful. and pretty cheap

But for those not  expecting it - duck at times may not be fully cleaned of feather lumps and also, an order of a whole duck comes with the head as well.
author: Kent T.

description:
Hands down Cheung Hing Restaurant served up the best Roast Duck I've ever had in the city!

For under six bucks, I got the Roast Duck over Rice special listed under the BBQ Rice Plate section on the menu. It was so dam good!

From Roast Pork to Duck Feet, this place offered a variety of mouth watering rice plate specials and a la carte items.

Limited seating inside available to enjoy your meal. 

Good friendly and fast service..
author: Gary E.

description: I always see a line if I'm ever passing by around 5pm....I kept promising I'd stop by and try so today I did, reading all the great reviews about the duck I thought I'd give that a try.... but as I took my place in line I was watching the guy chop the variety of protein hanging in the front, and looking at the very short list of menu choices I changed to the BBQ pork... because of the line/ language barrier I just chose the BBQ pork, I was thinking that it might come as a takeout meal but quickly realized this was just a per pound purchase. There was an even more pronounced language challenge at paying so I was too embarrassed to try to muddle my way and try to select other items.  The price was fantastic for over a pound of BBQ pork. The people behind the counter despite the language challenge were very nice..... oh and the pork, was glutonouesly fantastic.... next time I would love some noodles to put it on but truthfully I was full after just the pork... this place is Absolutely worth the line!! I will most definitely be coming back!
author: Matt W.

description:
When you go there at 11am on a Monday and you see a line full of chinese people ordering to-go... you know it's authentic.

This is totally the place to go for LEGIT chinese bbq!

My friend had the roast duck and noodles and the duck was REALLY tender, skin was crispy and the flavoring was delicious.  I had the chashu BBQ Pork plate and it was also delicious! Although they gave me a LOT of rice and the chashu itself could've been a little bit more flavorful.

But no complaints. Good price. Good food. And plus, even though we didn't speak cantonese, the lady there still gave us good service.  

Thumbs up!
author: Gloria C.

description:
Best Chinese Barbecue?  In this neck of the woods, this is the hot spot.  There's a reason why people drive out of the way for their barbecue.  Lines are out the door at times as I always wonder how the heck they keep up with demand when the going gets tough. 

Have you been here, seeing the line, thought to yourself whether to wait or not?  I have.  Peering down at my watch while not even wearing one, I shake my head and always end up waiting.  "This line is keeping me from my soy sauce chicken?!"  

Unlike Chinatown, you won't have to yell over three not so friendly four foot tall older Asian ladies that'll cut into the line like a running back; the crowd is less rowdy and there probably be only one.  Here's a little trick that may be obvious to some yet not to others.  Cheung Hing offers a range of steam table items besides their barbecue.  Most of the selection is derived from various meaty delights.  To bypass that line, go to the front where the steam table dishes are and simply order something from there.  At the same time order any of the barbecue goodies you want along with that steam table order.  This'll expedite things immensely.  Apparently, this is a "separate line" to the barbecue line.  To the naked eye, a cluster of people calling and pointing crowded around the front doesn't rub off as a line to most.     

PERSONAL FAVORITES TO ORDER FROM THE STEAM STABLE:
*Deep fried tofu - Let me see...I don't have an official record, but I swore I have eaten 25 of these bad boys in one sitting once.  I highly recommend these tofu delights, but not making eating records out of it like me.  Filled with a meat paste and served up with thick dipping sauce, these make for a good side or appetizer.  Falls under a MUST TRY outside any of the barbecue.
 
*Braised tofu with mushrooms - Seeing a theme?  I like tofu.  How can such simplicity be so good?  Deep fried tofu braised with mushrooms, some napa cabbage, and carrots.  The gravy may be overwhelming and fatty (probably zapped straight from the meat fat).  There's a simple solution.  Add an extra cup of white rice, always fixes the problem.    

All the stuff here are greasy, artery filling, heart stopping, and really delicious.  Nothing says yummy than biting into a big piece of meat intermingled with a chuck of well flavored fat.  Besides the adverse health features, having an aching for some barbeque pork or roasted duck, hop on by or better yet, jog on by.  The cardio will help what you'll intake (not really).  ENJOY!
author: Arnold T.

description:
So I decided to visit this place after reading all the great reviews. Today my belly was full. Outstanding duck and crispy pork. I found a new place to eat when going to SF. 
7 thumbs up!
author: Harold Y.

description: Years later I still come by. Cost is a bit higher as with all restaurant but same taste.
author: Gordon M.

description:
I was ok with the utter lack in ambiance at Cheung Hing.

I didn't mind that by all appearances, this is just another dingy little Chinese takeout spot.

I was fine with the short-tempered woman who used a saran-wrap covered karaoke microphone to shout orders back into the kitchen. Actually, that was kind of funny.

I was willing to put all that aside for some amazing DUCK. 

But when my friend and I ordered and proceeded to eat our entire order of a half duck, half steamed chicken (they were out of soy chicken. Boo.), and Chinese broccoli, each of which filled an entire styrofoam takeout box, we felt totally disgusting afterwards. Why did we keep on eating? We were hungry. And it's hard to resist greasy, sodium-saturated Chinese food. And let me reiterate the GREASY part. Each takeout box had at least a 1 inch thick layer of oil at the bottom. For each piece of meat/ vegetable I picked up with my chopsticks, I spent a good amount of time shaking off the oil. 

The chicken.. soft and tender but a little tiny bit on the dry side. Flavorless. You really need the ginger paste it comes with.

The duck.. tasty. But again - does it HAVE to be drenched in oil?

Chinese broccoli - can't really mess that up. Oh wait, you CAN if you drench it in a pool of oil.
author: Ziyan C.

description: So they were shut down by the Health Department and had a major cleaning.  Food still the same and the clerk handles money along with your food. And they still don't ring up the money all the time (padding the register here?) So I haven't gotten sick yet and the food is still good.  Cha sew, duck and all of that is good. Maybe the kitchen is finally clean!
author: Stefan L.

description:
My god I can't believe I actually tried this place. Four stars place??? To call this place dirty is a generous perception of the word. This place was filthy from the counter to the tables to the peoples clothes serving you the food.No corner has been left untouched by what seems to be a layer of brown dirty greasy sheath covering the entire place. To be generous the food looks like a dog threw up its dinner.  I am incredibly surprised they are open for business and passed the inspection to reopen. The roasted duck was nothing special much less to risk an illness. 
I am ashamed to have entered this place.
author: Sandra M.

description:
The boy & I were shopping @ Safeway but we just could not decide on what to make for dinner.  In the end, we said we'd just get some barbecue to bring home to eat with some rice & veggies.

We got Cuttle fish again this time but only half a pound.  We realized that while it tasted good straight from the fridge, they were better @ room temperature or even slightly warmed up.  We also got some Char siu (BBQ pork) which were too sweet & too fatty; even though I specifically asked for semi-fatty.  We got a third thing which may be weird to most people but it's something I absolutely cannot resist - Chicken gizzards/hearts cooked in herbal soy sauce.  The flavors were all there without being super salty.  The gizzards were cooked slightly crunchy which I really like.

Everything that we got gave us enough food for 2 dinner, 2 very comforting & delicious dinners.
author: Karen S.

description: The BBQ stuff are ok, a bit greasy and salty, the guys who cut the meat did not wash hands or wear gloves , and they received your money at the same time, also they were not easy to talk to, well, it's a Chinese BBQ place, what can you expect right?
author: Shan S.

description: My husband ate here earlier today. He left a tip on the table. But as he ordered food to go over the counter, the waitress asked if he left a tip. Now that's not very polite. Food here isn't even that good. Never eating here again.
author: T B.

description:
Over the weekend, my family had some party trays for my sister's baby shower.  Prior to the event's day, we ordered and paid in full for 4 items, chicken chow mein, fried rice, chicken wings and string beans.  We went to pick up the food on the exact time indicated but we were told to wait another 15 minutes.  From my observation, the original copy of the order receipt was misplaced by them (cashier or cook).  I overheard the staffs argued over the order.  Awkwardly, no words of apology or appreciation for our business at all.  
After we consumed the food, we agreed that the cook added high volume of salt to the food due to bad mood and/or rushed.  The food were too salty.  We ended up tossing the leftover food away.  The management should evaluate the cook.  This was the second incident I had with the cook.  About a month ago, the cook overcharged me while trying to work the cash register but I was glad the cashier noticed it and returned the difference.  This restaurant is going downhill.
author: Steve T.

description:
Crispy skin BBQ pork is definitely worth the trip to the sunset. One of the few 4 star places around here. Might be a little hard to communicate but worth it for the brave. Old and young alike flock to this place so you know its authentic if not better than that. 
It was about 8 bucks a lb for the pork. More for the duck. Get half and be on your merry way. Every time I've gotten it I gobble it up in the car cause the smell will force you to eat it before you make it home.
author: Augusto M.

description:
Everything purchased was really, really authentic... 

those roast meats just dangling-- all glistening-- in the window... someone, strap me down! I have never seen anything so tempting.

Dad manned the unmetered car, Mom inquired about the downhome dirties, like vinegar-braised pig's feet with soysauce eggs and some innards.. I wasn't going to get distracted.... too busy watching 2 SFFD guys order up a storm of roasted medley with a whole lotta rice!

Some BBQ cha siew pork and some siew ngap roasted duck, and Mom's homestyle boxes (can't do it.... maybe a taste here and there, but my ABC palate sort of revolts).

Incredible stuff.... can't believe I've only been here for the first time only last week. 

Right when I was praising them for all of their stuff, a fresh, fresh pan of yeurng deow foo/ stuffed tofu with minced pork comes out, steamin' hot...

omg... get me OUTA HERE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! too much temptation flying everywhere. I would highly, highly recommend anyone who is craving some hang-in-the-window-meat-hooks varietals to make a pit stop here. 

It's all mind-numbing how small, but how popular, this place is....and how endless the food flies.
PS This joint is only a 'restaurant' inasfar as there are a few stodgy tables about, and they do serve wonton and the like. But most ostensibly, consider this a take-out Chinese deli!
author: Jana C.

description:
Cheap. Delicious. Well worth the wait in line.

I've rarely come where there wasn't a wait outside Cheung Hing to get inside. You know it has a good reputation when people are willing to wait for a few minutes to order.

The roast pork is pretty amazing. The won ton noodle soup is also not bad, for the price mind you.

It is worth the trip out there to try it out if you haven't. I love the whole certificates on the wall claiming it's a Top 100 Chinese Restaurant. Kind of funny to see that.

I assume everything they have here is really good. Sure, it can be really oily, but they are one of the best quick Chinese food restaurans in SF.

It's well worth eating in as well.
author: Alex T.

description: Classic hole-in-the-wall Chinese place in the Sunset with the best roast duck I've had in ages. Rest of the "typical Chinese food" was good enough. Super take-out.
author: Kathy A.

description:
ROAST DUCK! and BBQ Pork!

that is all! it always smells sooo good when close by. *droool*

they can understand a bit of english, and my chinglish, so its all goooood.

sometimes the guy gives me a really good duck, not a lot of fat..and sometimes...theres barely any meat and all fat! bleh.

but still the best duck I think!
author: Christine M.

description:
After having too much to drink, what else is the best cure but oily roast and bbq pork with plain white rice, right??
Anyway having read all the great yelp reviews about their bbq and roast pork , I decided to stop by and check out this place and boy I was SO GRATEFUL that I did.
The skin of the roast pork was so crispy it was purrffect and it definitely hit the SPOT!!!
If you are not lining up for the meat hanging outside the window and you look like a lost girl like me wondering what to order, skip the line, go inside and the ladies will help you. They were very nice to me and my order was placed fast.  There was so much food for just under $8. 
Don't forget to BRING CASH.. Luckily I called first because none of the YELP reviews mentioned that it was CASH only but then again, what do you expect from authentic Asian places like this.
Cheung Hing... you are my to go CHINESE place . I will see you again VERY soon. Thanks for the cure!!!
author: Claudine V.

description: Hole-in-the-wall. Duck and pork were great. Chicken feet also great. We were visiting from Sacramento. 4 of us (2 Chinese, 2 white) sat for lunch. The waitress was friendly and helpful, speaking perfect English. Cash only. It was all wonderful and reasonably priced, and we'll be back. Both dine-in and take-out seem good.
author: Geoffrey H.

description:
Duck: 4.5 stars
BBQ Pork Char Siu: 4 stars

Got duck hor fun soup and bbq pork hor fun soup. Love the meat here  - really reminds me of authentic Chinese butcher places. Always a line! Too bad it's so far away - wish there was one in Southbay
author: Jamie T.

description:
3.5 Stars. They are definitely better than average.
I enjoyed their roast duck:plump, juicy, sweet fatty.
You got to get a fat duck vs. a skinny duck.

Dining in is not an adventure. It's dirty, unpleasantly noisy, and cramp.
The forte is definitely "Take Out".

They should get rid of those tables and make their "Take Out" line more spacious and efficient. They could cut back on maintaining dining ware and dishwashing and


JUST FOCUS ON PUMPING OUT THEM FAT JUICY DUCKS !!!
author: Winston W.

description: This place never disappoints.  All the BBQ items are delicious.  Yes they are fatty, but exactly what you would expect.  Because they are so busy all the meats turn over quickly and don't sit on the window very much.  I usually get duck over rice, roast pork with the crispy skin is totally great, BBQ pork is tender.  The ribs are pretty good.  I like tongue, but the other parts are too advanced for me.  Did not try too many dishes on their non BBW menu, but they have a very large menu of those.  Servers are nice, although limited English.  But that's just very cute.  Come all the way from Marin sometimes when get the urge for the BBQ.  They do close early by 8:30 starting to wrap up.
author: Mary G.

description:
This place is seriously underrated in terms of Chinese Food in San Francisco. I would have to say that this place has the best roast duck, roast pork, BBQ, pork, and everything else in this city. I can't even begin to say how delicious everything has been from this place. I'm not sure what they're called but those over-sized meatballs that they sell here are so delicious. I haven't really come here to eat any of their rice plates but I'm sure those are good too. 

I always come here for half a roast duck, a pound of BBQ pork, and one big meatball. Then, I go home and make myself some steamed rice and I have myself one delicious meal! There is always a line outside the door to wait for the guy to chop up your meats for your but it's totally worth the wait.

I'm not Chinese and I don't speak Cantonese so ordering can sometimes be frustrating as the guy behind the counter does try very hard to understand you with a smile but hes not always the most successful. Luckily, there usually someone in line who can help you out with the translation. Either way, don't let the language barrier stop you. Usually pointing and holding up fingers and nodding will suffice to get your order completed. 

Also, bring cash. They don't accept cards.
author: Rylan C.

description: Absolutely delicious roast duck and roast pork. If you can look over the restaurant condition, their food is delicious and has the right portion. I suggest to take food to go during the dinner time but if you can't you just have to endure the staring of many people waiting in lines to order take outs while dining.
author: Jesse Y.

description: dang i know this place got shut down for rats, but the roast duck is just so juicy and tasty here! great prices too!!!
author: Jason C.

description:
Roast duck and BBQ pork were pretty good.

Chinese brocolli with oyster sauce was overcoked, not fresh, and had too much oyster sauce.
author: Edmond C.

description:
I'd give this place less stars if they did not have good poultry on certain days. My family usually comes here to order duck, chicken and roast pork for Lunar New Year and the meat they have at the window are sometimes good and sometimes regretful.

I grew up coming here since I use to live in Sunset. Now that I don't live in Sunset, I get mt Chinese poultry elsewhere. But anyways, I notice the service here is typically Chinese. Yeah I said it because I grew up around Chinese people and being one myself. The butcher would ask my mother which bird or meat she wants. My mom would pick the most suitable one and the butcher would tell her that he recommends a "better one" which is obviously the crappy one. When the customer tells you that they want that one, just give them what they are paying for! sheeesh.  So be careful of recommendations from the butchers who work there.

I RECOMMEND people to come here and just order a whole bird or whatever. Buy the meat especially in the noon time, because by night it gets old. 

Definitely don't eat here at night because they feed you left overs. Recently my friends and I were craving duck so we sat in and they served us crappy old duck with leftover vegetables.... It was so nasty and the duck was super greasy and fat. So I asked myself, "what are they feeding me?" Again... don't eat here at night because that's when they wanna get rid of the leftovers.

This place use to be so much better and they had potential. It's too bad they fell this low throughout the years. It's a hit or miss now. In conclusion don't sit in and eat, buy the meat earlier in the day and bring it home.
author: Victor Q.

description:
Although there's always a line, this place was our go-to spot for an easy and filling dinner. It's a treat to bring a whole roast duck home for dinner. But the last few times we've noticed something was different. We let the last time slide because it may have been a mistake, but today confirms it. 

They sell most items by the pound, but ducks are only sold by half duck or whole duck. We bought a whole one tonight, and usually it's filled until the to-go box is unclosable. Today, we've noticed that the box closed and was kind of flat. When asked why the person before us had an unclosable box, both of the cashier ladies simultaneously responded that our duck was more lean and healthy. Fine...we also bought some half a chicken, roast pork, BBQ pork, and some of the prepared food items. Comes out to $60. We go home, excited about the duck, open the box only to find a duck head and bill, pieces of neck, and a bunch of skin and bones....the fu.....? No juicy breast pieces to be seen anywhere! Nowhere! When complaining about this issue with another patron, they had the same problem before and suspect that they keep those pieces for their rice plates that they sell. Those dirty crooked thieves! Ruined our dinner tonight. 

We shall not return to your long lines and lies!
author: kim w.

description: This place is a local neighborhood Chinese deli. It has a great assortment of meats and side dishes too. I would definitely recommend the roast duck or barbecued pork (siu ap and cha siu). If you want to order a rice plate, you can head to the back and avoid the lines for the deli.
author: Brian C.

description: Greasy but good, better than Chinatown.  Always people in line, but moves quick.  New stuff comes out and meat is tender,  a little fatty, but roasted and seasoned nicely.  If you don't  speak Chinese, just point and say 1/2 pound.  This guy was chopping  the meats up and not complaining if the customers made small orders. Try the stuff a la carte.  Then return again and buy and eat again.
author: Rey D.

description: Unsure why I haven't rated this yet, but this is my go-to spot for roast duck. It's absolutely delicious! The roast duck here has juicy, succulent meat without being too fatty or salty.
author: Gabriel C.

description:
It is the place where I very first  time tried a roast duck! They say you will never forget your first love. It is not about me - I can't clearly remember who was my first love, but I will never forget the first bite of the heavenly tender, juicy flavorful piece of the roast duck in my mouth. Wow! What a discovery! 
This place is better for pick up (always line that make this little place overcrowded) but my husband and I like to get our duck  immediately, right there,  have no patience to wait. By the way my husband is Chinese guy raised in SF when he brought me here said this is the best roast duck in the city. Don't have any reason to doubt!
author: Anna T.

description: They have good Chinese BBQ but if you are not paying attention they are liable to give you old food. You really have to be assertive every time. The gap-toothed owner/chopper is the worst. I had to throw away $6 of BBQ pork today because it tasted funny and the $14 duck was very salty and was coated with a wax like stuff (I was told it was sugar). I will come back but I will be like "No, not that one, this one, chop chop." Sadly, this is the only kind of language these people understand.
author: YM L.

description:
They start cheating now!!!

Be careful!!!

I always go there before because it was good.  

But this afternoon I went there with my wife had a lunch and something to go. The server asked me how much meat to go.  I said 1 pound.  It came out with the package "1.1 pound".  I tasted a bit and went home.  When I put the package including the box and the bag on the weight it comes out 13 ounces!
Unbelievable.

I don't know how they can survive with this cheating technology. I feel sorry for them.

And I drove 15 miles back to them, they didn't say sorry or anything.  Instead they were acting like I was take advantage of them.  
I got my money back, but no one pay my gas for that 30 miles round trip.

They are Chinese, may be that's why. I wish our Chinese people can be more professional or at least more ethical in the future.
author: Johnson X.

description: Most definitely one of the better stops for quality Chinese BBQ.  My family's picked up take-out here on a number of occasions over the years and the roast duck in particular is top notch.
author: Eric F.

description:
As they say, the dirtier, the tastier.  Got myself a whole duck and some banana leaf wrapped sticky rice (which are not so tasty at the end of the day).

My left arm started to get numb from all that duck - it was good while it lasted. (:
author: David A.

description: Yuck! After leaving my BBQ pork in the fridge for a couple of days, the BBQ pork was growing mold!!!
author: Derek S.

description: Little hole in the wall place supposedly having really good roast duck. The duck I got was pretty anorexic with no meat, just very fatty. The duck was ridiculously salty even with rice.
author: Julie C.

description:
been coming here for as long as they have been open. i don't live in the sunset anymore but as time and travels allow i eat the food here-roast pork. duck. sticky rice. soup. 

fatty and EXCELLENT!
author: Mr G.

description: Their glutinous rice is no good. It could be the timing, was there in the evening after work and ate there.
author: Ris N.

description:
This is my go-to destination for all things Chinese BBQ. The rice plates are reasonably priced and the food is delicious. There has never been a time where I have seen the take-out line not have at least 3 people waiting to place their orders.

I have had almost everything on the menu. For any first timer, I would recommend getting a combination rice plate of roast duck and BBQ pork.
author: Jesson d.

description:
DUCK DUCK goose!!

When you're too lazy to cook turkey, order takeout from them.

Duck tongue.

Duck.

You get the gist.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
Buyer beware!!!  Went to buy roast duck, white chicken, Cha Sui yesterday for Chinese New Year. Of course there was a long line but we finally were able to wind our way through to order. Unfortunately because it was so busy our order was chopped by a thin gentleman in the back rather than the usual chopper in front. When we got home and opened the white boxes to heat up the duck and chicken we were shocked to see that all of the nice breast pieces of duck and chicken were not there. Our suspicion is that there was some quick moves by our meat chopper working in the back to save the choice pieces for later. 

So keep a close eye on the man with the cleaver or be prepared to inspect your order before leaving.
author: Gary L.

description: As good as it gets to for the pork and duck that you put on rice... Granted, I'm usually not a fan because I have pretty american taste in food.. I don't like anything that looks remotely dirty lol.. This place was surprisingly tolerable... Pork skin was crispy and meat was juicy... While I'm normally more of a duck person, I preferred the roast pork. It you're in the sunset, check it out!
author: James H.

description: Their food is good overall.  Their roast pork is the best compare to other bbq meat they r selling.  The reason I give them 2 stars cause the whole staff just let someone cut in the line that people been waiting for over 23 mins.  Yes I been looking at my watch cause I fed the meter for 35 mins.  After waiting for over 20 mins when it's only one person ahead of me, then this 50-60 yrs old woman walked in and say happy Chinese New Year to the whole team especially the female owner.  Then ordered whole duck, BBQ pork......... For to go.  I could not believe she could act so comfortable cut in a line of 15 plus people behind her.  Oh to refresh their memory, everyone call that woman "dai gar Jie". Well, you don't really need any enemy if you have few more of this kind of dai gar Jie.  Cause just the matter of the time, your business will be gone.  Will I go back again, no thank you!  Been going to Lum wor shiu for many many times, their food is good their line is even longer, but guess what, never have anyone cut in front of me.
author: Red Bean B.

description:
One day, while randomly, but insistently, craving duck, I found this place on Yelp. It's definitely not a fine dining experience, in fact, it's very misleading when you pass by the place and see a short line out the door. This is more of a take out type of joint. If you want to sit in, DON'T STAND IN LINE. Walk right in and take a seat. However, like most of the people that go here, you might just wanna take out because in door seating is sort of unappealing.

I ordered a half duck with rice ($9.75), without rice I think is about $2 cheaper & it was damn good. The duck skin was nice and crisp, oily like duck should be, and the meat was a good degree of salty. It went really well over rice & half a duck is quite the meal. It is actually probably good for 2-3 people. 

Yummy yummy duck. Definitely would be my go-to place for roast duck in the Sunset!
author: Junel S.

description:
One of the best Chinese BBQ places in SF. Kind of hidden since its stashed in the heart of Sunset, but the food here is f****** bomb. You can snag a BBQ pork rice dish for under $6 and the portions are so generous there will be enough for a second meal - and this is coming from a giant 6"2' 200lb food connoisseur. Their BBQ pork, soy sauce chicken, and roast duck are great as well - you really can't go wrong with any of these items.

This is gonna be one of the few reviews where I'm just gonna keep it short and sweet -  you just HAVE to try it.
author: Felix C.

description: Ordered  and chowed down half a duck, roasted pork (ribs section), and Yang Chow fried rice with a good friend. It is heavenly.
author: Honest E.

description:
1. Stand in line and decide what you're going to order by staring at all the poultry hanging at the window.

2. Right when you take a step into the doorway, tell the butcher what you want and the amount, i.e. half a duck, whole chicken, 1 lb of fatty chinese bbq pork.  Sliced or chopped?

3. Watch him cut all the meat in 5 quick chops.

4. Pay the woman and leave.

I LOVE the boiled chicken that comes with the ginger sauce.  Chinese people line up for their bbq pork and I must admit that I can eat the sliced pieces of pork like potato chips.  Meat is always fresh and warm.  I can't stay away from Cheung Hing.  They need to put a restraining order on me before I spend all my money.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
aww yeahhhh roast duck come to mama!

Sure the roast duck is greasy, but hey- that's why duck confit is so yummy right?! it's all the duck fat that gives it the flavor. 

The only tricky thing about this place is that you really need to know some chinese if you want something very specific- I embarrassed myself by getting a brain fart on the fried tofu balls [pay phai too-fu]. But then again, I guess if you don't care for anything specific you can just look and point. Most of their food can be seen a glass panel and some of the items are also on the menu - I couldn't find the darn too-fu balls though &ended up with something else.  

So far I've tried their salted cabbage [choy], their roast duck [haau-aap], their bbq pork [shui mai], the fried tofu ball [pay phai too-fu], and the tofu with fish [yew too-fu]. 

They weigh each item behind the glass display (except for the duck) and you pay by weight- it's about $4 per 1/4 lb. 

The duck is most expensive if you get a 1/4 cut ($6) and least expensive ($15) if you get the entire thing- I would recommend that you bring all your homies &share that duck - or just get ready for a ton of left over duck
author: Lucia C.

description: Apparently this place has opened up again! I'm not sure if the owners remain the same but maybe they cleaned up the place and meet the health department standards now.... I'm just going to keep my old rating for this place but I don't have intentions of trying it or even eating the stuff other people buy from here.
author: Denise L.

description:
I'm a white kid from Wine Country, so my experience with "Chinese food" is very American. I'd read here that this place serves actual, authentic Chinese food. I figure I might as well drop by and give it a shot, especially since it's only a few blocks from my friend's house in the Sunset.

The food was delicious. The BBQ pork was tender and sweet but not overwhelmingly so. The rice was cooked just right and the veggies were a good contrast to offset the heaviness of the meat. I took my order back to the house and put just enough sri racha on it. I was so very satisfied.

Maybe I was tired, but I had a hard time understanding the people behind the counter. I'll cut them a little slack, though, since English is obviously not their first language, and I managed to order my food anyways.

Overall, a positive experience. I'm definitely going back to try other dishes.
author: Patrick P.

description:
SHUT DOWN BY THE HEALTH DEPARTMENT!!!
And from what other folks have told me, its not the first time. 
Went there yesterday, and the big SF Health Dept Notice was on the door since the day before...8/6/13.
Our goto place for good Duck, Pig and Char-Siu...but now,  sadly not. And...being warned now, most likely a place I'll be avoiding. 
Too bad. I knew the owner's dad when it first started years ago before their fire.
Good flavors, but don't want to risk my health for that!
author: Art Y.

description:
My parents have taken me and bought food from Cheung Hing since I was a kid. I am now 21.

Now that I'm away from college down south in Irvine, when I go home I HAVE to go back to Chueng Hing.

This is probably my most favorite chinese restaurant that I've been to. I don't even think it would be possible to make any of these dishes at home. Well, I'm sure it is, but maybe not as delicious.

The food platters are delicious. My favorites are:
Beef and Scrambled Eggs over rice
Yook see jeen mein... it might be called shanghai style noodles.
The Yang Chou House Fried Rice is delicious.

The bbq foods are some of the best I know. Duck, pig, pork. SO GOOD.

The porridge is also amazing.

I don't think you can go wrong with any dish.

Honestly, one of the best chinese restuarants I know.
The workers have been working there ever since I've been there.

Though the place is a little dirty, the good food offsets that. But honestly, just take out if you like, it still tastes just as good.
You can even call in!

Note: I don't think the other Cheung Hing in Milbrae compares up to this one. Everything just tastes better at this one.
author: Andrew N.

description:
The place is small and looks abit low~no maintance. price is about 20% more expensive than other Chinese restaurant. I ordered a half, roasted-duck, and they charged me $0.50 cent for the sour source which always comes with the duck with no charge at other restaurant. BUT the quality and taste of the food there is obviously better than most Chinese restaurant I've been to in San Francisco.  
Will I return? ... Yes.
Will I return all the time? No.
author: Joe M.

description: Many friends recommended the pork BBQ Here. I finally had a chance to give it a try. Right after I sat down, I started to struggle. The floor was greasy, the table felt sticky. Finally I decided to stay. The food here did taste good. But when I went to the restroom, oh my, what a terrible smell. It was 'old grease' coming from the kitchen next to the restroom. I wondered how could this place open to serve people food. This was the worst food facility I've seen in SF. They should hire some professional cleaner.
author: V L.

description: A small hole in the wall with 5 small tables in Noriega location. Most people take out the roast duck, roast pork, roast chicken, and etc. The roast duck take out is very tasty every time we come here. Most take out food is excellent but meter parking ($2/hour with meter person coming around frequently) is very difficult in this small neighborhood locale. This restaurant's line is out the door during lunch time even for take out. Off the beaten path; however good for take out or for picnic out by park or beach.
author: Clifford W.

description:
I love Chinese food. Americanized, upscale, PF Chang's fusion fake Chinese, Panda  Express... pretty much anything goes.

This place... I would call it an authentic Chinese experience.

It's cheap. Under $6 for Chow Fun? That's hard to beat (my standard dish I judge all Chinese restaurants on). BBQ hanging in the window? Of course. The duck is really good... a lot of fat and it's really greasy, but damn, it's good. 

You can order pre-made food cafeteria style. You can also get made-to-order food from their fairly extensive menu. Everything (at least entrees) is under $10, and a lot are under 8. Half a duck sets you back over 10 I think. The serving sizes are huge though. I mean, I eat a lot, but if it's supposed to be 1 dish a person, they put me to shame

Sure, it's kinda dirty... but you get free tea if you eat in! Or you just order it takeout and pretend like you didn't see the grease all around you...

Or you can be like me, and be happy when you how much of a dive it is (ie. dirty)--when there's still a long line and it looks like this... you know it's good. Like I said: authentic Chinese experience.
author: Justin E.

description:
Best  BBQ pork/chicken and roast duck in the Sunset/Noriega Street. Everyday around lunch time there is always a long line out the door to get box lunches. I usually get BBQ pork and rice (sliced bbq port and sweet sauce over a bed of rice) Yum! 
I've ordered other dishes and never had a complaint. Excellent!
author: Len L.

description: Best window-hanging meat in SF! Roast pork with the crunchy skin, sweet barbeque pork shining and dripping in its glazened glory. The duck is succulent and has a crispy skin. Tip: if you're ordering rice plates and what not, you can cut the whole line and order with one of the ladies!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Best Chinese BBQ place hands down. There's always a line outside around dinner time from everyone waiting to buy goodies to bring home. 

Their roast duck , bbq pork and squid are delicious! But when getting squid let them know you want the body and not the tentacles... Or else they'll give you some of both. 

A little trick you can do to get your items faster is to order one of their pre-made dishes ( I highly recommend their fried tofu triangles or their tofu that's shaped like a ball) then when you're done, they'll ask if you want  BBQ item as well!
author: Jess s.

description:
Since my last review I've been back to Cheung Hing 3 times and have to say their service has been less than stellar on 2 occasions. 

1) Feb09 Sat afternoon, I called in advance ordered [1 roast duck, 1 soy sauce chicken, 2 lbs of bbq pork, 2 lbs of roast pork, and 1 order of string beans. I was told 20 minutes. I arrived with 30 minutes and had to wait 20 more minutes as they help customers in line.  I had to ask them 3 times where's my order.  The owner mouthed-off and said can't you see we are very busy, you're not our only customer. No sorry 's :(

2) Mar09 Fri after-work 6:30pm. No lines, got the same boss lady, she remembered me.  Got a bit of attitude from her.  She was being her bossy self.  Business looks slow & price$ have gone UP.   Oh!  State Board of Equalization Cheung Hing does not always ring up every transaction - it's a cash business (an audit is due!)

I don't care how good your bbq is, I'm looking for a new bbq place. Goodbye Cheung Hing!
author: Rich W.

description:
just went there to pickup a half soy sauce chicken and a few other things for lunch.  Normally their food will rate four stars.  The reason i gave them one star is their F UC ked up service.  The guy that cut the chicken up just pour the sauce right into the box instead of their usual plastic sauce container.  You guess it.  When i go back, the sauce leaked all over my car and carpet.  What was this guy thinking pouring sauce directly into the box. When i call the place back up, the person that answer tries not to understand english or difficult to communicate.  come on.  without customer service or messed up customer service like this will not work either.  

Train your workers properly to serve the public and do not try to disavow knowledge of it.  There are many other businesses around you.  do this a few more times word will get around and guess what...  less business,  cutting corners and pissing off loyal customers may lead to customers taking their business elsewhere.  just remember without customers there is no business. Without a business you are back in the unemployment line.
author: brian l.

description: Cheap Chinese comfort food! When my husband and I need a cheap and quick meal, this is one of our take out choices. Please note I did not include the word "healthy". We usually get minced beef with egg on rice, beef with scrambled egg over rice, gailan, or beef chow fun and we have gotten the wonton noodle soup (ok) and the salt and pepper squid (which I would pass on in the future). Oh and we did have the duck once which was the greasiest duck I've ever had - just don't eat it every night and you're golden.
author: Lisa H.

description:
3.5 Star rating

Service:  Now, take things with a grain of salt, as my friend who is fluent in cantonese ordered everything for us.  The service here was pretty top notch.  When the lady said they had little char siu left, she offered us some roast pork as well for no charge!

Quality:  I came here pretty close to closing but the roast duck we got was really oily and not to mention COLD!  Everything we ordered was waaaay too greasy for me.  Felt like I was gonna break out!

Price:  This is probably the main draw.  Food here is dirt cheap.  Whole duck for $16?!! I'll take two for myself next time!

I really want to try this place again but not at around closing.  I hope that the next time I go, I can edit my review and bump up the rating to at least 4 stars.

EDIT 12/2012:

Having retried this place recently I've got to say wowwwwwwwww!!!!!!! Man coming at a busy hour sure made a huge difference!  Quality of the meat was top notch.  Piping hot meats that I couldn't resist waiting to get home for so I just ate them in the car.  One must get the Roast Pork; by far the best I've ever had!   I'll give this place a 4.5 star rating now.  Honestly if I were to had this great experience from the start it would surely get a 5-star rating.
author: Anthony I.

description:
I guess this place has fallen off the radar last time I been here as being a good place.

It's now just, okay in my opinion. Gone are the days of around the block lines all day. It does perhaps get busy at times, but I remember this place cracking from open to close!
author: Doug R.

description:
Oh how I love roast duck!  

I don't know why it took me so long to come back here, but OMG, I'm so glad I did!  I was craving some roast duck, so I made my way down Noriega to Cheung Hing.  Doh!  I forgot they only have metered parking around there, and I forgot to bring change.  I parked anyway and ran inside....the roast duck is worth a parking ticket!!!

I ordered roast duck over rice( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/KGtbsfOCrfEhklnp219muA/l ).  Their sauteed green beans also looked really good, so I asked for an order.  I thought it would come in a small togo container, but little did I know....it was a FULL order( http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/TFKUzH_H9ZUrcdh7maZyHQ/l )!!!  

I got home and devoured the roast duck.  It was soooooooo good.  Cooked to perfection with all the right seasonings!  The duck skin was crispy and oh so good!  Nom nom nom!!!  The green beans were delicious, too....nice and crunchy!

Lots of food at a good price!  I'll have to go back for some roast pork...yummmm!
author: Patra I.

description:
They always have the best cha-siu (bbq pork) and duck. I always come here to get my fix. This place was one of my most missed places when I went to school in Irvine. Their places were just not as good, and they tricked me once when I wasn't looking and gave me a bad piece of cha siu, not "half fat half skinny" like I asked for.

This place is legit and they always help you out. And trust me, make sure you don't get cut by those old Chinese ladies who PRETEND they don't know English. I know I look like an ABC but I can speak Canto just fine and have no problem yellin them back into their proper spot in line
author: Wilson T.

description:
I come here for the BBQ. The roast duck is bomb! I just bought one yesterday actually... I was the only customer out of the 8 inside that DID NOT order in Chinese and I feel like they were a bit colder to me... Anyways get the roast duck, a whole one for 13.95 with tax and you have a meal for four :)

Yes the place is dingy, dirty, small, with whack parking but it's poppin and if everyone is speaking chinese at a chinese shop, then you know it's authentic, good, and well priced!
author: Linda N.

description: Great roasted duck at reasonable prices. Have to try the chicken next.
author: Frank B.

description: I would buy my BBQ pork at this place always a good neighborhood gem.  Quick simple, and consistence in the food quality.  It has that hole in the wall feeling but without the holes in the wall.
author: Philip W.

description: Lived in the sunset for one year and started coming here. That was 20 years ago when I lived in the sunset. Cheap, Chinatown style food where they have roast duck and chicken hanging in the window. Good, cheap, reliable food. Will continue going to this place whenever I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Dixiee N.

description: Was in The City around lunchtime, so I Yelped a restaurant close to me.  This place was literally down the street and around the corner.  Read the review of the won ton soup with roast duck.  I love won ton soup, and I love roast duck.  This place serves them together.  Oh, this I HAVE to try!  Sure enough, they bring a big bowl of won ton soup from the back, then slice a 1/4 section of duck and put it right in the bowl.  Oh my WORD is this stuff good.  I completely echo what the other reviewer said about this dish.  The soup does not overpower the duck, and the duck doesn't overpower the soup.  They actually compliment one another to create deep, rich full bodied flavors that I simply have never had together. Oh, and all of that plus a side of chicken wings was only $15 with tip. Great food at a value price too?  Can't wait to get back to San Francisco and this wonderful little hole in the wall restaurant.
author: Orlando G.

description: Awesome Chinese BBQ, especially the ROAST DUCK.  A small hole in the wall.  There's always a line of people waiting for the duck.  One thing though, they need a numbering system.  The last time I was here, a small mini-riot broke out over the duck, they ran out and about 20 people waited for a round of ducks from the rosaster to come out, when it did, there was MASS confusion! I got mine, but it wasn't easy..luckily the old BBQ man recognized and remembered me as BEING NEXT.  Had no idea what they were yelling in Cantonese, but I definately wasn't getting any compliments from the old chinese ladies behind me.
author: Demanding T.

description: BEST CHAR SUI (BBQ POrk)  I EVER HAD!!!!  The meat was soo tender and price reasonable.  They cut it up for you right there and there's always a line.  Now I know why!  Next time friends or family are in town or I'm hosting, I will definitely be coming here and grabbing at least a pounds worth of this delicious meat!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Long line for roast duck ($14.95 for a whole) and it was tasty but super fatty.  So much fat under the skin and the whole thing was in a box swimming in fatty gravy.  Little ducky had feathers stuck still in it too.  eeeek
author: Alias A.

description: I dig their fresh roast duck. It is so juicy and mouth watering every time I take a bite. Cheers!
author: Gina Y.

description:
I've seen lines here day and night.  It's a chaotic, confusing Chinese deli with lots of yelling (in Cantonese) and chopping sounds.  I felt like having duck for lunch one Sunday morning so I joined the queue and the guy in front of me bought the last two ducks; 12:15 PM and they're already sold out of duck!  

There wasn't a menu in sight but the deli meats were listed overhead (duck feet, duck wings, duck tongues, chicken, BBQ pork, pork ears, pork stomach) and I asked for roast pork over rice.  What a fabulous, simple meal.  The roast pork is lean and flavorful and the skin is extremely crispy and tastes of five spice powder.  There is a thick layer of fat between the meat and the skin though, but it needs to be there to keep the meat moist while making the skin extra crispy.  They provide plenty of white rice to soak up the flavors along with mildly crunchy boiled cabbage, under $7.  

Okay, I bought the roast pork again and received much fattier pieces.  I definitely recommend getting the meat over rice to offset the saltiness and soak up the juices.  

After I ordered, I saw the menu was taped up and they also have copies for the people who dine in.  There are a few tables on the side and a fairly long menu that includes congee (I have to try the congee).  The service is brusque and efficient.  But it's still confusing unless you understand Cantonese.  Cash only.

March 2008 update:  I was ready to award another star if their congee impressed me.  It's staying at four stars because the congee is good but watery.  I had the roast duck congee.  They add chopped roast duck at the very end.  The congee was lukewarm and I had to expend much effort separating the meat from the bones.  When I eat congee, I don't even want to chew - it needs to be as easy as possible because it's comfort food.  They should add more ginger and scallions too.  On the positive side, they give you lots of duck and the duck is extremely flavorful.  For 50 cents you can add preserved egg to any congee and they use good preserved eggs.  

The dine-in menu is actually pretty lengthy and includes rice plates, won ton soup, noodle soups, braised noodles, fried rice, chow fun, BBQ rice plates, and seafood, chicken and pork, veggie dishes.  I spotted a spicy pork blood dish that I'd like to try.
author: Lolia S.

description:
The place for absolutely the best roasted duck in the city!  I also haven't tried a place that prepares Chinese style BBQ pork better than Cheung Hing either.  If you're to ask people in the Chinese community where to go for the best Hong Kong BBQ, I bet you they'll tell you to come here.  

My favorite was their five spice chicken.  $5 used to get me a half cut of chicken or duck.  I was pleased to learn that, five years later during a recent visit, the price has now gone up by only a dollar.  It is still an incredibly great deal.  

Places like Cheung Hing made it possible for me to eat out for dinner every other night in SF.  

The lines get long during lunch and dinner time, so come early to get your cut of meat and then I'd recommend you leave.  You don't want to dine in unless you're okay with a crowd of people staring at you eat or could tolerate the sticky table tops and chairs.  There's only like six tables in this tiny restaurant.  Besides, there's nothing like seeing your bird or pig taken off the hook and chopped up in pieces just for you while you're standing in line.
author: Andrew K.

description: My mommy loves this place. Bought to go stuff home such as the roasted duck. Today we had lunch there. Sis got the duck with lai fun noodles soup. Mom ordered half chicken & roast pork while I got the chicken wings. I like ABC's salt pepper wings more cause it's a bit spicy & hot.
author: Amy C.

description:
This place has the best Chinese BBQ, at the best prices....I love their roast duck and the roast pig over rice, so goooodddd...making my mouth water now.....yummy is all I can say.  We ordered a plate of veggies, wasn't all that, could have done better myself......But back to their duck, delicious, a little too fatty sometimes so you gotta scrape it off with the fork or spoon in order to get some crunchniness with the rice.  I usually order the duck wings in the front, hecka cheap, but way too much hair on them, I spend more time pulling hairs off than eating it itself.   

A couple of times, we ordered take out cause it is just too busy there and we head on to the beach at the end on Geary and just park on the top parking lot, looking over the view with our cooler in the trunk, filled with ice and drinks has made it a perfect day.......
author: Leslie Y.

description: I usually come here for the roast duck and roast pork. The roast duck is flavorful although greasy. The roast pork skin is crunchy.
author: L Y.

description:
I've only had the duck, but its so juicy, and so crunchy. Five stars for duck (but over four because I've only had the duck), it's Quacktastic!!

Also I dont eat there, always get to go, very bad service. could tell they didn't want to serve me, and they didn't want to give me water. 

But that Peking duck is the best I've had in the city.
author: Isiah B.

description:
Still good, still dirty as can be, but damn good!!!! Oh my goodness so good! The bbq duck was so good, I would say be aggressive and pick out the duck you want. Don't be afraid of saying, "no, I don't want that one, and I want that one." They look at you with disgust, but hey at least you'll get the better duck!! trust me, you'll be thanking me if you choose your own duck. As for the hot items, the fried chicken and garlic green beans are the winners :)

This review is based on the fact that I went running over golden gate bridge and was craving something greasy :) TOTALLY WORTH THE RUN!!!
author: Nina M.

description:
This Chinese restaurant didn't live up to the hype that yelp gave it. For me, it was just meh. My friend also thought the same. I ordered the bbq pork and she had the roast duck. The duck wasn't as yummy as people had written it out to be on yelp, but that's just my opinion. We also ordered the dumpling won ton soup which I liked but she thought was just alright. 

Our service was great. Although there we were a little lost in translation , the lady that served us was super sweet, bubbly and tended to our every need. She reminded me of my mother haha.
author: Denny P.

description:
I'm probably ruing my keyboard by filling it with plum sauce, because I couldn't wait to write a review of this place. 

My man and I have never been away from home on Thanksgiving, and unfortunately for us, our new stove is WAY too tiny to make a turkey. Enter Cheung Hing. 

They have a window full of amazing roasted animals for your eating pleasure, but in the spirit of a Christmas Story, we went for the duck.

I don't even know what to say. The skin was amazing. The meat fell off the bone. I would BATHE in the juice. And the plum sauce adds just a touch of sweet. 

We have a new holiday tradition. They'll be seeing a lot of us. It's worth the drive, trust me.
author: Lindsay J.

description:
I didn't realize until now that, after so many reviews, this is one place I never wrote one for. So hear goes.

As the Yelp main primary photo suggests, the highlight here is the Chinese BBQ here. Often in the daytime there's a line of people ordering food for takeout.  There are a few dining tables but the space is small.

I assume most people come here for the roast duck, which I occasional, having a rice plate here. My bigger preference here, though, is their cuttlefish over rice. This is the one place I know in the City where I can order it. Yum!

I'm pretty certain this is the original location there's also one in Millbrae. It's run by the same family and it's bigger with a wider dine-in menu. It also appears they're about to open one in South SF on Grand Ave.
author: H K.

description:
Wifey took Matt to this popular Noriega Chinese Deli to pickup some dinner. Although Matt came here a few times many years ago, this deli was wifey's favorite spot when she briefly lived in the Sunset after being allocated from Hong Kong.

We were here, because we were too lazy to cook. We bought assorted hot-food takeout items. Among the items we got was the popular Roast-duck which cost nearly $9.00. Also we bought two long strips of Barbecue Pork which cost $7.50 for both strip. Eventhough both items were oily and greasy, it was very fresh and tasty, as oppose to some of the Barbecue Pork and ducks from Chinatown, they're don't dry out and stay moist after a stay overnight in the refridgerator. Two long strip of Barbecue pork seems a lot, but it can be your lunch item at work for the next few days.
author: Matt G.

description:
I always suspected this place was a bit dirty ... well, it's true.  It's a DIRTY PLACE.  They were closed down for a while by the Health Department in July 2012 for SERIOUS, SERIOUS, health and food violations.  

http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:2:4278339481197157::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:2291
author: Guess G.

description: I smelled this place one day walking by so I tried it and I was so pleased with the duck over rice.
author: Fhinz B.

description:
This place has the best rice with roast pig and duck for dinner.  We saw good reviews for catering so we physically dropped by to order cater for our 3YO birthday party.  We spent $120 and ordered enough food for 50 ppl.  We even had left overs afterwards.  Here is what we ordered:

Large fried noodles
Large chicken wings
Small fried rice
40 egg roles

Note: when we called the day before to confirm the order, it took probably 5 tries and 5 people telling us that they would look up the order an call us back.  No one ever called us back.  So you have to be persistent to confirm your order.  We picked up our order with no problems.
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
I live walking distance to here and it's dangerous. 

Delicious.  There's seems to always be a line out the door to get food from Cheung's.  So far, I've just had the BBB Pork, Chicken, Duck, and Green Beans. Everything is amazing.  

I only knock of one star for a stupid reason.  If I keep eating here I'm going to clog all my arteries. lol.
author: Michele P.

description:
OMG, this place has better roast duck than in many places in L.A. For the price, $13.95 for the whole duck is a slickdeal. I was suprised to see a line at 7:30PM on a Saturday. I thought maybe there would be no more ducks by the time I made it, but there were at least still 10 or more hanging roast ducks with about a moderate line of 15-20 people. I learned about this place from my uncle who always brought duck to L.A. for me. But this was the first time I took a 2 hr commute from St. Helena to try it fresh. Flavor was good and I decided to buy another duck to bring back.

If you debone the duck for the meat and bake it in a oven at 325F, you'll have a nice crispy Peking duck (or Beijing duck ). You can use a corn toritilla with some sweet fermented black bean paste and green scallion to wrap for a convenient meal the next day.

Restaurant is very small (about 5 four-seater tables) and you'll be sitting next to the line while you eat (which made me feel like an animal exhibit)

What's around:
Bank of America is right next door (I believe it's cash only).
Boba shops
Chinese market
Thai Restaurant
Pub
Plenty of street parking
Safeway
author: Gary K.

description:
I guess its pretty obvious by looking at the reviews below that Cheung Hing makes bomb ass roast ducks (chinese style). Contrary to what others said about them being shady, they actually give you alot more meat than other restaurants I've been to, so even though I live on the opposite end of the city, I'll drive here just to get their duck.

I always get the roasted duck, soy sauce chicken, with extra roast duck sauce and ginger on the side - over rice.

I think they're nicer to you (and more generous with the portions) if you speak to them in Chinese.
author: Rosie W.

description: Living in the neighborhood with many Chinese restaurants.  This one is pretty good, food is delicious, kids like it.  If you just picking up you don't have to wait too long for cook to prepare food.
author: Ingrid B.

description:
WHOOPS!! This is the kind of love my DOCTORS used to warn me about! 

Cheung Hing has the most TASTY DUCK that I have tasted thus far, and I grew up on my solid share.  The roasted pork has very crispy skin (i.e. crunchy), but it's not as juicy as others I've enjoyed.  They also serve other Chinese delights, but they didn't look too appealing.  I have yet to try the BBQ pork, but I have an inkling that it's just as flavorful as the duck.  One downer is that the meat was cold, so I had to wait until I got home to reheat it.  Otherwise, Cheung Hing is worth the visit to the gym.
author: Diane N.

description:
As a merchant in Chinatown, we thought the best roast duck in town would be in my 'hood.  Unfortunately, this is THE best roast duck in town in terms of crisp skin, meat flavor, and freshness.  It's easy to find as you'll often find people lining up out the door waiting to get their fix.  The prices are reasonable too and their roast pork is very good too.
So why only 2.5 stars, giving them a generous extra half star???

a) you tell them how much pork and which part you want and they grab whatever pieces they can't sell (unless you're related to them, that is) -
big minus one star

b) you tell them the amount you want of other foods such as bbq pork, roast chicken, or their cooked foods (usually dollar amounts) and you can add anywhere from 25 to 50%. - 
minus half star

c) if you feel especially brave and tell them "That's not what I wanted", they give you a look like you owe them something or they're doing you a favor by selling it to you. - 
minus one star

It's too bad, because I do get cravings for their roast duck, but, when I see their stone faces, it's easy to forget about this place.
author: Mike C.

description: great take out and great chinese bbq. maybe the best, hands down. only thing i can't stand... the women that work here always try to force you to buy other items. so, stand you're ground and say no. also, quick note: if you're planning to order take out - call ahead and have them take your order.
author: Ann T.

description: I've been told there is a homeless man who steals meat scraps from the garbage the Safeway meat department uses for trimmings and sells it to Cheung hing for what I don't know maybe melt down the fat for frying I hope it is not true Cheung hing if I ever see it myself I will call the health department I have ate there and it is very good food just hope it is not true the person who told me works for Safeway and no longer eats there he say abc down the street is worth the walk he was very serious my self not worth the risk proceed with caution that was very disappointing I really liked them they should also clean better when there closed I can smell the restraunt from outside scrub your walls a bit that's it hope it was helpful
author: Frank L.

description: Roast duck is delicious, there's no lie about that. There's almost always a line when I come here. Minus 1 star because they hustle hard here! 50 cents for a small little container of plum sauce (maybe 1/2 a tbs-1tbs worth...).
author: Tina S.

description: taste no that good ,because they changed the owner recently! Yesterday i went to Cheung Hing the one at South San Francisco, the service was excellent and the place was clean, and the food taste very good!!!
author: Rain B.

description:
Oh Cheung Hing, you are like a Chinese grandmother wrapped into a hole-in-the-wall take out place!

Please note:  You come here to eat.  Not sit down in posh chairs and have 5 waiters attend to your needs.  This is about solid, fast Chinese food.

The standard:  cha siu pork, duck
The favorites:  pi pa tofu (they're tofu balls of deliciousness), fried chicken wings, beef and tofu over rice
