And just like my Chinese grandmother, do not peruse the food with your eyes for you will be met with a woman ready to push more food down your throat!

Order ahead if you're doing take-out to avoid the crazy lines!  Also the long line outside is mainly for duck and pork... slide past the crazies and go in if you're just grabbing food to go.
author: Christine K.

description:
I was turned on to this place, back in 2002 (by a friend who is Chinese). She had the 'scrambled egg, prawn, chow fun'; I had the roast duck (I also highly recommend the roast pork).

I used to go here once a week (call ahead, avoid the line). 

Over the years I brought a few other friends (who happened to be Chinese, as well - PURELY by coincidence) . . . and they couldn't stop raving about the place (seriously).

I've tried roast duck in 4 other places throughout San Francisco, I've also tried 'chow fun' in countless other restaurants . . . and NOWHERE, did I find the quality to match THIS Cheung Hing is THE BOMB (there's another on Clement, DO NOT go there).
author: Peter B.

description: After all the rave reviews, I finally got to taste what all the commotion is about. They proudly displayed their trophies and ribbons for the best BBQ meats in San Francisco Bay Area. I don't know how many years in a row, but there were plenty of ribbons lining the top wall of the restaurant. We ordered bbq duck, soya sauce chicken, salted chicken, pork stomach and bbq pork roast. Everything was good, but the duck was definitely a cut above the rest. The flavor of the duck made me a fan. They only drawback is that the duck was quite fatty with hardly any meat on it. Would I come back? definitely, but the next time I think I will stick to just ordering duck. It's just that good!!!
author: David Y.

description:
Please don't come here expecting service, cause that ain't its thing.  As a matter of fact don't expect service at any Chinese restaurant cause if you go in with this knowledge your experience will be much better.

I had a good number of things on the menu so I'm not going to be specific.  Just go in eat and go home, don't expect the creature comforts of other restaurants.  If you want great customer service and/or a great dining experience, don't come here.

Decor:1
Food:4
Service:1

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami I would!
author: Kelson H.

description:
There's always a long line here its well worth the wait, just order the roast duck and the bbq pork some of the best ive had in san francisco.
But beware of the pushy ladies when you are in line you would think they are in a hurry to get that roast duck.
Just one time i was about to order the roast duck and as soon as i said it a little elderly lady just told the butcher her order and he just totally ignored my order.
But if you can get pass these ladies you'll do just fine.
If you choose to eat here be careful of the floors and the tables, most of the time they are dirty, but its cool just order the roast duck and you won't regret it.
author: Corey W.

description: Roast pork and char siu over rice is awesome! It's a comfort food - Chinese fast food style! The roast duck wonton noodle soup is pretty good too! Cheung Hing definitely has really good Chinese BBQ. Yes, the place isn't spic-and-span and yes, it's kinda sticky, but the food is damn good!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
LOVE this place!

Super cheap bbq meats and actually good. The cold boiled chicken and bbq duck are so fresh and don't have that scummy dirty meat taste that some Chinese places offer. Grab a half of each, big bowl of rice and Chinese Broccoli with Garlic on the side. Under $15 and super delicious!
author: Natasha S.

description: Been back several times since the last review and its get better or tastier every-time i get my Chinese BBQ fixed. For vaule and dollars spent, this  BBQ is a better deal than the typical American BBQ joint. Its a  different type of  BBQ, but thats my opinion. Still outstanding value for your money!!!
author: Wolfy W.

description: Awesome Chinese restaurant. I came here the other day and had a great experience. The food was really good, tons of great flavor and wasn't too expensive which to me just enhances the flavor. I will admit it took a little bit for my food to come out and the service was a tad lack luster, but it wasn't bad. A good experience and meal to sum it all up. I look forward to coming back for sure.
author: Jose D.

description:
I have been coming here for years and must admit they make some of the best roast duck & roast pig in San Francisco. The already prepared food on the the steam table is ok but the BBQ items is what's worth coming for. 

Chow fun and won ton is one of the easiest to make and their's is pretty dang good too.
author: May G.

description: Yes, they got closed by the Health Department.  Yes, the bathroom is not cleanest one I've ever seen.  Yes, their service sucks.  But their roast duck and roast pork over rice are yummy!  Who cares about those things when the eats are good??
author: C L.

description: Friendly here with big portions but I got sick here.  Twice.  Once it was after eating the BBQ pork in the morning.  I think they must just leave it out at room temp all night long.  The duck is supposed to be good, the shrimp and eggs were good.  But like I said, I got sick here twice and I rarely get food poisoning.  I just think that meat sits and sits.  If you get it the same day they cook it you are probably okay.
author: Fredricko B.

description: I highly recommended their roast duck and pork..YUM!
author: Aniko N.

description: This place has the best Chinese BBQ deli items in San Francisco and is worthy of a drive across town. Their BBQ marinade has a good balance of Chinese five spice, savory, and sweetness. Extra sauce is always a request from my family. There are typically lines out the door until about 7 pm. Their food is definitely worth the wait.
author: Lillian C.

description:
Their Chinese BBQ is the best. I like the roast pork and the bbq pork. The duck is delicious too, but too fatty sometimes.

I always get bbq pork over rice! One time I ordered it late (around 9PM) and they threw in some random food that they serve like for lunch specials. Like tofu and eggplant... kind of cool.. or gross. We opened the box, and we're like... what the hell is that? It's a nice gesture though.. I guess. 

I like their goose wings and octopus too. 

Don't eat inside though! It's dirty so get your stuff to go!
author: Christina X.

description: This is one of my favorite chinese restaurant in Sunset District. Hole in the wall and may feel & look dirty but the food is good. Close to home. Cheap prices and tasty food. I love their roast duck and that sugary plum sauce! We always order to go because it's a small place and they only got like 4-5 small tables inside. Usually there are long lines during lunch & dinner time. My bf & I always order roast duck, singapore curry noodles, porridge with preserved egg, fried chicken wings, sometimes roast pork with the skin on...mmm. Sometimes there may be a huge line (especially during lunch hours), but it's totally worth the wait.
author: Amy H.

description:
Ok, this is the penultimate Chinese hole in the wall, greasy spoon restaurant.  It's like a diner and just as good or better.  If you're into roast duck, then this is the place to go.

When I'm in the city, this is one place that I'll go to, and I have never ordered anything except the duck.  The service is not 5 star and it's typically dirty looking, but if you like to eat, then this why I go here.  

The owners are friendly and helpful, even if they don't speak English well.  They can cook!  The duck is succulent and tasty.  Order the roasted meat over rice and you get a side veggie.  

If food and taste is more important than the looks of the restaurant, go here!
author: Dougg K.

description:
roast duck, bbq pork, green beans..

roast duck, bbq pork, green beans..

roast duck, bbq pork, green beans.. those 3 things are my usual take away order..

love love love this place.. it's convenient, yummy, and super cheap.. nothing to eat? cheung hing. lazy to cook? cheung hing. on a budget? cheung hing.. there's always a line but it goes by quickly.. make sure to get there early bc they will sell out. once, i made the mistake of coming in late and the duck and pork weren't as tasty as usual.. so go early! 

gosh, i miss this place dearly and the food coma that comes along with it..  =)
author: Raquel T.

description:
So, this place is a cheap and greasy hole-in-the-wall. 

That's why I love it. 

Delicious roast duck with a crispy outside skin and thick and juicy char siu? More, please. I mean, seriously, this place is super cheap for what you get and the massive portions they serve. It's all around $5-$6 bucks for roast duck soup noodles or roast duck with rice. That's a steal in this city. It's always busy here with take-out orders, but if you go inside, you can sit on the tables and eat a good lunch or dinner. It really makes me feel like i'm back in Hong Kong eating at a BBQ place! Score.
author: Lauren L.

description:
Jimminy Cricket!  This place is delicious!  I had passed this place while grocery shopping and my friend and I commented on how "authentic' it looked...complete with hanging ducks, cheesy decor, and fobby asians inside.  Well, I came home from work yesterday and found out that the boyfriend's dad had come over to visit and bought us a roast duck from here.  Legit.  The duck was fantastic....and I had it a few hours after they had purchased it too and had to reheat it!  The skin was crispy, it was tasty, and it was melt in you mouth delicious.

I have no regrets about moving into this neighborhood now that I know this place exists.  Absolutely none at all.  Amazing roast duck is worth anything!
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Char Siu and Yang Chow Fry Ryyyce Beeches!!!  What ya'll know about that!?!?!   Big Up my Yellow Massive!!!!  I'm catching the fever up in dis here mug...  Getting Freaky with my lil' yellows...

I've been making runs, slanging goods around the Sunset lately, keeping the streets hyphy in the Noriega hood and keeping all my lil Sunset homies strapped...   I could hits this spot up like all day, erry day. I ain't messing with no duck, b.c we ain't eat -ish like that in the hood, but when it comes to pork, BOOM SHOT fi DEM!   Rasta-Fari Live!!!!!

T-H-U-G Life Approved!!!!  Boom from mi GLOCK 9 mm...  More FYAH!!!!!!
author: Ubique K.

description:
Ok - I really wanted to give them 4 stars, but here's why I can only give them 3.. let's start off with the good.. Had the roast duck like what everyone else had been saying and it was really good! coming from me, who don't really crave duck..this one stood out!

now the bad.. I listened to my co-worker who suggested ordering a turkey from this place.. they told us how great it was.. so, we listened and ordered it.. turkey was 15 lbs and for $55.. we were given a # and a chose time to pick it up.. 

now, comes today - Thanksgiving.. we got there at 4:30P for a 5P pickup and they tell us to come back at 6P.. ok, we were upset..but, we still needed a turkey.. then we come back at 6P and guess what?? they tell us not ready.. come back in 1/2 hr! oh my! we were upset! we complained and wanted our money back.. they wouldn't give it back to us.. we weren't the only ones with this problem.. long story short.. we finally got our turkey and it tasted good.. not dry.. it came with Asian sauce.. good turkey, but hated the service!
author: Linda Y.

description:
Absolutely scrumptious. The best roast duck, by far in the bay area! Mmmmm Mmmmm Mmmmm! 
Just the right level of 5 spice, rice that isn't drenched in the usual dark-ish sauce but is super tasty somehow. I'm guessing its duck fat drippings. Yumm.
author: Kheng Y.

description:
+ duck
+ pork
+ BBQ pork.

They are all fresh, juicy and delicious! The only downside is that the place seems a little greasy & dirty..(tables, chairs, cups).

I would prefer ordering for take out, but I drive all the way from Oakland! Oh yeah, the ladies there are always trying to advertise and push you into buying other items, so be prepared!
author: michelle h.

description: Terrible line policy. People waited in line for their turn for more than 10 min, the owner and cashier there kept allowing customers to cut in front of everyone in line. When people complained, they just kept quiet. Don't shop there again!!!
author: Patty K.

description: Great chinese bbq. Roast pork. Roast duck. Soy sauce chicken. Cha sui. Yellow chicken with the ginger sauce. Mmhmm. The lines can get pretty long during after work hours so come at other times unless you don't mind waiting.
author: Sarah L.

description: Always great duck, pork and everything there. Get there earlier since things run out and always a line there.
author: Kerry T.

description:
Man this place is good. Super cheap bbq goodness. Yes yes yes, agreed, the roast duck is killer. The sticky fried rice is amazing. They have the BEST green beans I may have ever had in my life, somehow they are always cooked perfectly! Yes they probably use a large amount of MSG, but whatever, doesn't everyone know MSG tastes like heaven???? The inside is not so spotless, and the staff does not have the most clear English, but man do they do bbq right. 

They also have an incredibly efficient and easy take-out system. Wait in the long line that runs out into the street corner and you will be in and out within five minutes to enjoy your food from the comfort of your own home
author: Kristen E.

description:
Oh my holy roast duck.  Why do you taste so good?  Also, tell your cousin roast pork to stop tasting so good too.  Aaaah!  If I lived close to Cheung Hing I would be SO FAT SO FAST it's not even funny.  As it is, when I sleep, when I dream, I dream of food, and the food I dream is yours Cheung Hing, all yours.

4 Little Duckling and Fat Piglet Stars
author: Leon K.

description: I think they got money hungry here. I remember back in high school, however many years ago that was, their roasted duck and char siu was the best. Around dinner time the lines were LONG! You had to wait about 30-45 min to get your order. It's not the same anymore and the lack of a line shows it. I think they've changed their recipe to adjust to difficult economic times, however they've also upped their prices. That is just not too cool. The familia does not like getting their Chinese deli foods from here anymore.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
You want to bust your diet- go duck...

Duck story alert...

OK, what happens when you eat duck twice a week- you get chubby cheeks. 

During the dot com era i used to live down the street from C.H.C. and for budgetary  reason I developed a healthy addiction to duck over rice.   I loved walking up the street / Ave's- on Sundays during the football season and ordering half an order of duck and picking up some cold ones at the market... Oh-  the joy of cruising the skateboard back down to 48th with duck and bier in hand- I actually foolishly felt that this was a form of healthy exercises. Till one day my roommate Derek asked "hey what the hell wrong with your face- its getting round..." "what the hell have you been eating!"  Ahh duck! "gee you know that's really fatty"
Oh no, it's really good for you- "No!"  I remember running into the bathroom in complete shock- God what have I done- dam you tasty duck... So, I went to duck-rehab and now I'm down to duck every two months or so...

C.H.C. does have the best duck in the city - it's worth the wait... This place is a gem and a Sunset institution. I believe that some day they will retire their chopping board to the Asian American Museum- to display for all to marble over... 

Side note : Duck tongues are tasty...
author: swys -.

description:
CH has been supplying my fam with delicious roast pork, soy sauce chicken, roast duck, bbq pork, and last minute take-out dinners consistently for the past two or so years. I think we've been going there longer but I'm not sure. All I know is I get sent there to pick up stuff a lot!

I really like their selection of food too. Their chicken wings, fried tofu, and all the other stuff my mom likes made to order like the shanghai rice noodles and spicy eggplant. The folks there are fast and nice if you know what you're ordering. You gotta pay attention to the butchers though because they'll give you the extra fatty stuff. Especially watch the "amigo" (as my mom calls him) chopping away with his back facing you. 

Avoid the busy times (end of the day, after work, Chinese New Year) if you want to pop in and get something quick. Otherwise you'll have to stand in line and run the risk of whatever you want running out. Parking is a bear during busy times too. Oh and don't bother parking in the Safeway lot across the street- they tow!
author: Dawn L.

description: This is where you get real bbq Chinese food. Besides their authentic and famous bbq items , I found their corn fish filet quite outstanding. No question one of the best in sf!!
author: Wai C.

description:
90% hit, 10% miss.

Most of the time they have the best roast pork/duck around.  But sometimes they overseasoned (too salty) or underseasoned (too bland).

Very annoying that they wanted to charge 50C for the duck sauce that came from the same duck that bought!  What'choo talkin' 'bout, Willis?!
author: Bob S.

description:
This place is normally my default place for quick Chinese take out and barbecue. 

This time they messed up the order of hong kong style beef chow mein. They went back in and supposedly remade it, but instead of re-doing the noodles they re-fried the noodles with the bad sauce on it.  Bad combo, bad sauce and burnt noodles. 

Hopefully it's better next time.
author: Connie J.

description:
3.5 - 4

HOLY HELL WHY AM I ALL THE WAY IN THE OUTER SUNSET?!!??!!

For YOU Cheung Hing:

with your fatty, meaty, greasy roasted ducky over rice ($5.25!)

with your oh so tasty, yet slightly too sweet and tangy pork knuckles with hard boiled egg  (take home, reheat, so good!)
 
with your fried white fish dish that my pescatarian friend enjoyed

with your eggplant and succulent tofu dish

with your perfectly cooked string bean dish with bits of pork stir fry

with your over the top greasy ass cardboard covered floor that makes for a makeshift  slip n' slide to the bathroom

with your quick talking broken english speaking no bullshitting Asian woman server who bought out all the goodies in record time

with all your Chinese customers that have no problem getting all up in your business at the dinner table to see what kind of dish you ordered

YOU, Cheung Hing, are the reason why I'M ALL THE WAY IN THE OUTER SUNSET!!!!

(P.S  Fuck you, Chinatown).


Sara Bareilles' King of Anything.
author: Walerz B.

description: By far the best roast duck in S.F. known. Nicely  flavored, juicy meat, with tasty skin to go. Cha-siu is not close to the best tho, as even memories of my dad's version is better. They do charge extra for plum sauce to go with your duck, duck, sorry no goose here. Yea, do try the cuttle fish.
author: Ming W.

description: This is one of the places that has a line that never ceases. I went to check it out and was amazed. I usually don't like duck because it smells but this duck is so tender and tasty! It was so good no wonder this place always has a huge line its the best place to get roast duck!
author: Cristy L.

description:
I've had the duck and it's definitely Cheung Hing's best-- fresh tender meat with nice semi-crispy skin. The roast pork is okay. If you buy roast pork on the rib, it's more expensive because that part of the meat is more tender and in more demand but it's also alot more saltier.  

I've had their cooked to order dishes too like the fried prawns which got really soggy during the commute home. Cheung Hing's cooked to order dishes tend to be overly oily even for a Chinese restaurant. I was surprised to discover that their Beef Stew Lo Mein was actually just beef stew with unflavored won ton noodles that came with a generic dipping sauce.

They also have a buffet type display of pre-cooked foods. I tried their fried chicken which was tasteless, soggy,  and cold. The fried chicken tasted like bad leftovers from the night before. DO NOT buy fried chicken here. The deep fried chicken feet tasted like it was fried in very old oil that was reused too many times and had a bad aftertaste. 

The duck tongues were bland. The spareribs were nothing special-- a little too sweet.

Come here for the roast duck and stay away from anything that is fried. Prices are good but some things like the fried chicken was not edible.
author: Lorissa W.

description: Ducks are fantastic still.  However the Shui Gow is not that good, has huge chunk of bone/tendon in almost every bite.  I recommend sticking with the Duck only.  I saw delivery of their ducks today from Petaluma of Reichart Ducks which were founded on 10 Ducks from Hong Kong in 1910.
author: Jim J.

description: I've been going to this place for many years. Until yesterday I realized how much my family likes it. I owe them a good review.
author: Lynn Y.

description: I've eaten @ Chinatown NY most of my life. This place, by far, has the best peking roasted duck - hands down!
author: PV D.

description:
Their rice dishes are pletiful and cheap. The roast duck tastes good, but nothing special in my opinion. Seating is like cafeteria style and you may not be comfy with people crowding around you.

They would have gotten 3 stars for the value but a few things made it only 2 stars.

1st) their star sales lady is loud, agressive, and persistently asks if you want this and that. I'm not interested lady, I just want what I ordered. She's such a salesperson that she saw a couple outside looking at the menu, went outside, and coerced them into the place. Slow day I guess.

2nd) I ordered some food and someone else in the line ordered the same item after me. It was near closing time so they only had a bit left, enough for only me or the other guy. 

Instead of a first come first serve policy, the server pointed the other person out to me and said out loud that they also ordered the same thing and put me on the spot to split it with them. They would fill my remaining order with a similar item.  This really shouldn't be my problem that they ran out. Whoever ordered first should just get it. 

That tells me they are just after money. Nothing wrong with that, but when you resort to such tactics, it's very low class. But what can I expect with a hole in the wall like this other than to get a filling meal for cheap and nothing more.
author: Johnny D.

description: I love roast duck.  When I was younger, I thought I was biased in saying this place was hella good.  Now that I've traveled a bit, I gotta say that this IS that freaking good.
author: Sam S.

description:
Our family has never eaten at the restaurant, but Cheung Hing is the only restaurant where we buy roasted pork and roasted duck.

My only weakness in life is a duck dish.  If your menu offers duck and you do not horribly butcher (no pun) the dish, I am a fan of your restaurant.

Cheung Hing roasts both the duck and pork an appropriate amount, leaving crispy skin for both with a juicy interior.  I would recommend this place to fans of both.
author: Andrew M.

description: This is reallly good! i went there with my friends 7 of us total and they pushed the table together for us.  The place is really small and not really modern, but the workers are really nice and all the dishes were delicious!!  Its like a panda express style where they have the food there and you pick what you want  but with better food!  We had a whole duck (which their known for), long beans, roast pork, sticky rice, chicken feet, and steamed rice on the side.  They dont' have ice with their water but it didn't matter to me.  The duck was my favorite out of all the dishes we had, it was very meaty and tasty.  Oh, and as we were eating they keep bringing out different food to sell !  I wanted to try all of them! so im defintely coming back again.
author: Susie D.

description:
juicy roast pork with crunchy skin.
that's all you need to know. 
best chinese bbq! my fam only buys from here.
author: Ian S.

description: Debated giving 5 stars.  It lost a star because I hate waiting in line and the place isn't great for dine in, and it's also not very english-friendly.  All that aside...awesome!  NOT vegan, get that crap somewhere else.  Here we have salty, greasy meat.  I got the duck and roast pork, no sides, as they looked a bit sketchy.  The meats were roasted to crispy perfection.  A fantastic meal that would drive a cardiologist into a seizure! Very fatty and very salty, but what do you expect from duck and pork?  Serve over plain white rice to absorb some of the flavors and really that's all you need to make a great meal. I live FAR but I can't wait for my next excuse to get back there and pick up meaty goodness.
author: Ken P.

description:
I ordered a 1/2 duck, 1/2 lbs of charshu (bbq roast pork) and pork fried noodles to go yesterday.  The place was a greasy spoon hole- in- the- wall with real bargain prices.  The bill for all 3 items only came to 18 dollars!  

4.5 stars for the roast pork which was really moist and tender.  The charshu at Porridge King in Daly City has better flavor, but the charsu here is more moist.  

3 stars for the duck as the skin was not crispy and there was too much fat under and around the skin, the meat was also too soft and it was very greasy.  The duck was good, but not great.  Porridge King in Daly city has better duck - crispier, less fatty, not greasy, firmer and slightly sweeter in flavor.

3.5 stars for the pork chowmein as it was also very greasy.  The flavor was pretty good though.
author: Paul K.

description: This is my favorite roast duck place ever! I usually get roast duck & bbq pork over rice smothered with extra duck sauce.  I come here once a week because I live only a few blocks away.  It's my go-to Chinese takeout place. yum!
author: Sandy C.

description: Good place to buy fried salt & pepper chicken wings
author: Billy C.

description:
CH is about as good as it gets for Chinese Roast Duck. They do it perfect with the crispy skin and right amounts of seasonings. Also, I've noticed that the ducks here aren't as bony or fatty as some other BBQ places, so you get a good amount of meat. They do charge extra for the duck sauce but it's a necessity

Not much sitting area and there's always a line on the wknds.

A definte must try for the Chinese duck lover.
author: C C.

description: Pretty solid Chinese BBQ -- roast duck has really good flavors (doesn't need the sauce that most places would give you, which they charge extra for here), and the roast pork and char siu is better than most.  Oddly enough their jung is pretty damn good too.  The ladies at the front are pretty nice to you if you speak Cantonese, and always tries to sell you on the rest of the food they have.  Overall, not the best BBQ ever, but best place I've found in SF so far.
author: j k.

description:
How does it feel to be like a hog in heaven?

For around twelve bucks, order my Triple X combo TO-GO.
No matter what kinda stress you are in, you will be sedated after this meal for a few hours, if not thirsty from the MSG.

**

This sinfully delicious HK-style order may take some Cantonese finesse because the staff's English is limited.  Pointing also works.

1) 1/3 lb Cha Siu (BBQ Pork)  -- Ask for half fat and half lean.
2) 1/3 lb Siu Yuk (Roast Pork)
3) 1/4 of a Siu Ap (Roast Duck)

Skip the rice.   Ask them nicely to put the sauce in a container for you.  This is essential.

Make sure when you order, the butcher doesn't get too zealous and give you 1/2 lb.  They are known for aggressively doing this.

Then go across to Safeway to grab your favorite bread with either
a beer or your favorite drink.  You will thank me later when you get thirsty.

Finally drive to the Cliff House area and devour your meal in peace.
Put on your favorite music and watch the waves.

The crispy skin of the roast pork and roast duck is so tasty, that
even some of my friends from China say they prefer this over the food there.  The cha siu is juicy and tender with a sweet molasses aftertaste.  

**

Cheung Hing is THE place to go for roast duck and Hong Kong style BBQ pork as take-out.  The problem with this restaurant is that it is too tiny to eat comfortably and too greasy all around.

Another complaint is that the line is long and it gets cold standing outside.

Disclaimer:  You should have leftovers for snack.  You seriously don't want to be the hog in heaven, just yet.

 /\___/\     Oink Oink!   Squeal!   - Dedicated to Yelper Jason C.
    .  .
( o o )
author: CT L.

description: Every place has their on and off days but when this place is on their roast duck pork soy chicken are great. I get a 2 item over rice with extra sauce. Quick tip. If there is a long line order something from the steam trays like their bomb tofu and they order you roast duck or chicken and they push u ahead!
author: King L.

description:
Yeah this place has some bomb ass roasted duck. 

BUT BEWARE!! THEY ARE SHADY!!

Cheung Hing will rip you off when you buy the duck whole or half to take home. There were numerous times when they secretly took some of the best parts (like the breast meat) and set it aside (possibly for people ordering the rice plates), and get away with it because they don't sell them by weight. And when you get home, you'll end up with pieces with lots of fat and bones.... and not much of the meat.

If you really love Cheung Hing, make sure you request them to not chop up the duck for you and you'll have a peace of mind you'll get what you paid for. The only thing that sucks about it is that you'll have to deal with chopping it up yourself when you get home.

So my family and I HAVE BEEN BUYING ROASTED DUCK FROM WIN'S. They are just as good, they won't rip you off and I trust them in chopping up my duck .
author: Nance W.

description:
Boy (on speakerphone as I'm driving): what are you doing? blah blah blah blah blah

Me: I'm in the sunset on my way to this place on Noriega. I have to get pig arm and duck neck for my landlord.

Boy: WHAT!??!??! DUCK NECK. PIG ARM.

Me: yeah. it's pretty good. have you ever tried it?

Boy: you're nuts.

Then my friend and I went in and after a little confusion (her cantonese sucks) got what we wanted. And then proceeded to act like five year olds by hitting each other with the pig arm the whole way home.  Thank you Cheung Hing for keepin' yo' shit on the real.
author: dr S.

description:
Roast duck: very tasty.  One of the best in the bay area.  Of course still can't compare to those in Asia.

Roast pork: it's okay not extremely good.
author: Hei C.

description:
One word: Over - rated. This has been the talk of the sunset in terms of best Roast duck and pork. But in reality they are never consistent in their cuts of decent duck. When I say decent I mean ducks that are not full of fat. 

My friends have nickname for this plate. Instead of duck over rice, it's call Fat over rice. 

Basically all you get is fat that under a crispy skin. Nasty. 

When you enter the cafe, you will see all these awards and ratings - which they show with pride because for some reason they score really high. 

Like I said, there ducks are ok. To get a decent duck depends on the cutter, whom sometimes can be an untrained and inexperienced cutter.

I dont dislike the store, I just think it is over rated. Because it is. 3 star is the perfect rating for this cafe. And forget about eating in there. Even if you find a table, you will cramp all meal long. And forget about privacy because the restaurant is going to be full of people lining up with their ass within 2 feets of your plate.
author: U L.

description:
4 stars for food alone but definitely a 5 if you take price into account.  The BBQ pork, roast duck and soy sauce chicken are must-tries here.  You rarely see lines forming outside Chinese take-out places at 3:30 pm but you see them here.  That speaks volumes to just how good the food is here (of course, having won quite a few awards and having them in plain view help too).  Luckily, the lines move fast because this is Chinese fast food afterall. 

There is some limited seating if you just want to eat and go.
author: Sandy W.

description:
CHA SIEW!!!!

I came here for the first time today with a friend to order some cha siew. It was an unexpected stop, but after passing by the window and we saw the meat hanging there on a hook... it was as if the meat was talking to us, telling us to come get it. And so, we did.

The man behind the counter greeted us with a hello and asked us what would I like. We ordered 1/2 lb of cha siew ($3) and a large box of white rice ($2) to-go since my friend didn't eat anything all day yet. The man then asked me nicely if I would like it chopped. I said, "yes please" and he diligently sliced the meat into nice, thin pieces. When he put the meat into the infamous white cardboard box, he even gave us some of the cha siew sauce/gravy! :)

The whole time, I was speaking Chinglish (Chinese + English) but he still understood me so that was good. After eating the cha siew here, you wouldn't want to get it from any other places. The roasted duck here looks good though. Especially when it's hanged up, with all the yummy juices dripping out from it. Oh, how tantalizing.
author: Annie S.

description:
Restaurant? I wouldn't really call this place a restaurant, it's so tiny inside!

My boyfriend's parents come here once a week to get some good old roast duck, cha siew, or roast pork to add on the dinner table. I barely come since there's always a line here, either that or other people cut in front of you. Yeah that's always annoying. 

Other than roast duck, soy sauce chicken, roast pork, and cha siew. You can order rice plates, fried rice, chow mien, and they also have hot foods to-go. Prices are decent for the food you get. 

Remember to try their roast duck!
author: Tracy A.

description:
I get all scared when I come here.  
If youre not yelling out your order within 1.3 seconds of walking in you get the stare.

If you havent ordered within 3.9 seconds you start noticing everyone else is giving you the "what are you retarded?...oh youre not Chinese...that explains it" look.  

If you have to resort to pointing at what you want because you dont know what its called, let alone what its made of,  the lady starts mumbling and asking you questions in Chinese making you feel as if shes performing a price check on junior sized condoms over the loud speaker.  

I stop crying and order the roast duck and roast pork over rice.  I drop back a few steps and wait for my order.  Oh no!!  The lady is handing out the orders in chinese!!! I start crying again.  How am I going to know which ones mine??  Okay I was behind that lady in line so once she gets hers mine will be next.  I stop crying.  Sure fire way to get yelled at by some small Chinese lady because youve grabbed her meal.  Sorry granny!!!!   I start crying.

Davids Bottom Line-  I finally grab the right bag and eat outside huddling and facing the wall.  The tears go well with the duck and pork.  I love this place.
author: David L.

description:
We've been coming to Cheung Hing for the last 15 years.  My mom and sister who live in LA request to get their 5 spice chicken whenever they are in town.  We've had them roast a turkey for us (using the same spices) once for Thanksgiving.  Very yummy.

Basically, if you want friendly service and freebies, don't expect that from Cheung Hing since their profit margin is probably not very high.  If you want solid, inexpensive take-out that tastes even better reheated the next day (as the flavors soak in), you cannot go wrong with Cheung Hing.
author: M Y.

description: Maybe my favorite place to get Chinese food. Not the Mandarin style food, but Hong Kong style. I get the roasted duck over rice (best in SF), or the scrambled eggs w/ beef or shrimp over rice. Making myself drool just typing this out. Prices are great and you know the food is good when there is a line of Chinese people outside waiting to order. I've gotten other stuff here and so far I haven't been disappointed. I've been going here for over 10 years! Try it and you'll be hooked.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
I am not saying I'm an expert in chinese bbq ok but trust me dogg, i had my fare share aight. I don't know why so many people is ging this place so many stars....... I'm thinkin the only reason why is becuz this place has been around for awhile now it reminds them about how good it was bad in da days.... WAKE UP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!     

Ok dogg!! I admit, it was good before but something happened. Change of ownership? change of chef?? or maybe they made enough damn money and they do not give a F about quality or taste anymore. 

Now .... let's get down to business!! I came here on 2 occassions. one was a dine in meal and one was for take out bbq. 

My dine-in experience was horrible.  first of all, i ordered  the mince beef over rice. For any of you who had this before, yalls know dat there's always a raw egg right in da middle. Always a a raw egg!!!! so when i got my dish, guess what i didn't find?? Bingo!! Ma damn egg!! so I politely ask if the chef forgot the and if they can add it in. The waitress said with a slight attitude saying that it doesnt come with an egg and if i wanted one it would be $1.50. I said, "$1.50!!!!" I could go to safeway and get a dozen freakin eggs for a $1.50!!!! Trippin!!! so i put my palm up and told her to " Puff....Be Gone You Devil" !!! On top of dat the dish was way too salty. 

The next time i came here I bought some chinese bbq to go just to give it another try. I specifically told the person that was cutting my bbq pork, to cut it into smaller pieces. I also ordered a roast duck and pork. I guess i was not paying attention that day when the person was cutting up the bbq i oredered(Ithink i was on the phone), but the bbq pork was in hella big chunks!! WTF!! You would've thought he was cuttin some prime rib or something. It sucks eating a fat piece bbq pork. it's just too chewy. The duck was'nt better either. where the heck do they buy their duck? Crack house?? It was the skinniest bird ever!! And the roasy pork!! those bastards gave me the ass part!! yeah you heard me "pig ass". I swear i said i wanted the rib section.

All in all, a really really bad experience. BAD!!!!!!!
author: RICKY C.

description:
This would probably be the BEST place to get some duck.. Whenever I go, especially on the weekends, there is always a long as line for some fucken good duck.. Which is a good thing.. One, you know the duck is excellent here and two, you're duck is always fresh! But thanks for my mama and papa, my siblings and I usually wouldn't have to wait in line because they would go buy it for us.. Oh how much I LOVE them!

Duck runs you about $11.. and the duck isn't the ONLY good thing here. Their BBQ items like cha siu is pretty good too.. 

Make sure to go get a package of steamed buns and have a Peking Duck party! (PLEASE invite me next time)

I think we should have like a Yelp Peking Duck event?
author: Juliane N.

description:
I have had a lot of duck in my life, but Cheung Hing has to be one of my favorites so far. 
You can tell by the line that wraps around Noriega why. The Roast Duck and BBQ Pork are fantastic. Throw it on rice with some boiled cantonese cabbage for under 7 dollars!! 

The duck and other bbq items will sell out quick on random days, so make sure to get there early.
author: Jason W.

description:
I'm very particular about the combination of how tomato beef chow mein is cooked. There has to be an even amount of beef and veggies and the thickness of the noodles has to be just right.


Cheung Hing has got it right. I am in LOVE with their tomato beef chow mein.
author: Jocelyn W.

description:
This place always has a line out the door every time I pass by and I guess its because of all the meat they sell there (especially their roast duck)!
I finally came here to take out some lunch and ended up ordering the black bean beef chow fun and an order of the roast duck and won ton soup for my boyfriend.
I waited about 10 minutes for the food to come out and was satisfied with my chow fun. Good portion and the taste was not bad. My boyfriend also loved his soup.
Prices here are cheap. I would never eat in here, there's too many people coming in and out but wouldn't mind returning if I was in the area for take out.
author: Miss H K.

description:
OMG!!! All my Chinese friends have said that Cheung Hing has the best roast duck in the City. They weren't kidding! I bought my lunch here today and was in heaven. They gave me the crappy cuts but it was still mostly meaty and succulent. Getting splashed by hot duck oil on my new CK sweater was worth well worth the fatty goodness. Risking the cholesterol induced heart-attack was worth my #99, duck over rice plate; or so I thought. A quick google search indicates that roast duck may actually improve your cholesterol level. Go figure. 

A thousand AZN drivers in a 99-Ranch parking lot won't keep me from going back to try the roast pork and char siu.
author: Kevo M.

description:
I'm going to be honest here. Cheung Hing's is all about Chinese BBQ. The roast duck, the BBQ pork, the roast pork... they got it DOWN. Anything they got hanging in the window... Even that yellow sea creature with the big round head and little legs. I don't know what it is... I never had any... I probably will never buy one. But if some was ever chopped up and offered to me, I'd try it and bet it tastes great.

I was first turned on to this place about 12 years ago, because a friend said they had the best roast duck in town. I went... had to wait about 25min but he was right... been coming here ever since. The lines are still long. 

But I'm just talking BBQ. I have no interest in the stuff they got in the warmers... sweet n sour pork or generic stuff like that. I wouldn't even recommend eating in, unless you got a thing for people's butts creeping along the counter to the register, cause thats all you're going to see... while your trying to eat.  A unique thing is that this is one of the very few places that offers BBQ Duck Liver, which is excellent for dips, gravies, and appetizer dishes.

Cheung Hing should be the standard for Chinese BBQ. Check it out. The line could be way outside the door, but the Roast Duck and Pork are well worth it.
author: Rick V.

description:
Look, if you haven't eaten Roast Duck here, you don't even know what Chinese Roast Duck is.  

I won't lie.  The place stinks.  The floors are so greasy it feels like your ice skating on animal oils.  The service is pretty crazy - one o.g. waitress - she's a sweet heart, but I swear she's on crack.  She'll rush you to death to order and when she brings you food, she tells you to take your time.

But let me warn you.  DO NOT ORDER OTHER MENU items.  If you do, you're on your own.  I cannot vouch for anything in there.  Most of the food will be from the slop station up front - felt sorry for the patrons next to us, as they ordered quite an exquisite line-up, only to be served second later after a few flicks of the wrist from the other cashier.  The only next best thing could be the won ton fun soup noodles.  But they are just average, at best.  The roast pork?  OK, above average roast pork, but how can you ever go wrong on roasted fatty pork?  You can't.

Remember, GET THE DUCK.
author: Isaac L.

description:
Went there yesterday and there was a long line out the door.  At 6 p.m. on Saturday, that is the only place with a line.  The roast pork has very crispy skin, but the meat lack flavor.  Char Shu is much better, juicy and moist.  The deep fried tofu is just OK, the sauce that comes with it is flavorless.
Overall, the food not as good as before, may have changed owner?
author: Chaing L.

description:
Because I like you, I'm gonna let you in on a little secret. Every Thanksgiving, Cheung Hing makes and sells roast turkey the same way they make their mouthwatering roast duck and chickens. Same sweet sauce, same flaky golden skin, and juicy meat! SO GOOD! 

I celebrated Thanksgiving last year, Asian style, with half a Chinese roast turkey, green beans with black bean sauce, Stoffers' stuffing, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, with mango Calpiso to drink. =D Ooh, and afterwards, my friend and I took the leftover meat and turned it into some yummy jook (porridge). It was my kind of Thanksgiving! 

I'm pretty sure they only do roast turkeys for Thanksgiving, so just call and make a reservation a week or so before Turkey Day and pick up your order the day of. They charge by the pound and you can order half a turkey too. Now you too can rock the Asian Thanksgiving!
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Cheap, fast, good Chinese food.

10% off if you pick up (I think..)

Ample parking at 1pm.

Too bad I don't like Chinese food.
author: Kimiko Q.

description:
This is THE place to get quick, delicious chinese food FAST!

Okay so the bf and me came here tonight for some grub...we parked and there was already a line out the door - good sign!

We ordered chicken salted fish fried rice, 1/2 order of roast duck, some bbq pork & some chinese greens....

I love love love salted fish fried rice and this place makes it right!!! Delish

Everything was tasty, fresh and good....this is the place to go for some good chinese food to go!
author: Jade B.

description:
I was just buying one hold duck and one hold chicken,I think 
i spend more than $25. but anyway I was just try to ask them for 
sauce & ginger for my duck and chicken. they told me that each 
sauce cost $0.35. I ask them how come other peoples get them 
free but just me. and then say they will give me the sauces for free. I went 
back to work. my coworker told my much the duck and the chicken 
are .... i just found out they did charge for the sauce. that's hella 
f... up.. before I think they taste & serves are good . but not now.... 
more..
author: mike l.

description:
Got there right before the line out the door formed. 
Roast duck was flavorful although I'm not a fan of 5 spice powder and it had that taste. Very greasy. Good skin. We needed way more napkins. Honestly, if you go, bring some Wet Ones. The cabbage was yum.. Latter on they hauled out some beautiful bright green stringbeans..but we already had the cabbage. Glad I tried it .  Grim surroundings.  The ladies behind the counter literally scream.  You just have to be up for it.  Looks like most people get their food to go. Probably would not go back.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Cheung Hing has the reputation of having the best roast duck in the city.  I don't know if that is true, but the roast duck is pretty damn good.  It is so moist... juicy even.  the skin is nice and crispy.  The duck overall isn't too fat; you wont see a big chunk of fat between the skin and the meat. *drooling....

The line is  long for take outs, but we ate there.  The rice plate and the noodle plates are pretty good deal.  In all, we ordered 1 soy sauce chicken rice plate, 1 roast duck & bbq rice plate and 1 roast duck & wonton lo mein, All of that only came out to be $18.61.  The lo mean was good.  the mein was chewy and not stuck together.  And they gave all of us a lot of meat on top of our rice and noodles.  I know that the chicken plate was at least a 1/4 of a chicken.
author: Janet S.

description:
In our first bout of Noriega vs Taraval (ok, Taraval and *friends*), Taraval's Just Won Ton won handily over Noriega's Won Ton House.  Next up is the duck round: Cheung Hing vs Win's.

Experience-wise it's apples and oranges.  Whereas Win's is a straightforward sit-down place, Cheung Hing is the proverbial Outer Sunset noobs-beware dining adventure.  All manner of roast ducks hanging in the window, and take-out customers cramming into the tiny place by the score.  Much confusion over where, what, and how to order, and over whether we were "for here" or "to go", all compounded by a higher-than-usual language barrier.  Insider's tip: if you want to eat there, DO NOT order at the counter; just sit down at a table and wait for a waitress.

Despite the baffling semi-ordeal of ordering, it all worked out in the end.  A whole roast duck for $10.75 (enough for 4), chopped up right in front of you, and perfectly complemented by some veggie fried rice.  The duck is absurdly fatty and well-seasoned to boot (I definitely detected a hint of cloves).  You know your cholesterol is going through the roof but you're compelled to eat every last piece of succulent skin too.  If I had been going straight home, I totally would've taken the leftover grease with me for stir-fry.  Indeed, if I ever have to serve a Christmas dinner, it's gonna be a Cheung Hing duck all the way.  

Safe to say that Noriega wins the duck round, tying things up at 1-1.  But  the real winners are the savvy diners who take advantage of yet another Steal in the 'Set.
author: Wes M.

description:
My Wisconsin raised boyfriend who is normally a beer, pizza and burger kinda guy, loves this place.  When he gets a duck from here, he says it makes his week even though he is shortening his life by a few years each time.  

It's a totally typical hole in the wall place.  Main items are the roast duck, roast pork, BBQ pork and a few Asian dishes.  There are maybe 4 tables to sit at.  It seems like this is a family run place, complete with the little 10 year old to help wrap up your bags and bring you a glass of tea should you choose to dine in.  

If you go with the roast duck, you can't go wrong.  It's to the point that when we get duck anywhere else, my BF always complains it's not the same as Cheung Hing.  

Despite all negative reviews of cleanliness and the like, I've been eating at places like this my entire life, and have never seen anything out of the ordinary and I am still standing and alive and haven't ever gotten sick from food from here.  

If you want more room to sit at and actually feel like you're in a restaurant and not a to go place, there is a Cheung Hing down in the Peninsula, same yummy duck.
author: Denise B.

description:
1.5 stars because BBQ is edible and you cant ever go wrong with fried chicken wings.

extremely greasy stuff but you knew that.

no lines, just cutting to the front to order, but you knew that.

takes only cash, no credit.  but you knew that.

definitely questionable sanitation, and you definitely knew that, son!

we've tried this place over 6 times, each time we got lazier and lazier to cook dinner and hoping this place would have something that was better than what we ordered previously.  each time got worse if it weren't for the chicken wings which we dressed in sauce when we got home.

i'd like to say i wouldnt come back here, but i probably will again....  goddamn, why do i torture myself? food masochism at its worst
author: Christopher N.

description:
OK so here i am trying to shrink my percentage of bodyfat  more and swearing off meat.  i'm thinking about going 75%  vegetarian.  doing really well until i pass this place today. 

 ohhhhhh long lines of chinese people waiting.  this usually means its something free, cheap eats or pay more but good food.  this place is great prices for great roasts of every kind.  Chinese have a way of cooking anything that moves.   it may not look like frog or sea slug but it is or they drown it in sauce; then it's called, "Todays Special".

Fat steroid sized ducks, soya chicken, 5 spice chicken, secret sauce squid, roasted porky pig, many hot plate items involving vegetables & some fish, fowl or meat, all great for building those winter love handles.

yeah i really ucked up today.  you would have thought i was shopping to save some poor starving village.  now my stomach gets to were ever i'm going a minute ahead of me.  now i know how some pregnant woman feel like.  hey, maybe i'll be lucky enough to get some of those, "Your Positively Glowing Now", i'm pregnant compliments.

i thinks its a cash only place. parking is so so. minus 1 star cause that wooden chopping block can't be cleaned properly.  i wanted to say something but that guy sure knows how to use that heavy sharp ass hell cleaver.  cleaver fu equals run fu for me.

if your in the area, forget cooking and just enjoy. take that boss out that you dislike and ask for the, "Heart Attack Platter".
author: Dan W.

description:
I live in the sunset and have always wanted to try this place. My experience was just ok. I gave the place 3 stars because the food really tasted fresh, and was not too salty. The roast pork skin was delicious but the meat was kind of tasteless and a little dry. I want to try the pork BBQ! 
    The people seemed nice enough but when I ordered over the phone they spoke very quickly and offered no clarification. of my order, then quickly hung up the phone without a total or ETA.  I didnt check the order but when I got home one of the dishes was completely wrong. Service was the overall factor in my rating.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I don't eat here, but I come here to buy whole ducks. The dishes look decent enough and the staff is nice, but usually I'm a man on a mission when I go here.

I get the duck, drool at the the pig ear and duck tongue, and go down the street to get some ingredients from the asian marts.

At home, I separate the bones from the meat from the skin from the fat. This allows creation of a stock from the bones, red thai curry from the meat, noodle soup and fried rice from the skin and stock, and risotto and potatoes from the rendered fat and stock.

A single $13 duck, a few hours of time, and you've got enough meals to last an individual a couple weeks. What's not to love about that??

====

Rubric: 5 = Mindblowing 4 = Excellent 3 = I see the charm 2 = Disappointing 1 = Never again
author: Eric K.

description:
Roast Duck and Roast Pork 

I could sit there and eat that with rice...i'll die from the fat..

but I love fat....
author: phillip w.

description:
I usually destroy their half roast duck over rice, with some tender greens and asparagus.  Ask them to drizzle some of that duck chest cavity au ju over my duck and rice for that extra salty savory kick that you can't find anywhere else.

Also love their roast pig, with the crispy skin.  Always get extra skin.  And the BBQ Pork.  I try to remind myself to sample the stuff on their paper menus and secret menu but I always fall back on the duck or pig.  This place is consistently good, cheap and all about the take out.

Next time I've got to try the chicken wings.  They call to me.
author: Margaret L.

description:
I've been coming here forever. I couldn't tell even you how many years. I usually only get duck over rice, or if I'm taking it home, whole or half duck, since I always have rice at the house. It wasn't until this past year I tried the sticky rice and chicken wings. They were both pretty good.

This is hands down the best place for duck in the city. It's actually the best duck I've ever had. People say Win's on Taraval comes close, or that it has good duck, but I think Win's duck is awful compared to this place. Plus they sometimes give you the sauce, which like someone else mentioned, is also impossible to find anywhere else. The sauce/seasoning of the duck is what makes it.

Anyway.. now for the bad... 4 times out of the last 6 times I ate here, the duck was extremely lukewarm. More on the cold side than the warm side. This is easily avoided by going when the place is busy. I don't like to bitch so I usually just took it home and heated it up. I understand it's not cost effective to keep the cooked duck warm during slow times.

OK now this is the real bad part: the last time I came here, after the butcher was done with everyone's orders, he took a mini break. Well maybe not a break, but it was the first time I ever saw him not behind the counter. Around the end of his mini break, he starts picking his nose and blowing it. Using nothing but his two hands, no napkin, no tissue. Real good too. A good 4 times, getting up real good in those nasage passages.

I have worked in food before. I don't mind the place being a little dirty. I know about all the nasty shit none of you want to know about. I know how hard it is to follow health code every single second of your shift, and how annoying it is to have to wash your hands all the time, especially when you're busy. But it wasn't busy at all. I mean he was clearly taking a quick break. After he was done with his break, he just slowly returned to his post behind the counter towards the window. Didn't wash his hands, didn't put gloves on or anything, just got right back to chopping some meat. I have never ever seen the butcher with gloves on. The ladies I have seen wearing gloves before, but never the butcher. I wasn't even worried that much, since I already got my food, but my friends were. They watched him the whole time and couldn't believe he didn't wash his hands. Great first impression for my friends who don't know anything about Chinese food. They were glad they hadn't gotten anything.

But anyway.. strike one picking your nose in front of customers. I wasn't the only one eating there. Strike two, not washing your hands after doing it!!! It still didn't really bother me all that much, my review would probably just be a 3, since the duck is still amazing. I've eaten for weeks in a third world country before with flies flying everywhere touching every surface in the kitchen. Got a little minor diarrhea but not much worse than I've had in the US. But what really bothers me is thinking about all these years my family has come here. It has to be at least 10 years. And all these years these people probably didn't have the respect for their customers to wash their hands after doing any kind of activity with a chance of contamination. I haven't been back since, and I don't think I will for a while. That duck is damn good though.
author: Steve R.

description:
It is true it is good to be able to at least bullshit cantonese here because I saw a woman attempt to get take out with limited cantonese and they screwed up her order and she got mad. The women who take the order tend to get confused at times. The floor is sticky at times, but boy can they move bbq. 

The place is dinky compared to every other place I have seen but the food is very well done, just order the bbq and stuff on the menu with the other dishes they put out to the left of cash register it can be a crap shoot to how well it tastes, I have had something that tastes amazing and something that is overcooked and yucky.

They make really good roast duck and roast pork, the flavors are a lot better than in Chinatown and closer to me. The roast pork skin is always crunchy. I would also recommend their chicken as well.

Their congee jook is also pretty good with good flavoring and all the random stuff they have.

Their standout is the house special noodle with has squid, scallops and good sauce, albeit a little bit salty though. Quick tip about ordering this as take out is to ask them to seperate the sauce from the noodle. It is best to add the sauce and noodle when you eat it becasue then it will not make the noodles too soggy. 

There is also seating but is cramped but still the bbq over rice is still decent. For lunch it is cheap and quick if you only order the rice plates and nothing from the back that takes time to make.
author: Christopher C.

description: Just get the roasted duck over rice and thank me later.
author: Jessica J.

description:
These people drive me mad. And by mad, I mean 1. make me want to jump over the greasy counter 2. grab the small-sized to-go box 3. hold it up, and 4. yell, "THIS IS HOW MUCH I WANT! NO MORE BECAUSE IM NOT PAYING FOR MORE THAN THIS." 5. then pay and leave. 

Don't get me wrong, the bbq pork/cha siu/duck (that's all I've tried) here is extreeemly good, in comparison to the soggy pig skin Chinese restaurants usually give, but man oh man do these people push you to your limit. I'm talking about the ladies who serve the other food and cover the register. Not the meat-chopping people. The older man chopping the meat was very very nice -he cooperated with us when we told him what we wanted, which piece we wanted, and how much we wanted (1lb, 1/2 lb.). That's all we were asking for. Cooperation. An element that the cashier ladies clearly do not want to provide, at least when dealing with people. Ok, not everybody gets this treatment I understand (although when I walked out of the restaurant I heard another squabble building up) but I just have to put this out there. Let's face it: you gotta be strict with these people when ordering, or they're gonna take advantage of you. Despite knowing this, here's still went down:

-1 pound of string beans, but "no more" to them = put more in
-then when I say "too much", they put more in/load on up+talking to me in Chinese when i clearly only speak English
-don't give me that esl crap, i know you know what enough means
-ended up with screaming, everyone looking at us
-ended up paying for what should be a 2 person meal became 6 person meal
-asking me how many pounds of fried tofu
-do you think i know how many pounds of big friend tofu triangles i eat? no, i eat in in number of pieces. not pounds. my family will eat 10 pieces. how many pounds is that? you tell me. and based on last time when you gave me 3 pounds of food instead of a half, all I'm going to be saying are clear numbers now -just so that 4 pieces don't turn into 4 pounds.
author: Tara V.

description:
There are long lines out the door for a reason!

When you pass by this place, you usually see a line out the door, and they're all waiting for the cooked meats.  (Note: if you want the cooked foods or anything else, just go in because there's no line for that)  They have really crunchy and tasty roasted pork; tasty BBQ pork, awesome assorted cooked chickens, and of course, great roasted duck.  Haven't tried all the meats they have, but the roasted pork, BBQ pork, chickens, and ducks are their big sellers.  It's definitely a hot spot for many families to stop by to pick up some meat for dinner.  It's opened til 9pm, too, so it's very convenient!
author: Jason K.

description:
Contrary to popular belief, the roast duck is not the star here. Go down 2 blocks to 3 star, they have the best duck. 

Now, the true gem here is the roast pork, the skin is crispy and tasty. I prefer a lunch plate to go. The cabbage stir fried with garlic is a create lil extra with the lunch plate. Certain parts of the pig are best, but I will not divulge that information as they will run out of that particular piece and I'll be disappointed.
author: Dustin L.

description:
I've been eating duck from here for almost 20 years. In the old days it cost $7.85; now, like movie tickets, it's over $10. Still worth it. The duck meat is the most succulent in the city. At the end of your meal I guarantee you'll wipe up the duck juice that splattered on the table with your finger and suck it dry. The cha siu still tastes as good as when you had it at birthday dinners growing up. If you're not in a blow-out-your-taste-buds mood, the soy sauce and kuel fei chickens are a touch more subtle but still excellent. 

At any time there's a line twelve deep for take out. I've eaten in a few times, too. The menu is simple: any of the take-out items in the front served over rice. They serve you hot tea in cracked translucent brown plastic cups. They're the same plastic cups I saw 20 years ago. I have always wondered if these cups started their lives clear.
author: William L.

description:
Noriega is a great street with a lot of cheap good eats.
not exactly a dine-in type of place as mentioned previously, but that shouldn't affect its rating
anyway, it's your typical hole in the wall, duck and pork hanging in the window scene
whole roast duck/marinated duck  $10.75
definitely worth it!
however, the ducks are extra fatty in general
the cha siu is flavorful as well
try their pork/cabbage buns -- they are good
oh yeah, bring a cantonese speaking person
author: Rob C.

description:
It's always the hole in the wall that has the best food!  So be prepared to wait in a long line if you hit this place up during the evening rush.  It is well worth it though.

My Eat In Faves:  Duck over Skinny Rice Noodle and/or Ho Fun Soup

My BBQ Faves:  Roast Duck & Roast Pork.  Buy their duck sauce and drown your rice in it....hhmmmhmmm good.

My Take Out Faves:  Tofu/Bean Curd (depends what u call it??) & Stirfry Fish.  Who has time to cook these days right?
author: Jenny K.

description:
OMG, I LOVE THIS PLACE. It has the best roast duck in the city. Sometimes, I can even taste the damn duck in my dreams. The skin is crispy.  The meat isn't dry. And they give you so much for such a good price!!!!!  

The roast pork is just as damn good but you have to go early to get the good parts of the roast pork. Otherwise, you get some gnarly piece of the pig that you don't want to think about while chewing.  

Do not be afraid to ask for lean pieces. If it's too fatty, say so.  Yes, they don't speak English very well but they do understand if you speak loudly and clearly.  They hear the same phrases all the time, for god's sake.  Mind you, keep it simple.  Don't yell out long descriptions of what you want.  "NO FAT PIECE" or "NO TOO MUCH FAT" has worked amazingly well for my siblings who (as much as I adore them) can't speak Chinese very well at all. lol. :-)

Don't be afraid to try the other stuff on the menu.  Haven't had a bad experience there in all the years I've eaten there.
author: Angela K.

description:
This place deserves a five star review just based on their roast duck, which is what they're known for.  I've tried a couple of other things here and there, but the roast duck is definitely their niche.  It sucks to see the price go from $9 for a whole duck to almost $14 almost overnight, but it's still worth it at the $14.  

They boast a banner which claims they were voted top 100 restaurants in the United States.  I don't know how true that is, but it definitely is one of the top 100 restaurants to get roast duck.
author: Mike L.

description: Best Chinese BBQ in the city by far!  There may be debates on who's duck is better, but Cheung Hing has the best roast pork hands down.  If anyone knows a better place, please inform me.  Oh yeh, the beef and egg over rice is excellent too.
author: Robert Y.

description: The bbq here is very good!  The bbq pork (cha siu) was excellent, the best I have ever eaten...very tender pork with good marinade and flavor.  The roast duck was also very good; it was very tender and flavorful with nice roasted skin and plenty of seasoning.  I didn't care for the squid or the chicken wings, but they were not bad.  If you're in SF and want Chinese BBQ, this is the place to go!  Just look for the tiny bbq shop with a line out the door.  And I would suggest coming early because once they run out around dinner time, it's all sold out!  The lady behind us ordered 15 lbs of bbq pork, cleaned out the restaurant; luckily I ordered mine ahead of her.  The restaurant is tiny and parking really sucks around this area, but it's well worth the wait for good Chinese bbq.
author: Terence N.

description:
When they first opened, it was cool cause we finally got a pretty good place in Sunset for BBQ Chinese Items.  I think there have many that tried before them and failed but finally, there was one that got it right and their success just keeps going and going and going.....  You can see that by their constant lines...  

Even better than most of their Chinatown counterparts....
author: Mark W.

description: Best roast pork in town. Super crispy skin and succulent meat. They also sell it as a rice plate. We've never done sit down here. Always get it to go.
author: P K.

description:
Why the funk is this place only rated 4 stars on Yelp? It should be the only 5 star restaurant on the entire site. I'm dead serious. I live minutes from this place and eat here very often. Everything you have read is true. It really is the best roast duck in the world (and yes, I've tried roast duck outside this country). And all their other food is very good as well. 

And another thing, all the OG Chinese folks that come to this place need to get a Yelp account so that they can come rate this place to bring the average up to the appropriate 5 star level it deserves.
author: Arick R.

description:
Oh how I love Chinese food. I will only eat roast duck and BBQ pork from Cheung Hing. Their food is juicy and delicious. They are on the pricier side, but it's worth the quality.

Cheung Hing also has yummy fried chicken wings, they are perfectly spiced. 

My dad bought BBQ pork from another chinese store, but it was nothing compared to Cheung Hing.

People stand in line for this during thunderstorms!
author: Winnie L.

description: This place's roasted duck is da BOMB!!  Get it with rice and don't forget to ask for the sweet and sour dipping sauce!!  Remember:  You don't have to line-up with the line that hooks out the door if you are just getting a duck over rice.  The line is only if you want to get the entire duck or half a duck or anything from the butcher in front.
author: Patrick C.

description:
I wish we could break down ratings into various sub-categories, i.e. food, service, etc.  Though service in Cheung Hing has improved a lot (I've been visiting them not so often for the past 13 years), it is still not what I would consider as 'Excellent Service', especially if you are not Asian.

Their duck, however, is the best - that's why I give them five stars.
author: P F.

description: I've stopped going anywhere else for roast duck or roast pork (also got a whole roast piglet here for a party once, major WIN).  Love the way they try to sweet talk me (in Cantonese) for the upsell.  But you have to summon your inner Pushy Asian Mom here when ordering - they will literally rifle through the entire pile of roast meat for you if you make them, but if you just let them pick, some times they stiff you with the crappy pieces (as my decidedly non-pushy husband has discovered).
author: Jan C.

description: Their ratings and reviews says it all.  I would like to mention that their steamed chicken had a yellow tinge to them.  Food coloring or natural?  I'm staying away from that until I get clarification on what that is all about.
author: Lai L.

description:
I've come here several times and I must admit that their roast duck and roast pork are delicious.  If it wasn't for my last experience, I would probably give them a 5 star rating.

However, I came by a few days ago to order half a duck and a pound of roast pork.  It was getting close to closing time and the guy cutting the duck was pretty aggressive in trying to sell me the whole duck.  But my friend and I can't eat that much meat, so I politely declined.  He also gave us 1.5 pounds of pork instead of the 1 pound that I asked for, so I ended up paying more than I was expecting.  Well, when I got home we found out that the half duck that he gave us was all the bad pieces!  It was basically parts of the duck that were either mostly fat or mostly bones.  I've gotten duck multiple times, so I know what a half duck should look like.  Other than the leg, we didn't get any pieces that had much meat on them.  There were lots of pieces that was almost all fat with a very thin layer of meat or connective tissue over bones.  And there were other pieces that were less fat, but still only a sliver of lean meat over more bones.  I guess he must have been angry that I only got half an order of duck.  The roast pork pieces that we got were also very fatty, but I'll admit that it tasted amazing.  It was tender and juicy and not at all dry like some other places.  It ended up being a good thing that we got extra pork since the duck was so lacking in meat. Plus, the leftover pork was still good after being reheated the next day.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Can I get a G-D! (Translation: Gooood Daaaamn) This is an amazing chinese eatery thats grubby, cheap and good. BBQ pork, roasted duck, minced beef with raw egg over rice, braised tofu and the chicken wings!?!?! WHAAAT??? If you don't want to eat there, take outs an option and they cater too.  

Drawbacks? Although not many people actually dine in, get there early to beat the lines picking up to go orders. The BBQ pork and duck sell out quickly. Not for the faint of heart when it comes to cleanliness and if you're not familiar with the cuisine, go with someone who is or be daring and willing to point.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
Brought my friend here for lunch one day and as soon as we sit down, he asks what's good here.  I told him that the roast duck is out of this world and if he's going to order only one thing here, it has to be that.  He goes on to tell me all these reasons why he hates duck.  My response was, "this isn't your run of the mill duck.  it's Cheung Hing's ROAST DUCK!"  After a few minutes of debating, he agreed to try it.  Needless to say, after this visit, Cheung Hing recruits another faithful new customer.  

If this review is solely based on the roast duck here, they would definitely get 5 stars from me.  There hasn't been one thing that I can find wrong with the duck from the many years of me coming here.  But I took one star off for the horrible wait most of the time.  Maybe if/when they move to a larger space, I'll revise and give them 5 stars!
author: Selene K.

description:
This is my all time favorite place for roast duck.  I've been coming here for years and yes sometimes I wait like an idiot for the damn roast duck.  No other place in SF makes it better.  It  tastes o so very good with the plum sauce.  I always ask for extras and they usually just give you this one tiny container.  O wells better than nothing.  I think I can really sit and eat the whole duck myself.  

I also like the BBQ pork here.  Eat it while its still warm  its the freaking best.  Also you must try the duck liver.  Its pretty freaking good and my sisters always like the roasted spare ribs.  O my I'm getting hungry.
author: Allison T.

description:
CHA SIU IS GREAT --lean and flavorful.
Roast duck is also flavorful and juicy.  However it's all pretty oily, so beware.
A few stars are taken off due to the quality of service.  Don't come here for service, speak Chinese for the optimal in-and-out situation, and pay cash.
The Mexican butcher cutting meats is the best service-wise, btw. :D
author: Ming S.

description: Can you say NASTY. This place is not worth trying!  The service is bad and the  food is not what I would call Chinese Deli. I would rather drive to LUM HOA THUAN.
author: ALICE L.

description:
Roasted Five Spice Duck Haiku:

Oily Crispy Yum
Cheung Hing your duck is so good
Cravings satisfied
author: K W.

description: Bar far thee best roast duck,Ginger chicken,roast pork,,everything is good there.even their thanksgiving turkey is bomb
author: Avery H.

description: This is the only place where i buy roast duck! I love it soo much! I wouldn't eat here because the space is really small.
author: Francesca M.

description: Growing up, this was always the best place to get roasted duck, barbequed pork, and baked chicken. I am happy to report that nothing has changed (except maybe the prices, which are still reasonable). Sometimes this place can have a long line, but it is usually well worth the wait; you will surely receive a good serving of delicious Sunset Cantonese food.
author: Andrew P.

description:
My family loves their duck feet, roast duck, and bbq pork. 

I love their fish with black bean sauce, bell peppers and onions which you can purchase by pointing at the glass divider that separates you from grease splatters which are the result of the chopping of several kinds of roasted meats.

Also love their Hong Kong style combination noodles and their wet noodles. 

Quick, cheap, delicious.. Take your food to go where you can enjoy your meal in peace and avoid the hustle and bustle of the glory of Cheung Hing.
author: Christine C.

description:
Delicious and cheap, enough said!

My husband and I ordered to go the roast duck over rice, beef chow fun, and (accidentally) 1.5 lbs of roast pork.

The roast duck was the BEST roast duck I've ever had, and trust me, I've had a lot of roast duck in my life.  It was over rice with cabbage, all for only $5.25!

The beef chow fun was deliciously greasy and filling, again, only $5.25.

Two dishes would have been more than enough portion-wise, but my husband wanted to try their roast pork, so I ordered 1/2 a lb of it.  Unfortunately, I was misunderstood and ended up with 1.5 lbs of it...it's okay though, because at $6.25 a lb, we still only spent about $20 for 2-3 meals for 2!

Definitely will be coming back in the near future!
author: Shirley J.

description: If I need a quick meal on Noriega that's not too rough on the wallet, I head here. The duck is amazing! You might not like it if you hate greasy things, this duck is dripping! I get it with rice, and they use some kind of pepper seasoning that is just superb. They don't really speak English, but they are easy to order from. I just ask for a quarter duck over rice, and they get me the same thing every time. Love it!
author: Chris I.

description: Roast duck over rice.  I can't say enough about their roast duck.  It fortified me through law school and those cold and wicked summers, springs, falls, and winters in the Sunset.  I dream about the duck here.  If I had to choose a last meal, this just might be it.  Anthony Bourdain, you need to see to see this.
author: Rock T.

description: THE LINE IS WORTH IT! The roast duck is the BEST. The cha siew is pretty bomb too. Sounds gross but duck tongue is also good. Everything is just good, ok. Haha. Cheap rice plates, oh hell yes! I used to get annoyed when my mom would make me drive all the way out there just to get ONE duck, but who am I kidding, I will go far and wide for you, Cheung Hing. You hold it down as my #1 in my roast duck loving heart.
author: Jen L.

description:
I love their duck, love it, love it, love it.
Of course somewhere out there a more superior duck exist, but this is the get down and dirty kinda 'I am hungry but I don't want to cook' kinda thing, ya know?
I guess, the 'crispy' skin is not always consistent, because I've been where the I've had crispy skin.  I miss Cheung Hing duck with a big 'ol bowl of steaming rice, LMAO, and some of that duck juice poured over the rice and some Sriracha action, you know you all have done it, sitting in front of your TV eating your quickie dinner.
author: John L.

description: Been coming here for years for the the roast duck.  The duck and the cutter fish are definitely my faves but I also get the crispy fried bean curd w/ meat and black bean sauce w/ fillet once in awhile.  I want to try the turkey they make someday.  I think they are open Daily: 9am-9pm.
author: she q.

description: This place is better than the ones in Chinatown. Their roast duck is sooooo flavorful and juicy. On top of that, they give you humongous portions + friendly service! I also recommend their bbq pork as well.
author: Hana K.

description: Pretty good duck. I usually get the duck here to-go, but you can also dine in. I find that when you dine-in you do not get the best cut of meats. This place is ok for chinese food.
author: David N.
