description: Great roast duck and BBQ items! Been here for years. Although I don't frequent it as much now as I did in the past I highly recommend folks to try this place out. I think it's ideal for takeout although it has a tendency to get pretty busy during lunch and dinner hours. They do have seating for dining in but I'm sure it can get noisy and cold due to the shouting aloud of orders and the front door always being left ajar for customers to come and out easily. Their food in general is very tasty and consistent for as many years as I can remember. Check it out!
author: L C.

description: I haven't been here for a couple of years now since I moved to the east bay, but somehow I ended up in the Sunset today for some reason,  so I decided to gets me some Cheung Hing.  They got some new flooring from the last time ive been here because I remembered i would slip on the floors from all the grease. The roast duck was still as good as it was when I used to come here often.  All the BBQ stuff is good here not just the duck. They have that boiled chicken with ginger and onion sauce which always good to but I always wonder why they call it free run chicken?
author: Mike K.

description:
2nd time I bring a friend who lives super close to them, trying to help them really, my friend is not Chinese, I am and I ordered in Chinese.

I offered my friend some luck while we are in the store so we sat down, 2pm, at the open table.
Mean rude lady telling me that I must pay extra to eat duck in the store, WTF I paid for the duck and it's embarrasing, I eventually have to tell her that I come here a lot and just be nice, and it will be quick, she finally okayed it.

RUDE RUDE RUDE, I am taking my business to irving and 25th, the lam hoa thuan place, where they are much nicer. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/lam-hoa-thuan-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:pP72dMa8kx9iJRTU17UbxQ/query:duck%20irving
author: Jamie L.

description:
This epidomizes Chinese Hole-in-the-wall: greasy floors, nasty decor, roasted animal carcases hanging from hooks in the window, the waiter/waitress is a rude version of one of your relatives. Damn, I'm home! 

Like everyone else has mentioned: it's all about the duck. That salty, ole-so-delicious cabbage -- drowning in liquefied duck/chicken/pork fat -- they serve with their rice places is is heaven on a plate -- haven't found that in Socal yet. 

Come for the duck, stay for the duck. Better yet, take it home, cook some rice and chow down -- Cantonese style. 

Don't f*ck with the Cheung Hing duck!
author: Law W.

description:
This week I fell in love with a duck. 

The diner next to me was served a platter of crispy pork and duck on a bed of rice with cabbage. When it came time for my order, I wiped my chin and pointed to my neighbor's dish that I was adoring with saucer eyes. It was love at first sight.

When the meal was served, I quietly moaned at every bite of the flavorful fat, tender breast and crispy skin of the roasted bird. When the check arrived, I nearly fell over. Six bucks are you kidding?! 

The hostess introduced me to chicken feet and other delicacies on my way out. "You try these next time. You'll like them." She said. 

Walking away in a cloud of ecstasy, I agreed. I would have believed anything she told me.
author: christopher r.

description:
I just finished a FREAKING HALF DUCK!

Tonight isn't the first time I went there to get my duck fix, but it was the BEST time. It was FATTY, but the skin is so perfectly crispy, the meat is so tender and juicy! I think it's because it's Sunday, when they sell tons of them so they are sold very soon after they came out of the oven. Seriously, the meat melts in your mouth. 

Previous visits were ok, not quite as good as tonight, because not warm and apparently had been there for a while.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I went here last night.  After reading all the reviews and salivating all day.  I went straight from work.  The soup Nazi comment was accurate.  The staff doesn't like having to speak english.  So if you speak Cantonese be prepared to use it.  But, they were actually really nice just difficult to communicate with.  

The Duck was AMAZING so fatty and wonderful, perfectly seasoned and succulent.  I also got an order of their Green Beans really yummy and not soggy even after the drive back to Marin.  They were just barely cooked still a tiny bit crunchy in the middle (so good).  I LOVED all of it.

Keep in mind however, that this is a deli.  Not a good place if you are looking to sit down and have your duck with sweet buns or pancakes.  But, if it is duck fat you are craving this place will not let you down. Half a duck, an order of veggies, and some rice was perfect for 2.  But, I went really crazy for the duck so you might now eat as much. Or you might go just as crazy because it's freaking good!
author: Sonya C.

description:
I hate to play devil's advocate here, as this is truly the best Chinese BBQ in town. The line out the door doesn't lie. 

However, the MSG content is extremely high (probably off the charts), contributing to the lick-your-fingers-clean factor, so beware...you will be thirsty. Very, very thirsty!  So thirsty I'll have to sadly subtract a star from something so close to perfection. I suspect I'd only subtract half a star if that were possible.

And in agreement with other reviewers, if it ain't BBQ, definitely order/buy it elsewhere.
author: J C.

description:
On weekends there is ALWAYS a line going out the door (not to sure about weekdays).  There's a good reason.  The best roast duck ever!  It's so worth the long wait.  The roast pork and BBQ pork is good too.

There are only a few tables inside to eat so I wouldn't recommend  eating there.  Take your food to go!  

On extra crowded days, like around Chinese New Year, there are no tables.  They utilize all of the space to sell you yummy meat.  Usually this is how it works - for uncut meat you don't have to wait in line, go straight inside.
author: Stacey L.

description:
I would wait 2 hours in line for the roast duck here. It is the best in the world. Everything is good but the roast duck is to die for. The sauce is soooo good! I can eat almost a whole duck from this hole in the wall joint. The roast pig is good but only if you get there at the right time. I like the part near the ass (dark meat). 

Around Chinese new year I recommend bringing your PSP to keep you entertained while you wait. It's worth it!
author: Stephanie P.

description: Oh...Cheung Hing...I love your Roast Duck! It's definitely got the best roast duck in the Bay Area! Inexpensive, too! Whenever I feel like some Chinese BBQ, this is the place I go! I have discovered this place about eight years ago and been a fan since! The dimensions of this little BBQ shop is quite small...it's a hole-in-the-wall. I think it's really only suppose to fit about three tables at the most but they somehow made it to five tables...of course, all crammed together though. More than once before, I had to squeeze through between two tables to get inside and I felt bad for the person at the other table because my butt was literally in their face (and I ain't fat!)! Lol. But to me this is just something minor for the price I was willing to pay for their delicious roast duck. Their service? Fair. It is a hardcore traditional Chinese Restaurant, so I did not expect much service. Like many other Chinese restaurants, their theory of good service for you is to get u in and out ASAP, which I really do believe they do a great job at. It's like no BS...order, get food, and leave...done. My dinner there usually takes less than half and hour. As far as cleanliness, it's one of those places that I do not wanna know about...I don't wanna what goes on behind those kitchen doors. I will never use their bathroom. I love their food and I'll just leave it at that. Usually, I do try to keep myself from touching their tables and chairs as much as possible though...it doesn't look spotless clean, that's for sure. This place is really off the hook though as far as business flow. It's constantly nonstop! Their phone rings about every five minutes and there's always at least five ppl in line! It's usually the same two Chinese ladies that serves and they do work fast, just not fast enough in comparison to the flow of traffic though. A plus for those servers is that they are able to speak at least three languages: Cantonese, Mandarin, and English. A side note worth noting is that they do serve already-cooked dishes too and those do sell fast as much as their BBQ items do.
author: Winnie L.

description: We ordered a roast piglet last week for a party, and it was just DELICIOUS!!!!! The roast duck and chow mein was also really good. Good party food restaurant and orders to go.
author: ARLENE C.

description:
Good neighborhood roast duck and pork.  All good Chinese BBQ places get busy around lunch and especially early evening near dinner time around 5pm....always a line here.  Nobody really orders rice combo plates here (I'd rather go to that place on 24th and Irving).  

My only gripe is that I've been a victim of the "Chinese kid who doesn't speak much Chinese" treatment here a couple times.  As any Chinese American will tell you, sometimes old, fluent Chinese folk will try to bully you out of position in the line and order before you speak up...intentionally being a-holes.  OLD CHINESE PEEPS JUST DO THIS OFTEN IN BAKERIES AND BBQ SPOTS....I DUNNO WHY....THEY LIKE TAKING ADVANTAGE OF YOUNGSTERS.  This happened to me a couple times early on and was insulted that the butcher actually went along with it....but much time has passed and I now know how to hold my position in line.  Oh well, you sometimes gotta pay your dues.
author: Gilbert C.

description: this place was recommended to us by her mom. she said that this is the place for duck. it was a little out of the way, but since we were only spending one day in the city we had to go. its not a hole in the wall, but its real close. people lined up outside, which is a good sign. we got a half order of duck and i saw some bbq pork, so i got some of that too. a quart of rice and some forks, we were out of there looking for a spot to have our snack. i'm not much of a duck guy, but that was good. if i can have duck like that all the time, i might have to give up chicken and turkey. the pork was just as good. so good, that i can probably eat the pork and rice all day long. this place  put a smile on our faces.
author: Joey H.

description:
I second the "Soup Nazi" comment... stand in line out the door, walk in, order, move over, pay, move over, pick up.

Cheap and good food here. Small dine-in place, don't touch the table or anything else... it's usually sticky, probably they used the same damp towl they wipe the butcher counter with.

Anything BBQ from here is a hit.
author: qirk z.

description:
I wish I didn't have to share!  The best roast duck and roast pork, in the City.  Parking isn't too bad, either.  

Rice plates for lunch are pretty good.

Long lines during the weekends and early evenings.
author: Collin W.

description: I am counting down the days of feasting on Cheung Hing's lovely, succulent (sometimes a bit too salty) sexy roasted duck later this month. Oh yeah I'm also gonna visit my friends and family whom I haven't seen in over 1/2 a year. Sorry mama but you're gonna haveta wait. Roasted duck or bust..
author: Warren P.

description: OMG they have the best roasted duck ever! I ordered a duck plate and ate the entire thing in one sitting. It was just that good! Now i know where to buy duck to-go or have a roasted duck plate and eat-in or out!
author: Helen L.

description: i've been searching high and low for the perfect plate of dry fried string beans and i think i found it...in a chinese bbq neighborhood joint. these string beans are made just the way i like them...crunchy, salty, with a hint of sweetness. it's made with minced pork and pickled radish, giving it more flavor and texture. their bbq meats are also not to be missed, especially their bbq pork, which explains the long lines every time i've dined here. i'm knocking off 1 star cuz their food can get pretty salty towards the end, which i'm not a huge fan of. but damn their string beans are good!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
We ordered the roast duck porridge (kao ya zhou) and the famous Cantonese thousand year old egg and lean pork porridge (pei dan shou rou zhou).  

I ordered in Mandarin, which turned out to be a big mistake.

Instead of the roast duck porridge, we received beef porridge...in Cantonese I guess it sounds like ngiu yook jook whereas in Mandarin, roast duck porridge is kao ya zhou.  Somehow the waitress got it wrong. She didn't offer to redo our order or change it...

It's the best definition of a hole in the wall. The table was wobbly and the waitress immediately took a plastic spoon and stuck it under the wobbly leg...voila it stopped wobbling.  We thought that was endearing, but their famous roast duck porridge would've been best.  The long lines for takeout (mostly for their duck) show how popular they are.  

Just speak Cantonese I guess!  Sorry I learned any Chinese (Mandarin) in college, so pardon my lack of Cantonese. Or order in English! Though sometimes they seem to struggle with that too.  

The food was ok.  Oddly, we never have problems at the Cheung Hing in Millbrae in terms of ordering...and the food and duck there are very good.
author: Ye W.

description: Mmm cha siu and roast duck.  You cannot go wrong with this place.
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Primarily a take-out place.  The roast duck at this place rocks (probably the best on Noriega).  Scrambled-egg with shrimp chow fun is done just right.  The cha siu at this place is excellent.  The roast pork is just average, though.  

So what's not to like about this place?  The service.  They know that their duck's the best, and they're snobby about it.  Service at the counter and at the tables is downright rude.
author: Rich H.

description: Cheung Hing has a line out front for a reason.  The duck and pork here are wonderful-crisp on the outside succulent inside.  The vegetables are always cooked the perfect crisp tender too.  There a just a few tables on the side of the line of people buying food here.  The place is more suitable for take out.  It is my favorite place for duck (or pork) in the whole city!  And you can actually park near by.   I gave it five stars based just on the taste of the food, it is perfection.  You can also find a nice desert at one of the bakeries down the street
author: Diane P.

description:
Unmistakably the BEST chinese roast duck! For about $10 you can get the whole duck or $6 for half.  The plate runs about $5 or you can get 2 BBQ items for about $6.  (Their soy sauce chicken is pretty good too!) Did I mention that they LOAD the plate up?  Best bang for your buck!
A few notes-It does help if you speak cantonese and getting take out is the best way to go.  It is a hole in the wall so don't expect good table service.  Plan on waiting in line to order and don't let those older ladies cut you off! Going near Chinese New Year?  Forget about it!  This place is known for its chinese BBQ so get your chow funs somewhere else.
author: SFFoodie F.

description: Been here before, but my last visit was SOO disappointing. Been reading about how great the roast duck is. So I ordered a half roast duck to go. I watched the butcher cutting up the duck and was pleased to get a fresh one not, the colder one sitting on the side. But when I got home I found that I had two lower halves of duck. No breast meat! How lame is that? I don't know if it mattered that I was the only non-chinese person in line or what. The duck itself was okay. Luckily for all you fans of Cheung Hing there will be one less person standing in those long lines since I will not be giving them my business any more.
author: Stephanie R.

description: A friend of ours had a "duck party" earlier tonight -- amazing idea, by the way -- and ordered 10 ducks from Cheung Hing for about 25 people.  I think she was worried that the ducks would be too small, so she wanted to make sure there was enough, but by the end of the night, we had barely finished about 4 ducks, even though we tried our best to eat as much as we could.  It was some of the best duck I've had in a long time, and the skin was super flavorful.  The skin wasn't super crispy, but part of that is probably because there was so much "duck juice" in the tray of duck we were eating.  However, we kept going back to snack on more and more duck all night, and now I have a bag of leftover duck that I'm looking forward to eating later this week.  She also got a small tray of roasted pork, which was also very good, and skin stayed crispy all night long, which isn't always the case.  Now it's time for a meat-induced coma...
author: Pilan C.

description:
Wow the 5 spice chicken is ridiculous. Been there 4 times in the last 2 months. I was driving from Oakland to Half Moon Bay on business today and decided to go out of my way for this. It was better than I remember. This is the best deep fried chicken I have ever had, bar none. Any style chicken for that matter. It tastes better the more you eat.

They also have good fried sticky rice and steamed rice. This place is not the typical 'americanized' chinese food you find everywhere. 

Next time I will try the crispy duck. It looks better than the chicken. Dark crispy skin and juicy looking.......wow!!! I don't know what oil it's fried in, maybe lard, but I don't care. This is the only chicken wher I eat the skin and every last bit I can. Usually I am very picky about the skin.

As for picking ouit the piece you want, sure I watch the chinese customers do this all the time. The guy in front of me today argued for a 5 minutes about which piece of pig he wanted. The meat cutter even went through them all and the guy was getting irritated. Finally, the guy went back to the window and picked out the piece the meat cutter had picked out 2 minutes before!!! I get the impression that alot of them do it just because they can and it satisfies their need to boss someone around. Whatever....
author: gary c.

description:
As everyone stated, TAKE OUT ONLY! You do not want to eat there with people lining up next to you while you're eating. Its quite unappetizing eating there. 

I have not found better BBQ items anywhere in the city. Their BBQ Pork "Cha sieu", is ungodly, i bring it home and pan fry the slices until they turn a bit brown on the sides with of my steamed rice with a fried egg on top  with a side of veggie. PERFECTION. Pan fry it, it really brings out the flavor.  

Their duck is really good but i often don't order it cause its really oily, i recommend their flat roast duck, its not as oily and the skin is a bit more crispy. 

I love their fried tofu with the mystery mashed meat center. Although i went there last week and it had fish in the center instead of the usual filling. 
A+++++++++++++++++++
author: Eric N.

description:
Wow! A Chinese friend who lives in the neighborhood tipped me off to this obscure gem, vowing it was the best duck in SF. I'm a duck lover and agree--I haven't found anything better. As usual with the most excellent duck places, the prices are rock bottom, putting to shame those shishi places that charge you $30 for the privilege of dining on canard.

What are my duck criteria? Crispy skin, moist meat, most of the fat rendered out, and please, not too many feathers left in the skin. Ideally eaten, not hot, but slightly above room temp and definitely before the rendered fat congeals.

I've never had anything but duck here. Other items look good, but the duck is so excellent that I can't bring myself to reduce duck consumption to make room for anything else.

Heads up: it's tiny and a neighborhood favorite. Expect a line if you come at popular times. Consider carryout, since the ambience is nil in any case.
author: Bambooo S.

description: Are you kidding me!? Vastly overrated! If you ever think of coming here to pick up a simple rice plate, try elsewhere.  I stopped by, ordered roast pork over rice ( My all-time fav rice plate), and received scraps of left over pieces of roast pork.  You've been forewarned!
author: Brent S.

description:
People who gave 4-5 stars, are you all Chinese? 

I went this restaurant today, and if a customer did not help me, there was no way for them to take my order. They were basically ignoring me and helping the other Chinese customers. First I couldnt understand what is going on, then  realized that everybody behind the counter were speaking only Chinese. Thus they had to ignore me :)

I got roast duck and roast pork. It was ok, but if they were speaking a little English, it would have been much better
author: erdem u.

description: First of this place is completely unsanitary I will be reporting to the health department after I saw dirt everywhere. Secondly these people are racist. I was waiting in line to get duck and there were about 3 people ahead of me. The person in front of me ordered exactly what I was about to order which was half a duck. I could see one duck hanging above the counter and below it. The person in front of me got half the duck that was under the counter and I knew there was enough left for me. When I gave them my order they looked at me and said no duck. I could clearly see there was more left so I told them. They turned around started speaking in their foreign language and then told me to leave. As I was leaving I saw the person behind me ordering the same thing only they were Asian and got the duck. AWFUL SERVICE they should be shut down for their unsanitary business and racism.I would give -1,000 stars if I could
author: George M.

description:
My list of things to do yesterday:
1. Order tres leche cake from Safeway for co-worker's birthday party
2. Get take-out food for kids' dinner
3. Get my arse over the Legion of Honor for the exhibit (see LH review)

Check off 1, where to go for #2?
Oh. Look.  Cheung Hing across the street.  Hmmm, Yelper Charlton L. wrote a recent review of this place.  I've tried their deli stuff, let's try the take-out:
1.  Won-ton noodle soup - kid says it was OK but better than Win's on Taraval.  CH's won tons are larger (still 5-6) with more shrimp. (noodles & won ton and broth in separate containers)$4.55
2. Bok Choy chicken chow mein - pretty good with a nice flavor, healthy portions of bok choy and ample chicken breast pieces.  $5.00
3. Five Spices chicken over rice - the chicken was really good, you get about 1/4-1/3 a small chicken, lots of rice compared to amt. of chicken.  The 5-spice rubbed nicely over the crispy chicken skin with moist meat with the flavor infused into the rice and a dollop of cabbage. $4.95
4. Gai lan vegt/beef - she didn't hear me say "fon (rice)" so, we ended up with just the vegt/beef.  It was swimming in gravy & leaked all over the plastic bag, like a puddle of rain. $5.95.  It was OK, the vegt was very crunchy, not overcooked with slivers of carrots.  Not sure I'd consider this dish again even if it's over rice.
If you're going to dine-in, they only have 2-3 small tables.  One is used for the staff to hold the huge aluminum trays of food that people are ordering for parties.  During dinner time, you have to go early or put up with the queue from the doorway.  Definitely the most popular Chinese deli in the neighborhood.  Check off #2.
author: Ry T.

description: Not like this restaurant needs another review, but I don't get out to San Francisco all that often.  As my standard order for chinese bbq meats, I get the roast pork/bbq pork combo.  I lucked out in finding a space right at the corner, a few doors down from the restaurant and there was still time in the meter!  My roast/bbq pork were decent.  I don't know how often I'd get an opportunity to be in this area again but know it's still a reliable place to go.
author: J T.

description: Five star roast duck according my mom's friends. When my auntie from Manhattan visits, we go there once a day.  Hole in the wall, very tiny place with about 4 little tables that seat four.  Lines out the door, order at the counter, cashier at the end. Seat yourself or better yet take it to go and make a tasty soup with the sauce, and left over pieces. Roast duck, it's all good. Sam Woo in LA charges about $5 more.  Meter and residential area parking, you might have to look for awhile.
author: Nancy Y.

description: Not really sure what all the hype is about. Granted I didn't have the duck, but I had the bbq pork, and meh.... Maybe it's just my round-eye taste, but it all had that cheap chinese food taste. I got some of the regular dishes as well and they all had that similar taste. The only thing that saved it from one star was the mongolian beef, which was ok.
author: Parker H.

description: Sorry to tell you the worst BBQ duck I ever had!  Maybe is just me but I brought one last week, the duck is greasy fat, can't eat them.  I didn't want the sauce cause they told me will add 50 cents and not free.  I also try their BBQ pork, is all too lean, no good.  I mean, if you really wanted to try a piece of BBQ pork, don't go for lean meat, no good taste.  I usually order 1/2 fat, 1/2 lean that is a good BBQ pork, but they didn't even ask me how I want my pork.  Service is bad, people are mean!  No, No, No!  I will not go there!  Sorry ...wish is a better review but hey, it is what it is, telling you the truth!
author: Kitty G.

description: Only come here for the roast duck and that orange squid that they made.  Love the sweet & sour sauce accompanied with the duck.  As for the barbeque pork, ask for the one with some fat in it.  All lean meat is not good, and it gets stuck in the gap of teeth.  The chicken is nasty; go to Dim Sum King or  that place on Ocean Ave instead if you want some good Princess Chicken (gwai fei gai) *Chinglish*
author: Tadaa T.

description:
hands down the best roast duck in the 'set. yes better than wins. problem is, feels like everytime i go, i want to jump over the counter and chop chop chop them mutha frakers. yeah service can be off most the time, but hey, if you were chop chop chop roast duck, roast pork, roast..... all day, everyday, youd be pretty pissy too right.

ive been here on rainy days, people stand out in the cold and rain for this shit.  CRACK I TELL YOU CRACK. 

i havent been by too often lately, ive learned to settle with wins roast duck, which is good in its own, but damn its like saying, yeah, a bmw is a nice car, but shit, it aint no mercedes *cough* hen a. * cough*. make a trip to cheung hing, live through the bad service, get a roast duck, you wont regret it.
author: Euge L.

description:
go there. there's always a line.

i got the bbq spare ribs and roast pork today. delish!
author: L M.

description:
cheung hing should come out with a line of roast duck flavored lip glosses. 

quite possibly the best roast duck in the city.
but their other selections are excellent as well. TRUST.

the place is too small to eat there, especially with all the takeout people gawking at you feed your face, rice flying, plates chattering, feet firmly planted, double fisted and frenzied, sweating profusely, wordless.

cuz that's what will happen. 
so definitely plan on taking out. 

bring a wrinkled, wadded up one dollar bill and all the leftover change you found in your car ashtray and you can get roast pork and duck over rice or any other rice plates, tendon soup, chow fun, or kick ass congee with the works with that chinese "doughnut".

if you can't speak cantonese and you're trying to buy a whole duck, good effin luck. you'll probably end up getting the smallest, boniest one if you're not privy to the sunset's "butcher etiquette". i recommend going on babelfish beforehand and looking up "not that one! i want that one!" coupled with fingerpointing, head movements, and miscellaneous forms of gesticulation. 

if you have any qualms about standing in a line that goes around the block, are especially vulnerable to the sunset chill, have varicose/ spider veins, or don't have cash on hand, take your ass to panda express.

the endeavor is cold and cruel, but anything worth having is worth working hard for. 

definitely.
author: Vanessa D.

description: I can't really complain about Chinese food here! My family orders for their huge parties here every year. There is always a line! A whole roast pig! Yummy. But I think Chinese food tastes the same everywhere, but I can tell if it is bad. The only bad thing about Chinese fast food is that it is too oily.
author: Janet Z.

description: I give them 5 stars for their roast pork.  I like it better here than the one on iriving where everyone lines up at.  If you go here when they are about to close and they have roast pork left, the'll give you all the skin!!!!  HELLS YEAH!!!  Their other stuff, duck and chicken are good too but it fluctuates a little...sometimes its super good sometimes it's just ok, so i have to drop them down a star. So for quality roast pork you should try out Cheung Hing.  For other stuff, just go down to Irving....or just take a chance and buy it at Cheung Hing if it looks good....gotta save gas right!!!!
author: LittleBird 8.

description: The best roast duck and roast pork in the Sunset! Pretty much a take-out place but there is table service if you dare.
author: Jeff X.

description: the staff looks like they haven't showered in 2 months and the floor looks like it hasn't been mopped in 2 years.  BUT THE ROAST DUCK IS CHRONIC.  don't try calling your order in if you don't speak chinese.  if you do, your fucked.  you'll end up with pigs feet instead of the duck.  better to just go there and point out what you want.
author: J M.

description:
I've gotten takeout here many, many times, but I'm done. First, credit where it's due: excellent Cantonese BBQ, the ducks, cha siu and other BBQ items are very, very tasty, some of the best in town. The rest of the menu is OK, not distinguished but lots of variety and good-size portions for the money. But the last time I was there I ordered one of my comfort food favorites, fried chicken wings. After ordering I went down the street to use the ATM and when I returned I was told that I couldn't have them because they had already shut down the fryer. (Actually it was a patron who translated this information for me since the cashier didn't have enough English to explain it herself.) 
The place is open until 9:00PM. I ordered at about 8:35. In my book, either you're open or you're not. Or, one could at least put a notice on the menu that certain items might not be available after a certain time. So I had driven over there for this specific item and they weren't out of it, and they didn't inform me when I ordered that they couldn't fill the order. 
But that's not it. I have been to lots and lots of restaurants and takeout places and when they disappoint a customer many, if not most, try to make up for it in some way. For instance, there were still three or four barbecued ducks hanging in the window and it was fifteen minutes until closing. If they had offered me a half duck or at least something for my trouble I would have felt very good and well taken care of. Instead what I got was a perfunctory "Sorry" and that was the end of it. 
It's one of the few things I find unforgivable in a restaurant: a lousy sense of hospitality. It's the one thing that any restaurant in any price range can offer if they care to. 
I'm done with Cheung Hing.
author: Jerry M.

description: So glad this place is close to home. It's mostly a take-out place, but damn the roast duck w/ cabbage over rice is delicious. The sauce or excuse me, fat, is awesome. Especially when it flavors the rice underneath it. They really do have other dishes that are excellent as well, but try the roast duck. It's chinese comfort food at it's finest.
author: Jen Y.

description: I came here several times. Inside the restaurant , they have all the fancy meat hanging on the hook . Several include roast duck, roast pork. chicken, bbq pork. etc. I had a combination of roast duck and chicken. They come in a large portion. There meat taste great, not too salty. Great place for quick lunch or to go.
author: Tiffanie L.

description: ROAST DUCK PLEASE!!!  this is really the best place for roast duck.  Their roast pork is very good too!!  Can't find anything even remotely comparable elsewhere or anywhere.  Let me tell you how good this place is...Since I've started coming here, Roast duck elsewhere does not satisfy.  Actually going anywhere else makes me crave duck from this place even more.  Totally incomparable!  There always seems be a long line, but no wait is too long for mouthwatering ROAST DUCK!!
author: LoveFood I.

description: All bets are off when it comes to the roast duck. This is the place to get it. I've only ever had the roast duck and the roast pork here so I can't speak for much else but the roast duck is wonderful. Crispy skin, nice fatty meat and oh so tasty. Taking it to go is even better, that way you can pig out with a big bowl of rice as you attack those chopped up duck pieces as the duck grease dribbles down your lips in private.
author: kristin e.

description:
I never understand why some people peel off the skin when the eat a duck.  All the flavor's in there.  OK, maybe not all the flavors but most of it.  It would be like eating a burger without the meat patty.  People who peel the skin off their ducks before eating them shouldn't be eating ducks, OK?  OK!

When it comes to eating the roast duck in Cheung Hing, it should be sacrilegious to peel the skin off.  Skin-peelers should be thrown out the street on their ears.  Maybe that's why most customers who frequent Cheung Hing buy their birds to go.

CH is likely the best cantonese roast duck in the Bay Area -- that crown used to belong to Kwong Shing on Clement but unfortunately they closed a few years ago.  CH's roast duck has crispy skin and the marinade has penetrated into the meat of the bird.  The subcutaneous fat (prized by the way by French cooks, you fat avoiders out there) has mostly dripped away by the slow roasting.  The skin is crisped up, I'm guessing, by a final half hour of higher temperature roasting while the meat is kept tender by a steaming/boiling process via the hot water in the body cavity.

CH's roast duck has changed flavors slightly though.  The marinade used to flavor the duck is now with less sugar/molasses and is more savory.  I liked the older formula better.

CH's char siu is pretty good too but believe it or not the best char siu in the city is at Yank Sing.
author: Dave M.

description: Another great & budget restaurant in Sunset area.  Love their rice plate & noodle.  Expect $6/person for take out & expect $10/person if ordering dishes with friends, with tax & tips included.  As for roast duck, Lam Hoa Thuan Restaurant on Irving is my pick, personally opinion.  Beyond that, this is a must go restaurant.  Soy chicken and other BBQ are just as tasty.  Tables may not be adequate but it's worth the wait.  For Non-Chinese pals, although they speak limited English but definitely able to serve you with what you want.  One last point, order from the menu and not the dishes displayed, those goes by weight and personally I feel they a little expensive but if you like them, why not?
author: P. C.

description:
It's funny reading some earlier reviews of this place to see how high some expectations can be overall. I believe that giving an honest opinion is best when it comes to telling others about how a place is rather that use language which doesn't even resemble English. The restaurant in question is a small hole in the wall type place that can only fit about 25 people within max. It's more of a take our joint more than anything but I can easily say the best thing on the menu is their BBQ pork. I've seen countless times where people ordered BBQ duck and get ripped off with the lower parts of the bird. Since my folks and I go maybe once every couple months the people who work there know us already so there isn't a problem when it comes to getting the better meats. However with that said I am disappointed at the rising costs and smaller portions of the meal. Sometimes it seems like there's always more cabbage and rice with less meat.

Along with that, it's also annoying when your ordering out something that the people will always give you more than what you want. If i ordered 1/4 pound of something they will always give me 1/2 a pond and so forth. Sometimes I can really care less but at other moments it gets dull fast always having too much. I've never found service to be an issue but I can see where others have complaints. I don't usually order anything different from the norm but take my advice and just order the pork. Get the leanest meat possible and you wont be disappointed. Avoid the roasted duck over rice and buy the whole thing instead if you want the real experience of this place.
author: Jason Y.

description: My family's go-to place for takeout roast duck, cha siu, and roast pork.  I love the smell of roast and bbq goodness.  Yum.
author: Melinda C.

description: Roast Duck is the best!!! Lines are out the door during dinner rush hour. I always come here for my fix of Chinese BBQ. Definitely a to go place. Very limited seating. I also recommend the HK style beef and vegetable chow mein and chow fun.
author: Jeanette W.

description:
one more vote for the best roast duck !
great for take out.
this place is straight business. 
dont piss the man behind the counter off. they will yell at you..
author: sherly A.

description: OMG. My friend told me that this is the best roast duck in San Francisco and damn...he was right. Best...roast duck...EVER! The flavor is just right, and there's actually a good amount of meat on it too. Hands down this place is 5 stars.
author: Chrys U.

description: I went there yesterday to buy some BBQ pork to make some fried rice for dinner.  While waiting in line, I look over some of the cooked dishes they had and decide to get some tofu.  They had three different types on display and I wanted the deep fried tofu stuffed with meat.  The lady helping me asks how much I want and I said half a pound but she kept insisting I get a whole pound.  She spoke in Chinese.  I ordered in Chinese but it doesn't mean I understood everything she said.  Anyway, after she kept insisting, I just took the pound.  I think she was just trying to get rid of it since there was only a bit left.  Then I got a small box of green beans and my half pound of BBQ pork.  The guy in front of me was ordering a duck.  He was not Chinese and ordered in English.  They had chopped up a duck and gave it to him but then he complained and said they didn't let him pick the duck he wanted.  The people behind the counter, who didn't know English very well, opened the box with the chopped up duck and said it's a very good duck but he kept on insisting he didn't get to pick his duck.  Eventually, they gave in, and let him pick his duck and chopped it up for him.  Then they tried to sell the guy behind me the chopped up duck.  Anyways, the whole time I was there, the lady behind the counter kept asking me if I wanted anything else.  I think she asked like 10 plus times.  Seriously.  It was around 5pm so I guess they wanted to make sure they sell all their food.  So after paying $12 for green beans, tofu and BBQ pork, I discover upon returning home that I lost $5.  And I'm pretty sure I dropped it as I was paying.  I was carrying my son in the left arm and had a little trouble getting cash out of my wallet.  Anyway, so I am $17 poorer since that place does not take credit card.  That would be all fine if the food was good.  The BBQ pork and green beans were fine but the deep fried tofu I had was gross.  I ate about two pieces of it and noticed it tasted kinda funny.  I gave two cut-up small pieces to my 16 month old son and he ate the first piece that had no meat in it but immediately spit out the piece with some meat.  My husband had a piece and he said it tasted funny and he's really not that picky about food.  So I heat up another piece thinking maybe it tastes funny because it's cold but I end up spitting it out .  The meat was gross tasting and the tofu tasted old.  In the compost bin the rest of it goes.  It was definitely not fresh.  No wonder she kept trying to sell it and pass it off to me.  Ugh!  I will not return.  There are other places I can get BBQ pork from that has much better service.
author: Christina H.

description:
0 stars is more like it. 

 First restaurant I TOTALLY disagree with yelp on (usually they are spot on).
I also am Caucasian but love authentic chinese food. 

1. Duck? The fattiest duck I have ever seen, almost inedible. 
2. Service, very poor, 6 tables or so.
3. Got there at 6:30, ordered, then told no chow fun, no bbq ribs.
4. They brought bbq pork combo even though we hadn't ordered it, and of course charged us. We were so hungry after our selections were not available and the duck was horrid, we accepted it. 

$25 for 3 of the worst dishes I have eaten. There are SO MANY awesome chinese restaurants listed in yelp, that have been super. How this place gets more than a one star AVOID AT ALL COSTS boggles my mind. 

Wonder if the restaurant themselves wrote these reviews as this place really wasn't even close... Not even close.
author: G L.

description: the duck maker left the coop, not going to tell you where he went, you all just need to come back here!
author: david c.

description: best roast duck around. but had a really awful service experience here so i cannot give it more stars. if you're in the mood for Chinese roast duck, stop by for take out. Oh BTW, it helps a lot if you speak Chinese here.
author: Jeff W.

description: You would think you'd have to go to Hong Kong for such good food.  Mouth watering succulent duck, bbq pork, roasted pork, and five spice chicken are ALL five stars!!!  One of the best in town. There's usually a line in the evening, but it moves quite quickly.  This is more of a to-go deli type of place, but there are several tables if you want to eat in.  They close around 8pm..so there's plenty of time to drop by after work.
author: hello k.

description: Did I ever mention that I LOVE roast duck?? If you want duck that actually has meat on it then come here because they dont give the shitty and skimpy portions with no meat on the bones- their portions are definitely worth the $$$- so tasty!
author: M W.

description:
I don't live in the neigborhood but I don't mind to drive there for the yummy BBQ pork and roast duck!  They are perfectly made each time!
Best in the city!
author: Aggie Y.

description:
My family has been going here for years, ever since I was a wee little girl. I still have photos of my sister and I standing right outside of this place. Ever since we were kids, my family and I came here for some AHH-mazing roast duck and jok. I have fond memories of Sunday lunches spent here, filling our little bellies of congee, yao tiu, and for dinner, a take out box of sliced roast duck. 

This is the place to go for the most heavenly roast duck! Whenever we're in town visiting relatives, my parents still stop by here for some roast duck take out, and it makes for a great meal every time. Who can worry about all the grease, oil, and all the fattiness that goes into eating Chinese roast duck when you have Cheung Hing serving up the finest of fine? And as every duck eating connoisseur knows, the pieces with the least amount of meat are the most flavorful.. aahh.. I'm just salivating now from dreaming of it.
author: amy y.

description:
i love this place! its what a good hole in the wall chinese place should be. cheap, yummy, no frills chinese food. theres usually a line for the duck etc hanging in the window whenever i go but if you opt to sit in and eat, i havent had too much trouble getting a seat and seeing how theres only about four or five tables total, service is really quick.

its a bit of a trek from where i live but luckily for me, my dry cleaners is right up the street so i try to order from here whenever i can. i always get the duck, braised tofu and the minced beef with egg over rice. the egg is key.

my first five star rating for a food place and well deserved. i always leave here feeling satisfied and for that cheap of prices, theres really nothing to complain about. yay for hole in the wall places! i need to find more of these for sure.
author: georgette y.

description:
came here after class one day with a craving for roast duck.

walked in, ordered a roast duck over rice, drove home and YUM! 

*drools*....   crispy skin and moist duck meat, simply awesome.

one of lifes simple pleasures.

COME GET SOME!
author: David D.

description: This is the place for great soy sauce chicken, roast duck, and cuttlefish, among other delicious hong-kong style delicacies.
author: Will R.

description: this is the joint!  it'll be cold and foggy as hell and peeps will be lined up out the door.  The wait can be like 30mins out in the cold.  Best Roast Duck I've ever tasted and I don't care of people say the service sucks!  it's kinda like the Soup Nazi... we're talking about the Duck Nazi.  If you don't speak (Cantonese that is), smile, have the money ready, and don't say a word when they pick you out a skinny ass duck.  When you get your's, run home and make a big pot of rice.  Crack open a Tsing-Tao and eat until you can't eat no more!  Then, save the rest for lunch tomorrow!  I would have given it 5 stars if they gave napkins or plastic forks with the take out!
author: fred t.

description:
I cant believe all the good reviews for this place.  It is the nastiest chinese food I ever had.  I tasted each item on my plate and was pissed off.  I tossed it out immedietely.  I really dont get why people go here.  I bank right next door and I see the deliveries they get.  Skinned pigs on the dirty floor of the truck, hanging off the door.  Made me gag  

The sprite was good. (canned)
author: Dan M.

description:
Pros:
GREAT BBQ
Recommendations:
ROAST DUCK
BBQ PORK
ROAST PORK
all are packed with great, amazing flavor.

Cons:
service is not the best.
food is very fattening but still very delicious
author: jason l.

description: This is the place for Chinese BBQ. They have everything from chicken, duck to pork. It is boiled, fried or roasted. At around 6pm one can see how popular this place is when this tiny place has a line that wraps around the block.
author: M C.

description:
awesome duck and roast pork!  the best of ive had in SF so far!  both the duck and roast pork were really flavorful.  the roast pork is sold by the pound and the duck is sold half or whole.  the whole duck is $13.35, which is ridiculously inexpensive for a whole duck.  

be prepared...bring cash and make sure you have enough time to stand in line.  the line moves fast, but it gets really crowded so make sure you know what you want when you get to the counter.  this isn't really a restaurant, since they only have 4 tables.  i would advise just get take away.
author: Wendy S.

description:
Best roast duck and roast pork in the sunset.  

It is true that they sell the crappier meats  to non Chinese, ABCs, and younger Asian females.  They figure they wont complain I guess.  

Also it isnt clean.  But that's not a surprise either.
author: Jeff H.

description: could be cleaner but can not beat its duck noodle soups
author: Emm C.

description: Best Chinese style roast duck in the city...lines can get long and a bit unorganized but it's worth it.  Total hole in the wall- but I think a roast duck rice plate is $4 - good value!
author: Amina B.

description: I tried the roast duck noodle lai fun.  The soup and the noodles were very tastly because the drippings and the grease from the duck really flavored the noodles.  THe problem was that the duck was very fatty and didnt have much duck meat.  I think the one in millbrae is a little bit better.
author: Stevezee C.

description: It's true, they really have amazing roast duck. It was succulent and had a tremendous five spice flavor. On the other hand, it had too much juice, and was lacking the crispy skin that I usually enjoy with roast duck. It also seemed a little under cooked. The service at this place was horrific! They told me there were no plates even though there was a stack of plates right behind the woman who was telling me there are no plates. When I asked for chopsticks, you'd think I had insulted the waitress from her reaction. Absolutely ridiculous. I had some veggies on rice for $6.95 which seemed like a lot and some of the veggies were smothered with a very sweet sugar like sauce which ruined the taste. Overall, I wouldn't return.
author: Eater S.

description: Seriously, best roast duck in the entire city. This food is so delicious, that you just might HAVE to eat it... 3 times! Heart attack on a duck leg? i think it's worth it. Maybe even a stroke... just maybe. Still worth any ailment that you might have to endure afterwards IMO. KEKEKE
author: Chris L.

description: I stood in line on one of the craziest day to ever be in this place "CHINESE NEW YEAR" ...line was crazy! I came here under recommendation of a friend who once served me steamed chicken with ginger sauce. It was soo good that I had to know where he bought the chicken. After feeling so ill 2-3 days in a row, I dreamt of eating the same chicken, made a trip down this small hole in the wall place only to find myself standing in line for close to 30min. The chicken was cheap 6-9 bucks for a whole chicken (cost is equivalent to weight measurement of the item). I was stunned to find a line, then again it may just be the day's event. The chicken tasted just the way I had it last and i will definitely come back again for another because of the price.
author: Ateh M.

description: Many BBQ items are scrumptious, but it's really cramp in there. I recommend getting take-out cause it's small and really crowded. Not the cleanest or tidyest place around either! But the staff is friendly and the food is consistently good.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Upon arriving at this crowded little sit in restaurant, we see a bunch of ducks hanging in front of the window.  There was one duck that was particularly smaller than the rest.  It was about 2/3rds the size of the rest of the ducks.  The people ordering the ducks to go while standing in line didn't mind, because they had a watch over which duck they were receiving.  

The menu for the sit-in price is a dollar more than the to-go price for the barbeque, but  that's no big deal since one assumes that they're paying for the use of the dining table and utensils.  The problems with this setup however is that you don't see that they serve you the smallest duck that no one wanted in the to-go line, so you're essentially paying more and getting one third less.  The lesson here is, don't order the duck while sitting in.

Now the real problem comes from another dish that we ordered.  We had a shrimp dish with vegetables.  One of the vegetables was broccoli.  This one broccoli we had was so bad that it look like mold was growing in it.  This is the reason for the one star.
author: Cheng X.

description: Food is pretty good here. Love the roast duck and pork but the lady behind the counter is very pushy and try to make you buy more stuff.
author: Steven J.

description: Roast duck! Roast pork! Steamed chicken!  Outside of the motherland, this place has got some of the Bay Area's best siu lop dude....grubbin and so affordable, even on a teacher's salary.....tip...go close to closing time, the portions are more generous and you can bring the leftovers for lunch the next day.....
author: Kenny Y.

description:
The Cantonese bbq stuff is awesome here, roast duck, bbq pork, I had it over rice. Lines out the door, you know wassup

Ok the meat can be a bit fatty, you can ask for it the way you like 

To try
- noodle soup
- cuttlefish (muk yu)
author: xo x.

description: I agree with everyone the roast duck is good! The other stuff they have here is pretty good too. My mom saves time and work and preorder a cook Turkey here for Thanksgiving! The Turkey is pretty good.  A lot of good white meat. You can cater food  out here too, at pretty reasonable prices. My complaint main is the service, wait and communication problem if you can't speak good Chinese. Otherwise I would give it 4 stars. Also it mainly for take-out, they do have a few tables but not pleasurable to sit here and eat.
author: Leon C.

description: Cheung Hing doesn't mess around with the roast duck...the long lines outside testify to what people will do to get some.  Chicken is also pretty good, especially the cold boiled.  Roast duck plate will run you about $4 bucks. Can't beat that.
author: Eric G.

description: Okay, I hate this place. I simply despise it. I went there once, with a Chinese friend who ordered for us. She couldn't remember a simple word which immediately ignited derision, that resumed all throughout our dinner. It's annoying and  the food sucks. Frankly, I'd rather eat dirt, or U.S. Army MRE's.
author: Roger W.

description: Yes, the duck is amazing. Other stuff is a little dicey.
author: Gregory M.

description: Best place in the city for roast duck and bbq pork!  Long line for take-outs but it's worth the wait.  I wouldn't recommend dining in.  The place is way too small!
author: Edna T.

description:
A hole-in-the- wall place. I have eaten here many many times. For my first time here, my friend said to order the roast duck and BBQ pork over rice. It comes with some cabbage. Yep, my friend was absolutely right because every time I have come here, thats what I have ordered, nothing else. It is that good. I have had roast duck from just about every where in San Francisco and this place stands out as number one. I want to try other things on the menu but I can't pass up the roast duck.

FOOD:
The roast duck and BBQ pork is outstanding and irresistable here. I have not tried anything else. I will update this review if I try something different.

SERVICE:
If you dine-in, service is hurried because they are busy and they have a very small staff to serve many customers. People can mistake this service for rudeness. Know what you want and order everything at the same time. Don't expect too much here.

AMBIANCE:
A small place with only about six tables with seating crowded together. Tables and floors are sometimes sticky and greasy. Roast duck and BBQ pork can be seen hanging in the window. For some people from different ethnic groups, seeing  the duck or a roasted pig's head may cause you to lose your appetite. Customers waiting in line to order take-out stand along side the tables.

PRICE:
Roast duck and BBQ pork over a bed of cabbage and white rice with a soda will run you about $7.50.

FINAL NOTES:
This a busy place with a steady stream of customers. There are metered street parking in front if you're lucky to get one. It is directly across the street from the Safeway supermarket.

THE ROAST DUCK IS TO DIE FOR AND YOU WILL BE IN HEAVEN!
author: David D.

description: I loved this place!  It is a hole in a wall, super busy spot with the best Chinese roast duck I've ever had.  The roast pork was great, too -- super crispy skin.  I also had the congee with century egg and pork.  It's definitely an acquired taste, but I think the preserved eggs complimented the rice porridge very well.  The duck tongues didn't look very pretty and might make you feel like quacking, but hey, it's a delicacy.  If you're not too sheepish about "weird food" and a true culinary adventurist, dig in!
author: Desiree a.

description:
good: great duck & roast pork
Bad: Tend to ignore Non-Asians.
I've experienced this several times over the years.
Example: I'll stand there 15 minutes & when it 's my turn, the person next to you will quickly bark his order.  Last week, I stood in line for 15 minutes, The guy behind me shouts his order. I objected. 
 I was pointed & directed to the end of the line, in Cantonese! I shook my head, no!  
However, once you have their attention the attendant will try to sell you  more than what you came in for.
Real dog eat dog attitude
Moving forward, I'll take my money to Wins (40th & Taraval)
author: Sandy P.

description: The fact that there's always a line out the door should tell you something.  Roast duck and BBQ pork over rice.  You can't fuck with it.
author: Tommy O.

description: aight.. so i came here with a friend to try their famous roast duck and first of all the guy serving me didnt know english when i started asking him questions.. so i just ordered the duck over rice to go.. when we got home to eat i notice i had no meat whatsoever in my box.. it was all the crap pieces with bones.. he also cut me the bottom part of the leg which had nothing.. funny thing is.. when i got there i told him i found this place on yelp.. he didnt understand.. i disappointed my friend cause i said this place should be good due to yelp.. im annoyed.. im done..
author: kevin j.

description: These guys might be know for their roast duck but they are not going to win any rewards for the beef chow fun, chicken wings, spring rolls or the seafood chow fun. This is the second time we ate here. The first time we left with the impression that the food was sub par for SF Chinese. We were surprised to see the positive yelp reviews so we decided to give them a second try. We were more disappointed the second go around. The Beef Chow fun was barely adequate, chicken wings had a strange odor, the Spring rolls were tasteless and the scallops in the Seafood chow fun had a weird taste. I would generally recommend staying way from their deep fried. This is one of the few times we elected not to take a doggy bag when there was significant left overs. I would recommend Panda Express over these guy (and I don't generally recommend Panda Express.
author: M B.

description: 3 stars for the roast pork.  crispy skin, fat and pork.  pork is good.  i love pork.  ribs, butt, shoulder, intestines, feet i love it all.  i don't know what it is but i get a boner thinking about pig.
author: goldberg d.

description: the BEST roast duck in town. when i want duck i come here. there is always a line out the door. my friends from fairfield love it too. anytime i go back to sf to visit family my fairfield friends ask me to pick them up some.... roast duck....greasy goodness!
author: Linda L.

description: always a long line when a chinese holiday comes up! but the food is worth it. whenever my mom and i stop by, we always get the bbq pork and the soy sauce chicken. and from the hot food section the fried tofu and mixed veggies are really good too!! watch out for the old ladies that cut u line line tho...
author: christy w.

description: darn good roast duck, roast pork belly, BBQ pork!  the cuts are good and you can request extra fatty or lean depending on what rocks your boat.  its not the cheapest but the quality and taste is worth it.  quite a hike to sunset - which separates the real foodies from the rest. order take out (the shop itself is not pleasant for eating in) and share with a group of friends/family at home - you'll be everyone's favorite friend!
author: Teresa T.

description: I lined up in the rain for the roasted pork (cha sui). I bought a few pounds so we can have it for dinner. It's like a chinese fast food joint for roasted or bbq food. You line up, order what you want, pay up and leave. I don't a waiter for ordering to go. If you go on the weekends, just follow the line, which is usually out the door.
author: bob k.

description: they don't speak very good english so sometimes it's discouraging to call ahead and try to beat the looooong lines outside around dinnertime. but the food is good and cheap. duck is tasty. and their hong kong style friend house chow mein is my favorite! and it's only $3-something!!!! everywhere else it's like $6-something or more. but it tastes just as good if not better than the chow mein i've had in chinatown or milpitas. i don't know how they do it.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: roast duck? fabulous! bbq pork? tasty, roast pork? flippin awsome. this is THE PLACE to come for the roast duck cravings. and their tofu is so yummy. normally ill pass on the super greasy stuff but this is the good and addictive kind of greasy. haha. i havent found anyone who can top cheung hing and doubt that ill ever. only thing is that im not chinese and sometimes i have no idea what so ever to what theyre saying to me but at least they understand what im trying to order right? just dont get here so late or else you might not leave with a duck and that would totally suck for you. esp on the weekends.
author: Tuan D.

description: Their ROAST DUCK is the best in the city. I don't even like roast duck, but I'd eat an entire one from Cheung Hing.
author: Judy L.

description:
i have been getting food here for years and years. basically grew up with the 5 spice chicken and house special chow mein because of the days my mom didn't feel like cooking. 

started eating at the restaurant more recently because the bf has grown to love the food there too, especially the noodles (crispy) and the chicken wings. saw they had turkeys for thanksgiving and they looked pretty good too! heard one girl say that a 17.5lb turkey was about 50 bucks. 

i've grown to love the efficiency of the ladies who work the line/register...and with the good prices they provide, looks like i'll be a customer for while too.
author: L B.

description: this is the place to go to get your roast duck, roast pork, soysauce chicken, steam chicken, and bbq pork.  period.
author: Peter L.

description: killa roast duck and roast pork... good rice plates too.......
author: neldog W.

description: I have not had better roast duck or roast pork! Not much seating in the restaurant, take out is the best way to go.
author: neal j.

description: Expect arguably the best Chinese BBQ around with a big helping of "Kiss my a@# if you don't like what we sell or how we sell it!".  In all seriousness, the BBQ meat items here rock the house.  Don't listen to the overly sensitive Yelpers that gave this place a bad rating because the people at the counter didn't smile at them or care to hold up the whole line of patrons to practice their English.  Put on your game face, get what you came for, and go eat it.  What about the food?  The duck.  The duck.  The duck.  Did I mention the bomb duck?  This is what keeps me coming back.  They have the best roast duck around, and never second guess that.  Just read the reviews of other Chinese BBQ joints.  Inevitably, they all get compared to Cheung Hing.  The roast pork with crispy skin and BBQ pork are also great.  If you're feeling a little more adventurous, then order some of the BBQ duck livers.  I haven't really had the other dishes there, just the BBQ.  If you're going for duck, get there early and wait in line.  Sometimes they run out, and that makes for a very sad trip to your backup roast duck joint.
author: Frank S.
